data: b'If ever a movie needed subtitles in English, this is one. The accents and the soft conversations are great but difficult to follow because you can not understand what they say and they do not have subtitles. Their songs were simply beautiful and the story is great, but you lose a lot by not grasping what they say. But it was a most refreshing movie now. Good acting and history.'

b"`` Just Married '' is a painfully cheesy movie that is almost too cheerful and tender. Ashton Kutcher and Brittany Murphy play a couple of Romeo and Juliet that has been repeated in so many movies, is disgusting: he is the classic sports fan and the son of middle-income parents, and she is the daughter of a billion whose profession we never learn Her parents would have preferred to marry her to the snob of Peter Prentice, a boring antagonist who is more of an obstacle than a real character. Anyway, the cute couple gets married and travels to Europe where their lies between them and the incredible circumstances (they are expelled from a hotel after they ruin the circuit system when trying to connect some kind of sex toy) make it difficult to enjoy of the perfect honeymoon The movie got worse with bad jokes, boring characters and clich\xc3\xa9 and egrave; stories. I think I considered laughing once. The terrible thing about this movie was how amazing everything was. Each character was able to bring out a beautiful and moving monologue from nothing. Most of the speeches did not even fit the personality of the character, for example, Kutcher's character gave at least two of these monologues, and each was one of the best parts of the script of the film. Too bad they seemed forced and uncomfortable, since it is assumed that the character is not the brightest bulb in the box. Finally, the characters were painfully underdeveloped. We do not know if Murphy's character likes to be rich or not, and we can not really discern whether she is a rich ditz or an intellectual lover of art. We never found out what Murphy's father does, and although a good and strong father-son relationship between the character of Kutcher and his father is insinuated, we never know for sure. Finally, an attractive blonde was constantly close to Murphy's character ... was she a sister? friend ? cousin ? It bothered me throughout the movie. So, why not 1 star instead of 2? Well, Murphy and Kutcher proved to be excellent actors with incredible chemistry together. Murphy especially illuminated the screen with his dazzling personality and his cute and rough voice. Kutcher will be typecast forever as the fool, but he is a character that suits him. I discovered that they were the only highlights of the movie. In the last row: this movie kept me awake. It was quick and pleasant, but something fresh or different was missing. See if you like teenage chick fliks, not if your idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8ba movie is what will make you think."

b'I may not be able to add much to the reviews, whose compliments I totally agree with the content of this magnificent movie, but I still felt compelled to offer my two cents on the BluRay, which is equally fantastic. With the measure of the grandeur of the pure grandfather of the backdrop of this story now rightly restored in HiDef, the inherent drama of the plot now, finally, finally, has an equally valuable canvas on which it will present itself: a fact that It has been perpetually lost in every other video presentation I\'ve seen before. In fact, it is an impressive revaluation of the expected impact of this film and, from all the previous video editions, a transformation from a first level adventure, in another acceptably good way, to a first level adventure and, in Overall, an extraordinary show! I dare say it did not seem so good when I remember seeing it in my local theater so many years ago. For that matter, it looks so good, I do not think anyone can dream, since its appearance here, that this film, in fact, is approaching its 50th anniversary. From the opening credits, I see that the film was originally filmed on 70 mm, with much more detail than the more common 35 mm films. You can expect similar performance in HiDef with other movies of the 65 or 70 mm variety, such as 2001: A Space Odessy or Lawrence of Arabia - IF the disk transfer is good - and here it certainly is. The image inside the frame on this disc is always, and completely, as stable as the Rock of Gibralter. There was only the smallest amount of flicker, as seen in my configuration, but, again, only rarely and barely noticed when it was seen, I\'m still not sure if the disc was blameless or not. Not a shred of moir\xc3\xa9, nowhere. The sound is quite good and much better than I had any reason to wait. Although John Barry\'s excellent score was apparently originally in mono, it is by far the best I\'ve heard of him before; it even has a better impression than the original soundtrack (mono) available on CD, if memory serves me. However, the sound effects track on this disc is true stereo or, more likely, is derived from several isolated sound effects elements and then "panned" during postproduction. There are even some good extras: more than two documentaries about the making of the film, comments about the film, the theatrical trailer and even a brief, but interesting interview with John Barry himself, about the origins of his ideas for the score. But, in general, I love it when a film as majestic and monumental as this one receives the real treatment it has here. Sometimes, the presentation is everything! Highly recommended! !'

b"I have been a 3D nut for many decades. I pre-ordered this from amazon and man, what disappointment! The video quality is only slightly better than the shutter 3D DVD shutter since the 90s (and at least the 3D DVD was COMPLETE SCREEN) that was made from a 3D Japanese VHD disc. Even the `` red / blue '' 3D trailer of this film (from 3D Film Expo at the Egyptian Theater here in Hollywood) was Full Screen. If you search Google for this title, you will find some websites with photographic comparisons (PAL, NTSC, DVD, Blu-ray, etc.) and you can clearly see that this 3D Blu-ray reaps the film from ALL FOUR SIDES. Only a little is cropped from the left / right, but a bit is missing from the top and bottom to create this ratio of 1.85 from Full screen. Part of the 3D perception is lost because of this, and is probably what others here have meant with certain scenes that look like `` flat '' or `` 2D ''. One of the most striking scenes is one in which Margot and Mark are talking in the living room. This wonderful photo is obviously set up for the 3D effect. Margot's hand rests on the final table in the foreground, showing that beautiful diamond ring. Guess what ? In this Blu-ray 3D release, ALL your hand is completely cut! I kept noticing these scenes cut out throughout the film ... characters cut out in the waste, covers of lampshades cut out, etc. Yes, it's great to see that the red dress looks REALLY red, but unfortunately the colors are severely oversaturated. I think I'll stop at `` House of Wax '' or `` Creature FTBL '' until they get criticism from other guinea pigs out there, ha ha! I'm sure others will agree that the black ink printed on the Blu-ray disc itself seems horrible. I've seen better labels on pirated DVDs! Anyway, just my 2 cents."

b"When I discovered that this version of Lonesome Dove is abbreviated, it made me cancel my order immediately. Every moment of the show is great; I'm not sure why anyone would want to leave out specific segments of the show."

b'This review is to point out that this version (Westlake Entertainment) of Escape from Sobibor (which is a great docudrama) is NOT the uncut version of 143 minutes as indicated in the Amazon list and is also indicated on the cover of the DVD. In fact, it is the 120 minute version offered by many other distributors. Also, the transfer in this version of Weslake is not excellent. I have the TGG / Diamond version (also 120 minutes) which is a much better transfer.'

b'If you look at the fine print of this DVD, you will see that it is not approved by the Wayne Foundation. And what a note. The image quality of this DVD has all the characteristics of being a DVD recording of a VHS copy of the movie. They did not even bother using a new VHS tape: judging by the grainy texture and the annoying flaws that prevail (blinks, "hairs" on the screen, etc.) it was captured from an old copy of the tape. I have a VHS tape that has a better image than this DVD. Everyone PLEASE write the Wayne Foundation and tell them about the poor quality release of this movie! If we make ourselves heard, we could convince them to publish panoramic versions of Criterion quality of the less famous films of John Wayne. UPDATE: PLEASE BE AWARE! This revision DOES NOT APPLY NECESSARILY TO THE SPECIAL EDITION. Amazon is mixing all the McLintock! Check in a single bag. I do not know what the quality of the Special Edition (launched in October 2005) is, but it is not necessarily the same as in previous editions.'

b'This movie is based on a true story, and I\'ve seen the original story in `` A Haunting. "I was hoping that the film version would give me a creepy version of the original story, but all I got was bad acting, a dull story and terrible effects." The director seemed to have an excellent idea in his head, but he could not project it. They tried too hard to make the story "better." As a result, the story came out as corny and exaggerated. If you want to get a better and more accurate version of the story, check the `` A Haunting \'\' version.'

b"... but a terrible DVD. The sound is old Dolby Surround and the movie is in full screen. This seems very annoying to me. I've always liked Joshua Tree and I was waiting for its release on DVD. I would like to start a campaign for Artisan to change his mind. To re-launch this impressive film in widescreen format. They must do this since this movie is totally rock. Even the current cover is tremendously horrible. A temperamental image of a Joshua Tree would be better. One last thing. Amazon and the back of the DVD indicate that the runtime is 102 minutes when in reality it is the unclassified version 106. This version should remain intact in the future widescreen release."

b"If you want to be alone while you watch Alone In The Dark, there is good news and bad news. The good news is that you will get your wish. The bad news is that misery loves the company. Being hung by red nipple clamps over a pit of cactus and scorpions would be less painful than sitting through this menage a trash about aliens, monsters, nefarious scientists, kidnapped children, a paranormal putz and Tara Reid as a museum curator. Pell\xc3\xadceme, I must be dreaming. Better a pinch than a slap in the face, which is what this hokey poky of a movie offers. Alone in the Dark is supposedly based on an old Atari game, one I've never heard of. What I do remember about the old games of Atari were its graphics and rudimentary plots. I doubt that the later extended history of the film was even a consideration. So to fill in the blanks, writers Elan Mastai, Michael Roesch and Peter Scheerer borrow and steal from other films. Best Movies. Movies that make you realize that you are not only watching an imitation, but a really bad imitation, like Chuck Norris doing his tribute to Judy Garland. I'll admit that his interpretation of the Easter Parade made me cry, but only because he was kicking me in the face. That's what it feels like to see Solo in the dark. I do not care about stupid, stupid horror movies, but I hate the stupid, stupid horror movies that refuse to acknowledge that fact. Alone in the Dark comes with a poker face so impossible to know if we're supposed to take any of this seriously. We are, but we do not, or more precisely, we can not. There is no room for maneuver in the script, direction or performance. Alone in the Dark abounds with government conspiracies (after a slavishly long crawl), which finds paranormal investigator Edward Carnby (Christian Slater) teaming up with an elite group of government agents to defeat an ancient evil. As an orphan, Edward escaped the clutches of the unscrupulous government agent / scientist Lionel Hudgens (Matthew Walker), whose depraved experiments turned children into crossed zombies. Now that Hudgens has found the final key to unlocking the portal between darkness and light, it's up to Edward, the former lover and healer Aline Cedrac (Reid) and the command leader Burke (Stephen Dorff) to save humanity. Yes, that's who I would call when the ultimate evil decides to hit humanity: two actors who travel down the lane straight to the video and an actress best known to the paparazzi. Was this a casting decision or a retribution? The director Uwe Boll (The House of the Dead) is not much help, since he never allows the actors to come out of the box of paper or express any emotion beyond the written word. If everyone, in front or behind the camera, simply recognized the obvious, Alone in the Dark would have been a hoot. Computer-generated monsters that never seem to occupy the same frame as the actors, trigger-happy commands, an intricate plot that does not make sense, characters from paper dolls, all the symbols of a good silly moment. Very bad the people behind Alone in the Dark did not fall into that trap."

b"I do not know who I feel for more, Stephen Dorff or Christian Slater. Dorff, who is a great actor, although you would never know it from the films he is in, has not been anywhere remotely good since the original Blade in 1998. Slater's career has been declining over the years, by participating in some flop projects. Both sleepwalking actors through their roles in this latest video game for the adaptation of the screen of director Uwe Boll, the same guy who brought us another adaptation of video game, the incredibly bad House of the Dead. Alone in the Dark is not much better, with a history so nonexistent that you will be scratching your head wondering what is going on before praying for all to be killed. Tara Reid is also on board as the smart girl, and as mentioned by previous critics, we know she is smart because she wears glasses. There is no redeeming factor about Alone in the Dark, and if you submit to the House of the Dead farce, then you know what to expect here."

b"This DVD tries to put in an hour all the history of the exploration of North America. Given his goal, I think he does a decent job doing it. He summarized five hundred years of history and many dozens of expeditions and explorers in brief pieces of information. I do not think that this is a good educational tool, since it would probably lack interest, it does not have very interesting stories, only a flow of information. Rather, this is a good starting point for someone who wants to research exploration in North America and wants an introduction to the main events and people in their history. It's not really something that excites people about the story, people who see this should already be excited."

b"I really thought it would be amazing to watch a movie in 3D AND HD ... but unfortunately they have not found a way to provide a 3D experience at home without discoloration of the characters. Because of the glasses everything in the image has a green tinge. In a way, it defeats HD's purpose. Apart from that, the movie is pretty good! I have not yet seen the 2d version, so I really can not review that aspect of the disc, but there are some neat 3D effects despite the green people."

b'The special effects were fine, but the story was weak, silly and predictable. When I was a kid, I loved the Alien movies. Aliens (the second) is considered a classic in our house as we still laugh at how my mother made M & M rain in the theater after an alien frightened her. Then, with that, I was excited to see this movie and relive some of the memories. What a disappointment. It was not terrifying at all. The people in the theater were actually *** SLEEPING ***. I was jealous of them. In general, I was glad that this was a short film. Sadly, the most terrifying thing in this movie was a penguin. Do not see this. If you are a big fan of aliens or predators and you must catch it, wait for video or HBO.'

b'Before seeing this, do not make the mistake of grouping this movie with silly comedies like `` Tootsie \'\' and `` Mrs. Doubtfire. "Although based on a true story, director Greenwald eludes many of the Western (and Hollywood) conventions to bring one of the best westerns of the 1990s. Suzy Amis plays Jo, a woman who is too confident with some men After escaping to the west and leaving her child born out of wedlock, she is almost raped by two soldiers.To hide from them, she wears men\'s clothes and heals her face, eventually using her new fa\xc3\xa7ade to get what she wants. Ian McKellen plays the role of a woman who hates women, believing he is a young man, and eventually befriends Bo Hopkins, who has his best role in years, and starts a sheep ranch. She falls in love with a Chinese woman who was forced to hire her as her cook, and eventually she has to fight against a group of cattle that tries to carve out and expel the ranchers, Am\xc3\xa9s looks like Eric Stoltz in his scenes as a man, and it is totally credible McKellan and Rene Auberjonois have small but fundamental roles as older father figures in whom Amis trusts, but eventually turn against her. Bo Hopkins is excellent since the neighbor Amis tolerates, befriends and tolerates. David Chung plays the Chinese man nicknamed Tin Man as a defective man addicted to sick opium. It looks perfect for the part, scars of life and everything. Heather Graham also has a small part as lover of Amis, and does her best with her. The most surprising thing about this movie is what the movie is not. There are no nice scenes of "Yentl", where Amis falls in love with a man like a man. The war of the cattle company, a standard point of the western plot, never overwhelms history, or reaches a trivial conclusion. The final scenes, with the unmasking of Jo, seem almost a farce, but when you think about them later, they play with great sincerity and movingly, especially Hopkins\' reaction. Greenwald\'s camera turns a small movie into an epic, with a splendid scene from Montana. His script is also very smart, he\'s never going for the cheap laughs or the kind of exploitation a director might have done. I recommend `` Little Jo\'s ballad. `` Has a grade (R) for physical violence, strong armed violence, sexual violence, spilled blood, some blasphemy, female nudity, sexual content, sexual references, drug abuse and adult situations.'

b"I bought this DVD without having seen it in the theater or in a video. I bought it based on the good reviews I saw in the best ten end of the year lists. This is one of the few (unique) animated works that does not double as a musical. It is based solely on the strength of its characters to tell the compelling story of the young `` Hogarth '' (yes, Hogarth!) Who befriends a giant robot that landed forcefully on Earth during the 1950s. Naturally, the military and other adults suspect the seemingly benign giant. The true strength of this film is that both adults and children will enjoy it because it works on several levels. It's a sneaky comment about the paranoia of the 1950s (without being clumsy), an exciting adventure film and a comedy that has humor for adults and children. Both will fall in love with the `` Iron Giant '' (voice of Vin Diesal, from `` Saving Private Ryan '') that will finally teach humans a thing or two about loyalty and sacrifice. A word of warning for those with very young children: there are some `` cursed '' and `` hells '' (3 or 4) throughout the film; therefore, your PG rating."

b'Without a doubt the best Carmen I\'ve seen, apart from the Sunday film (I have not seen the performance of van Otter). The highlights are, of course, the performances of the soprano directed by Domashenko and Dashuk; both finish their roles correctly, even if the first one is not very subtle, but somehow I do not think Carmen was a lady of nuances. One simply has to emphasize its beauty: they are really impressive to see. I saw a Turandot a few nights ago (another production of Zeffirelli) that was ruined as a show because the princess was played by a lady who was the size of a hospitality tent (and was not a great singer either). Strangely, in this production, the protagonists are those who raise an eyebrow; they are middle-aged, overweight and visually unconvincing, and this diminishes credibility, given Zeffirelli\'s emphasis on the "look" of a production; It is difficult to see how Jos\xc3\xa9 and Escamillo could, in modern language, "attract" women in that way! OK, maybe the fame of the latter is a factor. As for the singing, the sopranos excelled, Berti was fine, Acelo medio, and one or two of the support singers rather doubtful. The director and the orchestra were good. As another critic remarked, it is not difficult to believe that all the families of Verona were represented on the massive stage, besides many tourists. There were more horses on stage than running in the Grand National, and I think I saw my dog, who had gone for a walk, in one of the scenes. Without elephants And yes, the constant search of male singers for the driver\'s track was annoying, but with so many people on stage, it\'s a shame they did not have to jump in the air to get the beat. But these are cavilos. I really enjoyed the presentation, more as a show than as a great opera. I think my dog \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bdid it too when he returned very late.'

b"It was the franchise fight that fans thought would never happen, except in the form of comics. After years and years of failed attempts and false starts, the powers finally succeeded. Hoping to capitalize on the amazing success of the merger of two successful horror franchises with Freddy vs. Jaso, two of the most popular science fiction creatures face each other face to face in Alien vs. Predator with those annoying humans trapped in the middle. There is not a clich\xc3\xa9 and eacute; that this movie does not like Disposable characters are widely sketched. For example, a bottle cap worn around the neck of a character is considered a defining feature. The film even manages to include that old chestnut tree where the characters overcome a fireball explosion. Fans who expect the two alien races to start hitting would have to wait almost an hour until their first battle, but it's pretty impressive as they throw each other out like something out of a comic book. It is true that the fight scenes are great in all their glory assisted by CGI, but this is not an endorsement. Poor Lance Henriksen is swaggering him here as a selfish entrepreneur who provides the only human link to the other Alien films (insinuating that he is the inspiration for the Android bishop in Aliens). It's only in about a quarter of the movie before it's dispatched quickly. There is an audio commentary by writer / director Paul W.S. Anderson and actors Lance Henriksen and Sanaa Lathan. They connect apparently as oblivious to the narrative disorder that is this movie. Also included is an audio commentary from visual effects supervisor John Bruno and creature effects designers Alec Gillis and Tom Woodruff Jr. Anyone who wants to hear these details will find this clue. There are three deleted scenes that total a total of two minutes and include a bit of Predator humor that was cut correctly. Also included are two advances and a gallery of the covers of the comics. to Dark Horse 's Alien vs. Predator series. Alien vs. Predator was not worth the wait and the fans of the comic will feel cheated. The movie begins slowly, but once the aliens and predators begin to hit each other, the weak script and the clumsy plot mercifully fade into the background. It's a shame because both alien races are ready for innumerable story ideas that subsequent sequels have not been able to capitalize effectively. All we have left is a good paint film by numbers."

b'Amazon offers this movie along with `` The Off Season \'\' in one package. LOSE THEM BOTH! This is really bad simply because it is not a really honest attempt to create a decent horror movie. This is as bad as those terrible "Brain Damage" movies.'

An intelligent film that is not based on rude humor to involve the audience.'

b"`` Battlefield Earth '' is considered one of the WORST movies ever made. It makes `` Hands, Hands of Fate '' look like a profound, human and moving drama about suffering in the hands of a cult and `` Plan 9 from outer space '' seems like a profound meditation on world peace and the dangers of science `` Battlefield '' has holes in plots bigger than Swiss cheese, and to think that it was a labor of love (!!!) John Travolta saw this film as a tribute to L. Ron Hubbard. But it ended a catastrophic failure. And no wonder. `` Battlefield '' has human beings living in primitive conditions, at the mercy of the dreadlocked psychics led by John Travolta and Forest Whitaker. Human civilization lies in ruins. The special effects, sometimes, especially with the ruins, are convincing. Pity about the rest of the movie. Barry Pepper (who seems to have retired, or something like that) stars as the hero, '' Jonny Goodboy. '' Not inventing that. Being a prisoner of the Psychlos, he manages to learn to read, fly planes, fire guns, all in a remarkably short period of time. As for the psychos, what was their motivation in world domination? Gold ! And yet, they were not able to find Fort Knox after blowing it all to pieces. Silent premise, horrible acting, a horrible makeup scene between Travolta and his real life wife, Kelly Preston ... it's better not to see her. This movie makes you suffer Moment for Moment, and Travolta wondered if his career was Living Live. At least, her taste for camp movies has not changed, as she acted as the mother of Tracy Turnblatt in Hairspray (Full Screen Edition). The love of bad movies is a battlefield."

b"The third installment of the popular & quot; Beverly Hills Cop & quot; series is like a distant relative who comes to stay with you. At first, you are happy to see them and catch up with the old days, but they will surely exhaust your welcome quickly. This movie reaches that point after about fifteen minutes. Eddie returns as Alex Foley, the increasingly unlikely fish detective out of the water in Detroit. Once again, Axel is battling with the police establishment, the Beverly Hills Police Department and the bad guys who killed his friend. Sounds familiar ? Even Serge (Bronson Pinchot) is back, in a desperate and painful scene that seems to last forever. The direction of veteran Murphy driver John Landis is acceptable, and shows Landis's usual style for rhythm and acrobatics. However, the script of the generally decent Steven deSouza is woefully half cooked. It is never clear what the tone of the image is supposed to be. The action scenes are very impromptu and are often played to laugh, while the comedy scenes are forced and without grace. History never builds the sense of danger and conflict that is essential for a film of this kind. It is not a riot of laughter, not remotely full of suspense. Also, any movie that makes Hector Elizondo (one of the best character actors) look bad has serious problems. There are two good things about & quot; Cop III. & quot; One of them is an excellent action sequence set in an amusement park on the Ferris wheel. That is the only exciting part of the movie. The other thing that I liked was the series of cameos from a variety of famous film directors (like George Lucas), a typical Landis gag. At least it gives you something to look for in some pretty boring scenes."

b"Great Milestones is an exploration of the breeding habits and mating rituals of various types of animals. Interesting aspects of this topic are how the Moon and the tides regulate and synchronize certain elements of reproduction and how climatic conditions also play a role. Not only are terrestrial animals studied, but some types of underwater creatures are also shown. In the second half of this documentary, parents are touched to protect and feed their newborns. Finish is a look at the young animals that leave the house or nest in the struggle to join the circle of life. With only 60 minutes in duration, this feature can make you want more. The sound, the narration and the video are pretty well done in my opinion. Bonus features are not offered except for a couple of trailers from other programs. The chapters are a bit short due to the time limit, but what is presented is entertaining and enjoyable, nonetheless. As diverse as the animal kingdom is, here we hope that Reader's Digest will make more of this type of documentary. If you are a fan of this type of topics, it is advisable to see them."

b"This series is very reminiscent of series like Trigun, Full Metal Panic and Outlaw Star, nothing serious, but entertaining, dramatic and funny enough to be very addictive. The first thing to keep in mind is that you do not take most of this series seriously, although if you are looking for a hardcore drama series like Ghost In The Shell, Akira or similar, this series will not be for you, while it has battles of wicks Space and some drama for most of the series, it is mostly happy for the first season. The beginning of the second stage of Vandread becomes a little more dramatic and serious, although especially with the argument of what the people of the Earth have done to the human colonies in space for their own agenda. The main plot of the series is that after more or less a century that the male / female genres separated and lived in different worlds, for some reason they began to fight each other for resources and personal agendas. The stories from both sides about what the other genres are like also make the series very funny, like when you hear the story in the male homeworld about how demonic women are and how they will eat your organs and they are just horrible. Thus begins the uncomfortable journey of three males trapped in a boat of a crowd of attractive females after a battle between the genders becomes chaotic and causes a fusion of the male and female spacecraft. The cast has a great variety of comical situations that make you laugh throughout the show and the characters are hilarious, as you see, when they try to interact between the genres at times. The real cute couple of the series for me was Hibiki Tokai, a third-grade citizen in his world who was basically a humble worker when he was caught on board the ship because he boasted of being able to bring a vanguard, and Dita Liebely a bubbly pilot woman of the ship that wants to contact its first alien and since it has never seen a man before seeing Hibiki as the first alien with whom he has contacted. The video is clear and clear, so there were no complaints and the audio was also good, the cast for both the Japanese / English was also good. Again, as in the recent releases of Funimation, the set consists of four DVDs placed in two thin-film DVD cases and in a paper sleeve, the extras are not just the standard intro / endless songs and some trailers, but the price is still not bad . So if you like sci-fi anime and funny action drama, here's a good one to look at anime collection ..."

b'The good news about this DVD is that it focuses more on Big Brother as a band, instead of focusing exclusively on Janis Joplin, like other documentaries. Unfortunately, the sound quality is generally very poor, and the images are often deleted. This is especially noteworthy because many of the same images have been used in other films such as JANIS, MONTEREY POP, BIG BROTHER: BALL AND CHAIN, and several television specials (A & E, Biography, VH1, etc.), so the comparisons also easy to make. I have reissues of 78 rpm vinyl records on CDs that have been digitally restored to offer a clearer sound than this DVD, and I have seen images of silent movies restored in a similar way, so I can only assume that this documentary was hurriedly thrown the sight put on the quick money and not much concern for the quality of the production. That said, the DVD offers a fascinating look to the band members at that time. Some look back on the Psychedelic Era with nostalgic affection, while others have obviously clung to and tested their grudges for the past 40 years. If they had never met Janis Joplin, the Big Brother story could have been very different: if no one had heard of them, or if they had triumphed on their own terms of blues and raw edges, I would never know. But this DVD offers tantalizing glimpses not only of what it was, but of what might have been.'

b"I bought this DVD as a media filler for my husband. We saw it together in preparation for an upcoming trip to Amsterdam. The film, which tells the life and struggles of the Dutch painter Vincent Van Gogh, was very well made and was one of the best performances of Kirk Douglas. Sometimes it was worrisome because of a harrowing description of Van Gogh's serious mental illness. Other strong performances by Anthony Quinn, who played the painter Paul Gauguin, and James Donald, who played Van Gogh's brother, contributed to the enjoyment of the film. The film was visually stunning and one could see the evolution of Van Gogh's art. I look forward to my trip to see the art of Van Gogh in person."

b'Flash Gordon is as entertaining and entertaining as it was half a century ago, but the people who assembled this package were lazy. There are a dozen or more individual episodes of Flash Gordon on each disc, but there are no "breaks" between them. If you watch three one night and want to continue where you left off the next day, you must restart the disk. There is no way to go directly to the next episode. You have to repeat the episodes that preceded it. This is simply vague or depressing on the part of the people who put the package together. They do not deserve your business.'

b'Hellboy 2 continues the story of Hellboy and his work with a paranormal agency. He is still surrounded by friends and a new leader who reminds me of the Doctor Who Morbius Brain. What happens during the film is a battle of the Earth between Humans and Elves / Goblins / Ogres / Trolls, and the Humans are almost annihilated by the Golden Elf Army of giant robots. But in a moment of compassion, the Elf King decides not to kill the remaining Humans and asks for a truce so that humans can build their cities, but leave the forests to the Elves and Trolls. Years pass and humans have forgotten the truce and have taken over much of the land of Elves and Trolls. The prince of the elves has decided that his father is weak to do something about the humans and decides that it is time to wake up the army of gold again. Packed with tons of action and a negative twist on what it is like to be different, Hellboy 2 delivers the products. Also included are the following special features: 6 deleted scenes, Troll Market Tour, comments, scheduled visits and an animated comic epilogue.'

b"The werewolves of Hollywood have long been characterized as serious creatures who pursue their victims as a shaggy Groucho Marx. The image of this loping wolf was originally recorded by Lon Chaney and the following generations of actors simply continued their style. But with AN AMERICAN WEREWOLF IN LONDON, director John Landis not only pushed the werewolf on all fours to resemble nothing less than a stray lycan tank, but also added a touch of much-needed humor to compel spectators to stay momentarily separated from the gore to contemplate what they had just seen. David Naughton and Griffin Dunne are two Americans who travel with their knapsacks through a gloomy English wasteland just outside of Wuthherful Heights. They are attacked by a howling werewolf who kills Dunne but simply bites Naughton before the villagers shoot him. This introductory scene in which Naughton and Dunne are banished by an unfriendly group of pub drinkers is a disturbing mix of scary fears leavened with sharp wit. It is precisely this combination of horror and humor that suggests that the viewer engages in extreme emotions ranging from laughter to suffocation, and the viewer is sometimes not sure which one to choose. Jenny Agutter is a very unappreciated actress who shines like a nurse who falls in love with Naughton, and can not understand a radical change in her eating habits, as she increasingly prefers her rare flesh. Agutter adds an unexpected dimension to a role that, in the hands of another less competent director, could have relegated her to being little more than a swig of visual candy in English. Griffin Dunne provides a visceral humor like a corpse that keeps appearing, like the ghost of Hamlet's father, at the opportune moments to remind Naughton that the price to pay for being free of liquorotropy may be a bit too high. And then there's the music, played on the same line as Simon & amp; The lyrics of Garfunkle from THE GRADUATE, but here Credence Clearwater Revival 's lilting & quot; Bad Moon Rising & quot; accentuates the revealing transformation scenes that a bad moon generates bad vibrations. Finally, Rick Baker's special effects are amazing because you can see lengthening bones, fur sprouts and nasal fins that stretch out while Naughton sees himself as scared as he is at the audience. Ultimately, AN AMERICAN WEREWOLF IN LONDON is an innovator in the werewolf genre in that vision and sound combine to present creatures as helpless in their own way as their own victims."

b'For its complete disrepute Amazon is publishing reviews of two totally different films as one! There are two versions of The Big Trail: a shot in 35 mm and duration of 110 minutes and launched in 2003, and a newer widescreen version released in 2008 with a duration of more than 122 minutes and filmed in Grandeur 70 mm and completely different in scale and impact. The important version, to add more confusion, comes with the first as a set of boxes. Potential buyers should be aware of this! The `` Full screen edition \'\' will confuse many buyers, in fact, it is nothing like that and therefore, I qualify it with the lowest rating. The film in its historical format deserves a total of FIVE STARS! and can be purchased on the set titled, "The Big Trail Two Disc Special Edition", which not only includes this lower version of the DVD, but also the very important and enormously historical "WIDESCREEN EDITION" version of the film, since it was shown for the first time. Again, I would easily rate this five-star panoramic editing DVD! The widescreen version lasts 122 minutes and is taken directly from the original 70 mm. The "Full Screen Edition" masked here as what it is not is not a cropped version of the panoramic image, but is actually a shorter 35mm version (110 minutes) of Fox at the same time for most of the Theaters of the day that the great movie could not run. Yes, it is a real movie and certainly a good one, until you see 70 mm. My low rating is to draw attention to all these important details that are not mentioned in most positive reviews. Most of what makes this film epic in scale is much better appreciated in widescreen format, and not in the completely confusing full screen edition offered here. I am usually tolerant of these concessions to the television medium: seeing a widescreen "Lawrence of Arabia" on anything smaller than a 60-inch screen is like looking at a colored ribbon stretched out in the middle of the television. So small, it\'s understandable why many people opt for cropped or "full" screen versions instead of widescreen versions, but the goal of "The Big Trail" is the magnificent GRANDEUR format, a monstrous 70mm image that offers dazzling details of the vast panoramas that make up the backgrounds of the film, these are amazing images, worthy of consideration with the great black and white landscape photography of the best American photographers in the West.If you have a large television screen, you only have to try `` The Big Trail \'\' in widescreen in the `` Special Edition of two discs \'\' of Fox. Once you have seen the movie In its uncut full glory on a good sized screen, you\'ll wonder why Fox released `` The Big Trail \'\' on the 2003 DVD in a `` Full Screen Edtion \'\' very changeable and misleading. So I ordered the widescreen version of `` The Big Trail \'\' and saw a milestone in American film production, something absolutely spectacular as it was intended to be seen. The Big Trail (Special Edition of two discs) My only complaint is Fox We insist on attaching the full-screen DVD to the widescreen DVD and we load two DVDs when most viewers just want to see a version.'

b'While the 2006 Le Mans DVD is similar to previous incarnations, the extremely poor video quality due to a large amount of distortion and pixilation, definitely makes this the worst of the Le Mans DVDs. In terms of content, it is the same: a lot of tests and classifications highlighted with a little more than one hour dedicated to the race itself. However, the poor image quality makes this DVD look almost like a VHS tape. The distortion and pixilation, at times, is horrible and really moves away from the pleasure of watching the race. If you compare this DVD side by side with the Le Mans DVDs covering the 2002 and 2003 races, the 2006 edition is definitely worse. Another complaint is that the DVD covers the tests and highlights of qualifying twice, which adds a lot of repetition to the DVD. "S running time of 140 minutes.This has been a continuing habit for the producers of this series, which They crowded into this featured show that originally aired on the SPEED channel before their live race coverage at Le Mans.This preview show, which takes a little over an hour to cover the tests and qualification, leads to true The beginning of the DVD, which then includes more tests and qualifying highlights The lack of special features and cameras in the car is another disappointment In the 2005 DVD, producers included cameras with special features for the car for the first time ( even though the DVD had some slight problems of pixilation.) In the 2006 version, there are no special features and the footage of the camera in the car vil is not more than a couple of seconds for each car that shows. It would have been great if there was a complete lap in the car on board the Audi R10 Turbo Diesel. Overall, I would still recommend this DVD to any Le Mans fan as it is the best record of a race in which Audi triumphed with a diesel-powered car for the first time in the 74-year history of the race. He also does a good job showing all the action of the race and all the drama and glamor that make up the annual festival of endurance at the Circuit de la Sarthe. It is disappointing that the quality of the image is so poor.'

b'Finally I gave all the hype and really went to see Minority Report. The question that remains for me now that I have seen it is: what was all the exaggeration about? Although I must admit that some of the special effects generated by computer were impressive, the performance lacked any type of substance. However, what bothered me most was the incredible amount of products placed throughout the film. Was not Mr. Spielberg sure if he would earn enough money at the box office to advertise Aquafina, Pepsi, Gap, Lexus and Nokia throughout the film? In general, I spent two and a half hours in the movie during which I asked myself more than once if all the people who walked through the cinema during the screening of the film, were they as bored as I was? The bottom line is, good free special effects and some interesting scenes like the chase at the car factory, other than I can watch commercials on my TV at home for free.'

b'It\'s my fault that I had higher expectations of this movie, but I guess this movie was not made exactly for guys like me anyway. The acting is fine, the character of Matthew McConaughey Ben and Kate Hudson\'s Andie really just have to act and react. The dialogue does not matter. The character of Kate Hudson always has the top, which is fine for a while, but after an hour it becomes exhausting. She completely invades every aspect of Ben\'s life; We never see Andie\'s world, apart from her two friends and place of work. So, while both characters have a similar agenda, there is a complete imbalance of superiority, and this is the biggest deficiency of the movie for me. He endures all his attempts to "lose" him, but all this only produces frustration in Andie and drives her to do more crazy things. As a spectator, you\'re dying to see her fall on her face only once. But that is an illusion. Ben\'s resistance to Andie\'s antics barely entertains me, and Andie\'s total lack of shame does not make her his. Of course both look great, and Hudson smiles positively when he smiles, but man, 112 minutes is a long time to endure this game. I can imagine some people thinking that this movie is great. Girl Power and everything. I do not know . But I think we can agree that the film was conceived as a vehicle for Kate Hudson\'s rise to stardom. This film reminds me a bit of WHAT WOMEN WANT (with Mel Gibson) for a variety of reasons, especially because it was written and produced by women, that in the film world dominated by men is a much needed perspective, but Nancy Myers (the producer / director of What Women Want) is definitely much smarter than the \'brains\' behind How to lose a man in 10 days. You just have to look at the DVD extras to see evidence of this. We met two of the producers, who obviously had facelifts. I\'m serious . It is creepy . They talk about the material as if it were Shakespeare. Then there is the director Donald Petrie, who completely lacks charisma. DOING WITH HIM is so cheap that it\'s probably more fun to watch than most of the movie. While he sits there chatting, a television monitor behind him shoots still images of the film, and an office worker (with her back to the camera) stares at a static PC screen biting her nails and shaking her head. She does this for the duration of the interviews with Petrie. Oh, and did I mention the background music that accompanies the extras? It\'s music from the department store. Or elevator music. Anyone who hate more. I did not bother with the comment. Donald is boring. There are no discarded songs, which is unusual for a comedy. The deleted scenes are really good, Andie shows some honest emotions and we have some quieter private moments between the two protagonists. Look, it started well. It felt like a spongy and harmless romantic comedy, but the romance lasted about 10 minutes. I can summarize my criticism with this observation of director Petrie\'s reason why he was interested in directing the film. He says it was because he discovered that Kate Hudson was attached to that. Aha. So, basically, if the movie works well at the box office, then it will launch And its career in Hudson. I\'m sorry, Petrie, but that\'s not good enough for me.'

b'`` Ring Around the Rosie \'\', starring Gina Philips (`` Jeepers Creepers \'\') and Tom Sizemore (`` Saving Private Ryan \'\'). I was interested in their names, but unfortunately the film is terribly boring, although it lasts less than 90 minutes.Gina Philips plays Karen, a young business woman who inherits a house in a remote place in the countryside, which may or may not be haunted Near the house lives a caretaker played by Tom Sizemore, who may or may not be possessed by something evil. The premise is very familiar, recently used in films like "The Amityville Horror", and with the correct direction of the film would be exciting. But soon you will realize that there are no emotions of any kind, not even a surprise for a sudden great sound, in `` Ring Around the Rosie \'\' that presents many recycled fragments of images seen in other thrillers: from rudimentary tricks like shadows moving behind the door, a strange reflection in the mirror, a strange noise at midnight or an unreliable neighbor looking at the protagonist, the heroine tormented by nightmares and her buried memories of the past. The film also features Karen\'s friendly boyfriend (Randall Batinkoff) and her lovely younger sister (Jenny Mollen). The first leaves the house while Karen stays to clean the house; the last one arrives there and what Karen sees and listens begins to become strange. Considering the nature of the conclusion and the suggested history of Karen\'s childhood (which I can not reveal here), there could be some psychological explanations about the strange events that terrify Karen, as in thrillers like \'The Others\'. "That\'s what I thought about trying not to sleep, but no matter how I try, I can not find one in this disconnected story that is confusing and illogical, if you see a character fall from the window and another character grabs her in his arms As if it were a caricature, you realize that this is not a very good psychological thriller, or maybe I\'m thinking too much, probably this is another badly written horror movie you can find in your rental video store, borrow it and I\'ll regret it later, whatever it is, I was bored, and I can say that with great confidence.'

b"The title comes from the idea that serial killers hold graduate degrees in murder, although I thought that the commission of mutual acts would throw them into a post-graduate territory. The 4 assassins mentioned here (Charles Manson, Henry Lee Lucas, Ottis Elwood Toole and Kenneth Bianchi) receive disproportionate coverage. Manson is not seen at all, which can be a blessing considering the crazed interview I've seen him give. Henry Lee Lucas has a short turn, too, but his teammate Ottis Toole has perhaps the most problematic situation. Although convicted and imprisoned for what is said to be 700 incredible murders, with Lucas, Toole gives the impression that he did not do any of them. That does not mean that it is totally crime-free, since it freely admits several acts of arson, but affirms that it confessed the murders based on the information that the police gave, that is to say, that it wanted that it was guilty, reason why it forced them. The study by Kenneth Bianchi, known as the Hillside Strangler, also refers to this behavior that the psychiatrist Martin T Orne defines as sociopathy from the textbook. But while it is easy to believe that Bianchi in his interviews pretends, it is more difficult to accept that Toole is, with his playful character and smiling facade. Maybe that only makes Toole the best actor, since Orne also believes that Toole is a serial killer. Bianchi's initial defense for his murders was a multiple personality disorder, and when Dr. Orne proved he was a phony, denying the testimony of other psychiatrists, Binachi abandoned the farce and was found guilty, although the negotiation of the accusations against his accomplice decreased the number from 14 vicitims to 7. This video was made in 1987 and it is said that Bianchi would be granted parole in the 90's, something that Dr. Orne believes he had a good chance of obtaining, since Bianchi's tactic of not repenting - no memory was winning him alliances. However, while Toole's face reveals an idiotic child entertained with his own game, Bianchi's is the banality of evil, a soft surface on which he can not be trusted. The video concludes with survivors of serial killers, including the mother of Sharon Tate, who meets regularly to supervise probation hearings of convicted murderers. One can only wonder if they could influence the release of Bianchi, since Orne predicts that once this form of obsessive / compulsive behavior is acted on, there is no way to stop it. In Dr. Orne's opinion, no matter how good a prisoner Bianchi was, once he was free, he would start again. Some may feel sorry that these men escaped the death penalty while in states where it was abolished, and the idea that life imprisonment is a worse form of punishment than execution is diluted by conditional release and good conduct conditions. service. This may sound harsh, but Dr. Orne says that there is no civilized method of punishment effective enough to be a decisive factor: the best thing to do is keep the perpetrators isolated from the rest of society. There are no parallels between the murderers seen here, there are no similarities that can explain what triggered their actions. If we can not understand his behavior, we can at least be grateful that he has been detained, at least for a while."

There are no extras in that ... but this is the only one.'

b"The only bad thing with this image is the title. Adapted from the novel by Thomas Harris `` Red Dragon '', the decision was made to change the title. Probably thinking that most American moviegoers would think it's a Kung Fu movie or something. Probably correct. This also predates the most acclaimed sequel `` The Silence of the Lambs '' by the same author. It's another great Michael Mann movie that oozes style and substance. The style can annoy some people. It is filmed with various unnatural tones, including violet, blue and green. While they may not be realistic, they always seem to fit the scene. Mann and his photographer place cameras in interesting places. Take, for example, the raw white cell of Hannibal Lector (Brian Cox). We see Lector and Will Graham (William Petersen) centered between the same 2 bars, with fast cuts back and forth. Another camera looms over the room. However, this movie is not really about Dr. Lector. It is a serial killer known as The Tooth Fairy (Thomas Noonan, really creepy). While Petersen struggles with his own sanity, he resorts to the killer using his ability to get into the murderer's head. He stole this theme for his television series `` Miami Vice '' about this same time. Another great tactic for which Mann is known is the use of music. Here we get an original score from The Reds and Michel Rubini, not to mention the incredibly cool climate scene with Iron Butterfly's In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida."

b"Once in a blue moon, comes a delight from the public that elevates the spirit. `` Strictly Ballroom '' is one of those movies. Directed in a delicious high-key style by Baz Luhrmann (WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE 'S ROMEO + JULIET, MOULIN ROUGE) in his crazy debut (the first in what would be called the red curtain Trilogy), the film tells the story of a dancer from upper room that is paired with an ugly duckling, left leg, when his nonconformist style wins him the disdain of colleagues more conventional mentality. Together, they give their all and aspire to realize the dream of the title of the National Championship. To say that this movie is incredible would be to fall short. It is one of the most gloriously entertaining and impressive films ever made. The cast is simply magnificent and Luhrmann presents here his style of direction and intelligent and fast editing. He brilliantly uses an opening of documentary style and occasional interludes that help to better understand the adorable characters. It works beautifully! This is definitely the feel-good movie of the decade. It is hypnotic, strange and deeply sincere, a deliciously entertaining multitude delight. A highly recommended!"

b"I love the first two films of Anne of Green Gables. I saw them for the first time on PBS and the original VHS tapes were released by Disney. Sullivan's first DVD releases were of very poor visual and audio quality. This new and expensive set brings together the four films, all in a 16x9 widescreen. I do not like the other two movies, so I'll just comment on the first two. These were originally filmed in 4x3 format, with the television in mind (I read that they may have played theatrically abroad). I'm not an expert, but these new widescreen formats are cut. Then, information is lost with these new transfers. That's too bad? Yes, because I think that the original aspect ratios of these films should be 4x3 (or 1.33: 1), since they were originally issued. Worse still, the quality of the image seems to be so digitally erased that many details that were originally visible are no longer visible. The audio seems to be fine; the default is the original stereo mix 2.0. Interestingly, closed captioning seems to have been done by nitwits. For the first film, the first disc (fortunately, each movie has two discs) has pretty good subtitles. The second album has the subtitle IN ALL CAPITAL LETTERS, and is full of errors. Very poor quality! ! At this price, I would not recommend fans buy back these movies if they are already their property. However, as an FYI, I contacted Sullivan Entertainment and was told that they had no plans to release the films in blu-ray."
b'What a waste of money this was. They did not even have Justin singing a song to see if he wanted to buy his other DVD.'

b'A sequel to director "Alien" by Ridley Scott was inevitable, of course. This traditional horror film set in outer space simply made too much money for the studio to simply leave it alone. Surprisingly, when director James Cameron took over, he was determined to make a different movie instead of just repeating the first one. Therefore, `` Aliens \'\' was adventurous, taking the story in new and exciting directions as a story of action and adventure instead of another horror movie. In fact, several critics feel that `` Aliens \'\' is better than `` Alien. `` But now comes `` Alien 3 `` - as an unnecessary sequel to an important movie as we\'ve seen at some point. The first director David Fincher and four writers have created another horror movie, trying existential allusions to make the alien in this movie "Moby Dick" by Ripley. `` But `` Alien 3 `` starts by changing the end of its predecessor and eliminating almost all the characters that matter to us. Fans will remember that Ripley (Sigourney Weaver), Hicks, Newt and the Android Bishop escaped in a spaceship at the end of `` Aliens. "But this movie begins with his expulsion from the ship and his forced landing on a prison planet, which kills everyone except Ripley. On this planet of maximum security, where the lice infestation requires everyone to be bald, Ripley discovers that the only surviving monster is still with them. Soon, she is organizing the prisoners to be alert, but since there are no weapons of any kind on the entire planet, they end up playing hide and seek with the creature for most of the movie. There are many things about problems with this movie, but the worst is its dark and somber motif; the lack of friendly characters; the unpleasantness of the premise of the film, which causes Ripley to finally discover that she has an extraterrestrial queen growing inside her; and a long chase sequence that is so dark and edited so chaotically that it becomes confused. Those who are looking for emotions or some improvement in the first films will be very disappointed. Those who are looking for a headache will have arrived at the right place. And why is it "Alien 3 (that is, in cubes)" instead of just "Alien 3" or "Alienz" or "Alien: one of those slimy monsters survived after all"? It\'s probably just a trick for writers like me to consider the issue and give the film a little more ink. It worked .'

b'As many critics show, if you love this movie, you will really love it; if you detest him, you will detest him * really *. As I have seen twice, and I am ready to see it again, you can place me firmly in the first category. I have not been transported and moved by a movie since `` The Fountain \'\'. (which evoked similar love or hate responses in the viewers). It requires the voluntary suspension of simplistic cynicism, which I suspect may be a point of friction for some ... but if you are willing to open your mind and your heart even more, you will be amply rewarded. The plot is simple, as it should be: a thread woven through the life of several characters, which takes them through the main events of the 1960s. Wealth comes in the evocation of the times, in the innumerable little ones details spinning around the characters. And most importantly, when everything is said and done, this is a story of love, beautiful and movingly told. If you have ever felt the intense emotions expressed in these beautiful songs, then you will identify with Jude & Lucy, Sadie & JoJo, and all their friends. Not only romantic love, but the genuine love of others as brothers and sisters, all together in this confusing and stimulating world. So, are there uncomfortable moments or scenes too precious for contemporary tastes? Of course! But that really does not matter, because one of the characteristics of the 1960s was the willingness to take ridiculous risks, risk looking foolish, or even falling flat on your face. I\'m glad that Julie Taymor took similar risks here, because it helps capture the sensitivity of that moment, a sensitivity that led to great creativity and innovation. And it\'s not just for that moment. The questions of unnecessary war, of the demonization of the Other, of intolerance and fear of change, of distrusting the imagination, are they not as powerful today as they once were? But although the film is definitely on the side of the counterculture at its best, Julie Taymor does not hesitate to show how even the best idealist intentions can go to dark places, as happens with some protesters who go to bombs. A hymn of peace and love, he is also very familiar with pain and despair. In fact, the film ends with the anthem "All You Need Is Love", a song that some consider unreflective. Artifact of naive and antiquated flower power. But I remember something that George Harrison once said, when they asked him if love really * is * all he needs, he answered that even if it is not * everything * that he needs, if he does not have it, then, of what Does the rest serve? Yes, it is a bright cloud, illuminated by the sun, of golden nostalgia in a sense ... but it is also a reminder that there is more to life than fear and darkness, that there is hope even in the midst of madness and the chaos . And in that sense, it\'s a very contemporary film, with a vital message. Very highly, happily recommended!'

b'A story within a story on a cruise ship: the history of the surface is of a "seven-year itch". A formal and respectable British couple, without children, celebrating that volatile anniversary, is advised by an Indian sage (in relation to the husband anyway) that children are a better marriage therapy than a cruise to India. Lust seizes the seemingly conservative Briton perfectly interpreted by Hugh Grant and deceives him. Yes, this happens to men all the time. In this cruise, the British couple runs into the sensual French mermaid and her crippled and old husband narrator who captures her husband Brit to tell his autobiographical novel never cut. And as for the writer\'s inner history and his French obsession, he shows how "greed" for hedonistic fantasy can lead to a dark, sadistic or at least regrettable behavior. Suffice it to say that everyone learns this lesson in their own way in the end. A subtle theme here is the representation of the unsuccessful writer, who buys too much in fantasy and tries to make life imitate art until both his life and his art do not reach. any success (this, like lust in seven-year-old male itching) is another truism: failed artists often expose themselves too much to the realism that ultimately causes frustration and failure) as well as telling their story orally to a mere chump on a cruise who completely loses the point and is ready to take advantage of his perfectly respectable life for a brief and scandalous trist in the same way that he turned the cripple into an odious and abominable loser. Like the song of Homer\'s Siren (who was also crossing the Mediteranian, right?) Vangelis\'s great score too, capturing romance and tragedy in one theme.'

b"I would recommend this movie for adults and children alike. It has something of interest for all age groups. There are beautiful and impressive southwestern landscapes, as the story takes place in the desert of southwestern Arizona, in Navajo lands. There is also a story about two children who lost their goat and believe that they have strayed into a canyon known as & quot; Cougar Canyon & quot; a place that is supposed to be haunted, according to the Navajo legend. They must go and look for the goat, of course, and they are harassed by many dangerous mishaps before successfully fulfilling their mission. However, the true stars of this film, in addition to the beautiful landscape, are the excellent photography of the desert wildlife in their natural habitat. There is a battle between a badger and a puma, or wildcat, as it is more commonly known, with a surprise ending. The close-ups of a diamond rattlesnake are incredible, and the narration is excellent, too. This movie is reminiscent of the old Disney nature documentary series that used to appear on television years ago, in the 70s. I enjoyed it immensely, and I am a senior citizen, but I can see that it would also attract children, since they are generally fascinated with wild creatures such as rattlesnakes, wild cats, black bears, etc. In its natural environment It is actually very educational, especially for us the inhabitants of the city. I can not say enough good things about this movie, you'll just have to see it for yourself."

b"The critic who has it in these pages is the one who calls the fact that Jonathan Larson conceived 'Rent' as more opera (using 'La Boheme' as inspiration), not a musical. And what that means is that the connection dialogue is sung at the stage of the voice, it is not talked about as a dialogue. Then, to see Jesse L. Martin forced to speak a dialogue like `` I reconnected the ATM in the Food Emporium '' when you know it is killing him not to sing it and he is also killing all the Rent fans when he listens to him restricted Simply speaking the words ... well, it's a major mistake because it hits the flow and energy of Larson's work great blows. Other concerns: * The first half of the work is redesigned largely rolled-by-shot. Then, strangely (given the fidelity in the first half), the second half deviates violently from the original. The director Columbus loses too much time organizing `` Take me or leave me '' in an unintentional way. Fun, no doubt, but the additional 5 to 10 minutes you have crossed out here could have been used to keep the scenes deleted intact. * The deleted scenes are not trivial issues: 'Rent' is a difficult story to follow for the unitiated. Each of those scenes could have helped explain the story. * Surely one of the reasons to support `` Take me or leave me '' was to get more Idina Menzel there. [Menzel (the original Elephaba in `` Wicked '' and the original Maureen here) has risen to Broadway royalty, so who can blame Columbus? ] But, if so, why leave aside 'Happy New Year? 'who has a fair amount of Maureen? * The deleted scenes end up dismissing the Anthony Rapp brand, which is unfortunate because he is the voice and the guiding thread of the work. Leaving his' 3D IMAX from my mind ... that is poetic ... that 'pathetic' number is an important omission, both for Rapp as an actor and for anyone trying to follow the movie: this is the key piece that puts things in perspective for the viewer in time. Why would Larson strive to put lines in Rapp's monologue as `` Christmas ... last year's Christmas Eve '' He is framing the scenes for us. This would be a three star review, but I will go for four because of the redeeming nature of the beautiful documentary about the Larson family: it is very powerful. It is obvious that the family is still suffering deeply 10 years after its loss."

b'As a child of the 70s, Schoolhouse Rock was a tradition of both Saturdays and pajamas, cartoons and cereals. Now, as a fourth grade teacher, I have rediscovered the value of these timeless cartoons. What was once simple entertainment coined between The Wonder League and several other ABC cartoons is now a valuable educational tool. Each year, my students learn and memorize the Preamble of the Constitution thanks to Schoolhouse Rock. And how interesting would the American Revolution be without No more kings, fireworks or the shot heard around the world? From the perspective of a fourth student, NOT VERY! This DVD is essential for students, teachers and parents. This fun and entertaining quick review of these necessary skills is an excellent way to learn with your children / students. After all, how else could we know that the purpose of a conjunction is "connect words, phrases and clauses"?'

b'This is a horror movie from the 70s based on the successful book of the "true" story of a haunted house on Long Island. It was unmasked and proved to be a total farce, but the film resulted in a dozen sequels and even needed that the Lutz remake.The family buys their dream home only to find that it is frequented, and also kindly contains the passage to hell in the basement Yes, it is completely overwhelming to think that if that passage existed in something called Hell, it would be in Amityville, Long Island. b"I do not like this movie. It deserves 5 stars for its excellent performance, a terrifying and harrowing story based on true stories, shady sets and photographs, and an atmosphere of despair. A German journalist, Nina Hoss, like the unwanted, dark-eyed, siren beaten, stays behind in Berlin to document the invasion of the Russians (Soviets). Soon, she is trapped in the rape and destruction of the city, and is defenseless civilians. After repeated attacks on herself, in desperation, she looks for a protector and finds a mysterious Russian officer (Evgeny Sidikhin) with a tormented past. Interested in it but reluctantly, he accepts, and what follows becomes a history of relationships and common ground in the midst of hell on earth. Without wishing to justify them, the writers, to a certain extent, show both sides of the conflict. The Russians, in general, long for their families, hate the war that dragged them there and tell horrible memories of the atrocities that the Germans committed in their homeland. Paying evil for evil does not compensate for your actions in any way, but I suppose it brings a kind of balance and understanding to the story. Fortunately, the assaults are shown in a non-free manner, and there is a nudity scene to make a point, but that's all for the graphic shooting. But one understands the message. The whole movie is depressing. I think the only hope that comes from the heroine's desire to survive, to maintain her sanity and a sense of decency, come what may. The written epilogue is almost as disturbing. The response of societies is to hide their past instead of dealing with it. A hard movie I will not see it again."

b"`` 28 Days Later '' is easily the best horror movie I've seen in a long time. What impressed me most was how smart he was; that is, the suspension of disbelief was very manageable. Once I get over the idea that a virus affects someone that way and spreads so quickly, the rest of the plot makes perfect sense to me. The few questions I had were easily found out about a beer with my friends. When I found out they were doing a sequel, I was very excited and in fact I dialed my calendar. The opening night, the first time I left work, I was there. Three hours later I was banging my head on a table and wondering if there was enough beer in the world to make sense of what I had just seen. `` 28 Weeks Later '' should become a case study in film schools about how to take all the good of an amazing movie and leave it aside for the continuation. As mentioned in other reviews, the gaps in the plot are huge and implacable. My `` favorites '' are: 1) the children simply leave the safe area and we even see soldiers in the watchtower who let them go, 2) no one is monitoring or watching the infected survivor (but not symptomatic), 3) her husband is foolish enough to kiss her, and 4) no matter how many blocks of the city the child is frailly braked, his dad `` Raged-Out '' appears quickly and focuses on attacking him and him alone. He was especially anxious to see the virus spread among the crowd, as was reported in the first film. Nop. When it hits the fan at the train station, what happens? The lights go out and they give us a lot of fast and stroboscopic shots. Gee, thanks. Unless you're epileptic, there's nothing scary about that. I give these two stars mainly because I could not give the `` Days '' seven. Well, let's call it one for the opening sequence and one for the end. If it were not for the promise of seeing France in the next episode, this film would have completely diverted me to any future `` 28 Anything ''."
