b'Based on a true story, CALENDAR GIRLS by Nigel Cole is a whimsical, moving, but sometimes trivial film. Trivial only in that there are many moments in which nothing of real importance happens, and the crisis points are predictably sentimental and exaggerated. But a lovely cast still manages to entertain. The idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bmore than 50 women to the natural is difficult to understand, but these women are so elegant and attractive, and the calendar is presented with such good taste that you can not stop catching when the calendar becomes an international success. Helen Mirren, long since won an Oscar, takes her role as Chris, the instigator of the calendar, to a wonderful fruit. Ciaran Hinds (Sum of all fears, Lara Croft Cradle of Life) is very good as her husband, who tells a sneaky journalist that causes a break in their marriage. Julie Walters (Oscar nominee for years Educating Rita) agrees with Mirren in his role as widow, whose death inspires the calendar. The other women, Annette Crosbie and Penelope Wilton especially, are all very successful in their performances. It is not a film that shakes the earth, but it is stimulating because it shows that beauty is not relegated to young people, perhaps young people at heart.'

b"Before watching The Girl Next Door, I expected it to be a typical obscene teen sex movie. After watching it, it has become one of my favorite movies, if not my favorite. It's a love story and a comedy in one. Emile Hirsch plays Matthew Kidman, a high school student who is an excellent student and a good boy, but he's a little nerdy and has not done anything memorable. throughout high school. This changes when she meets her new neighbor next door, Danielle, played by Elisha Cuthbert. Danielle is beautiful and Matthew instantly falls in love with her. Shortly after seeing her, he sees her undressing through his window and can not stop looking. Danielle catches him looking at her and gets angry at first, but soon it seems that she has also fallen in love with him. Danielle is a former porn star, whom Matthew does not discover until her friend Eli (played by Chris Marquette) shows her a video with her on it. To complicate things further, Danielle's former producer / ex-boyfriend, Kelly (played by Timothy Olyphant), appears one day and wants Danielle to return to the adult film business. At first, Kelly and Matthew get along, but this changes when Matthew tries to get Danielle out of the porn industry, something Kelly does not like. Eli and Kelly are two characters that really steal the show in this movie. Eli is the friendly nerd of Matthew's high school who is horny all the time and obsessed with sex and hot women. He had some of the funniest lines in the whole movie. Kelly (the pornography director who used to work with Danielle and also used to go out with her) is the great and wise girl who made me believe in almost every scene she was in. He could not decide whether to love or hate him: he is a great and fun boy when he and Matthew are friends, but when Matthew angers him, he becomes psychotic and violent. I do not want to give too much. in this movie, but Danielle makes Matthew do things he never imagined he would do. It really is a case of attraction of opposites: Matthew falls in love with Danielle's wild adventurous side, and Danielle falls in love with Matthew's innocence and purity. In several scenes, you can see in the background that Danielle is a good person, that she does not really want to be in the porn business, and that she really cares about Matthew. Matthew feels the same about Danielle and puts herself in many risky situations for her. This movie was so moving that I cried a couple of times and I do not cry easily. However, there were also such funny parts that I could not stop laughing (mainly the scenes with Eli and Kelly). Definitely worth looking at and not being well evaluated."

b'I do not understand why other countries have the 4 seasons available and the United States does not. This is a great show and should be available here. I have most of the shows recorded on TV, but I would love to have a box of this program.'

b'This is still one of my favorite shows to this day. I really enjoy watching the episodes again and again. This is the penultimate season and it is one of the best seasons. Obviously over the years, children are growing and maturing and that generates some interesting situations. In the episode Fast Friends, Steph goes out with children who smoke and make her feel pressured to do the same. I also like The Apartment, where Steve buys an apartment and DJ sleeps on the couch. Danny finds her (after arriving home late) and gets very angry. Full House is such a good show that I\'m sure today\'s young children would still like it, and "children" like me still like it because I grew up seeing that. There has never been a cooler (or cuter) guy than Uncle Jesse, and the love between the whole family is great and fun to watch. This is one of the best seasons and any fan should definitely have this in their collection.'

b"You would think that Hollywood would have no problem making a movie about Hollywood. Think again. It is true that there have been some excellent images in which Hollywood sees itself. The oldest one I can think of is 1937 's A Star is Born, which was remade like an even better movie in 1954. 1950 Sunset Boulevard is one of the best movies ever made, and a few years later Singin' came along. in the Rain, a classic musical. However, over the years, the industry has produced more bad films about itself than good ones. America's Sweethearts is somewhere in between. Its beginning is quite promising, but it wavers and goes downhill after that. Lee [Billy Crystal] is a Hollywood press agent with big problems. His boss, Dave [Stanley Tucci], needs him to promote the latest movement starring Gwen Harrison and Eddie Thomas [Catherine Zeta-Jones and John Cusack]. The couple used to be the most popular and popular married couple in the United States, and the public flocked to see their films. Now that they are about to divorce and can not stand the sight of others, they are cash poison. Lee must find a way to convince the press that Gwen and Eddie will be together again without letting the two stars realize what they are up to. He requests the help of Gwen's sister, Kiki [Julia Roberts], who is not only resented by the way Gwen orders her, but is also secretly in love with Eddie. Then there is the problem of the movie itself. All the study has seen is the opening credits. The director [Christopher Walken] does not want to show it until he has made some changes. These modifications will result in a film quite different from the one the studio paid $ 86 million to make. Reading the previous synopsis makes me see how funny and insightful the American Sweethearts could have been. The plot leaves ample space for farce and satire, but the writers did not take the opportunity. Instead of being brilliant, fragile and insightful, history is, on the other hand, pretty, cloying and docile. Most of the possibilities that Hollywood laughs at itself are useless. So is Julia Roberts. As much as I finally come to respect her, I do not think she's right in a simple Jane role. In addition, she has made the ugly duckling in a swan routine too many times before. The film is primarily a vanity project for Billy Crystal, who also produced it, and for director Joe Roth, who used it to launch his new company, Revolution Studios. They were probably afraid to bother the Hollywood establishment too much, of which they are a part. If your mind wanders while you watch a movie, it usually means that it is not grabbing you. There are several scenes in America's Sweethearts where a character says something and everyone in the room is speechless. I started thinking about this. In all my life, I never met anyone who said something that made all the listeners tremble, and I've met some pretty hot people. This is something that happens only in movies. Then, I began to list in my head other things that you only see on celluloid. Before I knew it, the movie was over."

b"The shelter generated a lot of controversy after its launch, and has generated a set of generally dizzy audience reactions. Many have responded with hatred towards the violent and unyielding nature of the film. My problem is not in violence. I can not connect with the first half of the movie, which deals mainly with the silly behavior of men while traveling backpacking through central Europe. All of that becomes a long wait to see what is expected in the second half, and it provides very little accumulation of what we will eventually have to endure. All the violence in the film is hard, personal and disturbing. It is not entertaining, but in a broader sense, quite interesting. It makes you wonder about the world, and what dark places can exist where anything or someone can be bought for the right price. This DVD contains some pretty good features, and overall a really good set of extras, including a featurette that is almost completely about the inspiration and reaction of the movie, and how much of it is based on reality. Eli Roth is undoubtedly an intelligent man, and he is willing to tell a message, not only of shock, but because of the rough and stark nature of the film, it is difficult to digest, and in general it is too uncomfortable to be really memorable . Maybe there's a bit of truth in Hostel."

b'TETSUJIN 28 is a Japanese live-action film based on manga series Mitsuteru Yokoyama, best known in the west for its 1963 animated black-and-white adaptation that aired on American television in 1966 under the title `` Gigantor \' \' "Here are some pretty spectacular scenes of two giant robots, Tetsujin 28 and Black Ox, that roam the streets of Tokyo and make a dent in their horizon, including a heartbreaking move where Black Ox leans back at the top of the Tower of Tokyo, there\'s even a lot in which Black Ox throws the disabled Tetsujin into the Diet building (Parliament), these sequences are quite exciting and well done, as if the cameras were on the scene and understood the action as it developed. , the two battles of later robots do not deliver the goods, the blows thrown are quite weak and there is not much movement in the fights, the robots never fly and they fight in the air, although, in the final encounter, both have that power. The original animated series had a giant robot action much more satisfying than we have here, even worse, the young man, Shotaro, who has been appointed to operate the Remote device that controls Tetsujin, he never seems to really want to do it. He is weak and scared for most of the movie. When he finally approaches the plate and accepts his role in the 90th minute, too long for us to have to wait, it is not particularly effective. While the child playing Shotaro can offer a realistic description of how a ten-year-old would react under the circumstances, I must confess that he was not exactly looking for realism. I wanted the boy to be completely in love and eager to control that powerful robot and send him into furious combat to end the depredations of Black Ox. Exactly how Shotaro (or `` Jimmy Sparks \'\' as he was known in `` Gigantor \'\') behaved in the original manga and anime. Or the heroes of the child in `` Johnny Sokko and his flying robot \'\' and the Gamera movies of the 60s. These new Japanese heroes are really weak when they are put to the test (see also Toru in GAMERA THE BRAVE and Tadashi in THE GREAT YOKAI WAR, two films also made in 2005, and both also reviewed in this site). What does this say about the next generation of Japanese heroes? At least Ash from `` Pok & eacute; mon \'\' still knows what to do in the face of a threat. However, I liked one aspect of the movie. I enjoyed watching two idols of Japanese pop music in the cast. The oldest is Hiroko Yakushimaru, who was popular in the 1980s and starred in a movie I remember called SAILOR SUIT AND MACHINE GUN (1981). She plays Shotaro\'s mother and is quite beautiful. The other is one of my favorite J-pop singers of all time, Yuko Nakazawa, one of the founding members of Morning Musume, who plays a young police detective assigned to the case. They give her her short dark hair and a simple blue navy suit, clearly an attempt to detract from her usual glamor, but she has a lot to do and it\'s always exciting to see her in action. Another key female character is Mami Tachibana (played by Yu Aoi), a robotics expert from MIT recruited to help restore Tetsujin 28 after a disastrous battle from the start. She is young and brave and looks good in uniform and beret while befriending young Shotaro. Akira Senju\'s score is pleasant and melodic and keeps things animated when the film slows down (which happens frequently). In fact, I also have the soundtrack CD. The final music becomes a repetition of the male choir singing the song `` Tetsujin 28 \'\' of 1963, accompanied by shots of the original manga, which is much more action-packed than anything in this film. The Pioneer / Geneon DVD does not offer credits in English anywhere, except what is in the DVD box.'

b"If you liked the first, this is up to your alley.I say that especially because of the tone (darker than many mainstream movies), the hidden nature and the unusual imagery have a tendency to put some moviegoers off. But if you just want to see a movie about a demon that was raised by humans to fight evil, this is a great movie for you. Guillermo del Toro's style of direction is very kinetic and fluid. This helps keep the pace of the movie, preventing it from appearing to be dragging. The scenes flow very well from one to the other (which is also done very well with some wipes and creative overlays). The real attraction of this film, however, is Hellboy and the team that was offered to him. Ron Perlman is the absolutely perfect Hellboy. His delivery of the lines is perfect to create a scathing, but ultimately adorable (and loving) character. He has an ironic humor about him that makes the Hellboy character something we can all identify with. We have all had moments when we feel less appreciated. We have all felt like the strange unwelcome. However, despite all the incentives that he has to give up on defending these human beings, he continues to do so because that is what his `` father '' taught him to do.Of course Abe and Liz are here too, and Doug Jones and Selma Blair do a wonderful job of portraying their respective characters. But this is not your movie. However, it is interesting to see that one of the elements of the story of the first film is turned around to portray the other side in this one when the team encounters the angel of death. In summary, as I said before, if you liked the first one, this is just your type of movie. I hope to see what Del Toro has in mind for the third movie. (Of course, we'll have to wait for `` The Hobbit '' to end first)."

b'Former government agent Edward Carnby (Christian Slater) must solve the mystery behind the events that happened when he was a child in order to save the planet from being destroyed by monsters from another dimension. Well, I\'ll admit, `` Alone in the Dark "It\'s not in my best movies of all time, but it\'s not in my worst movie list either." It can be directed by Uwe Boll, who is considered by many to be the worst director of all time, but if all of Boll\'s other films are like that, then Boll has been underestimated, because I\'ve seen many films that are much worse than this one ( for example, `` The Stepford Wives remake \'\'). The script is based on a video game, which gives `` video game \'\', moving from level to level, feel that you get with many movies of this type (like `` Resident Evil \'\' or `` Doom \'\'), but that did not discourage me so much as to want to go out and play the game. . Not being a player, this was my first encounter with `` Alone in the Dark \'\', and I found that the story was interesting enough to keep my interest in the length of the movie. The performance is unequal in quality. Christian Slater and Stephen Dorff (as another government agent) give decent shows, but Tara Reid is as unconvincing as she is a scientist who actually contributes to the entertainment value of the film. My main criticism is that some of the battle scenes are too long. There is a fight scene around the 1 hour mark that comprises about 15 minutes of people firing at monsters with very little dialogue, which became tedious after a while. Despite that, I still liked the movie and would be prepared to see it again.'

b'My son absolutely loves the book that sucks! , so when I saw this animated version available, I knew it would be right in its alley. The Schoolastic people have an excellent track record in the animation of classic children\'s books, and this is no exception. I Stink was animated in a way that perfectly complemented the book\'s illustrations, and Conan\'s partner, Andy Richter, does a fantastic job of giving the garbage truck a voice of "all attitudes, all the time." The animated version of I Stink is almost as shocking with my son as the book. The DVD also includes some other animated adaptations that (more or less) follow the theme of the garbage truck. Trashy Town is the only story with themes related to garbage on the DVD, but with its simple animation and its catchy "chorus", everything went very well. The others are unpredictable. Arnie the Donut was funny and a little disturbing (it\'s a sensitive cake aware of its imminent demise), but Monsieur Racine\'s Beast was a bit weird. I absolutely recommend the DVD I Stink to anyone whose son (s) enjoyed the book. It\'s a fun collection of animated stories, and a welcome break from Elmo, the Wiggles, etc.'

b'The problem is clearly related to certain DVD players that have trouble reading certain information on DVDs. You can point the finger at the DVD player, but the real question is why Disney released an album that is clearly problematic for so many players. Two different copies did not work on the four DVD players I tried (including my computer, so even that is not a universal solution). Disney needs to solve this problem and provide free exchange in some way. MGM had a similar problem with a James Bond album (Man with a Golden Gun) that only came to light in some players: they offered a free exchange by mail. Disappointing that Disney is not doing the same ...'

He moaned throughout the movie. Kristen Davis is better, but she can not save this mess. This movie makes John Denver look like a total fool and it was not. Save your money on this."

b'I am slowly becoming deaf at 44, so I am looking at many different means for self teaching. I was excited about this DVD, but when I started, I was horrified that there were no subtitles. I do not know enough sign language nor can I listen enough to get some of this. So, if you can not listen, do not bother getting this DVD!'

b"While for me `` Up, Down '' is still the best series of theater masterpieces of all time, this one is very close. Gemma Jones is excellent as Louisa Trotter, the cockney / hotel cook who never loses her sense of common sense nor her strong cockney accent even after becoming host to Richian and Famous of Edwardian England. The previous episodes focus on Louisa's rise from the assistant cook to the mistress of the Prince of Wales (later King Edward VII). But most of the series refers to acts at the Bentinck Hotel, an exclusive and private property in London owned and run by Louisa. With few exceptions, one's family must appear in Debrett 's Peerage for at least 100 years before one can reserve a room in the Bentinck. And yet, Louisa's selectivity is not so much a reflection of snobbery on her part as of her passionate commitment to be the best at whatever she does. The entire series is rich in characters and incidents, and in fact, Jones / Louisa is very much in the background in several of the episodes. But she is unquestionably the dominant and dominant character in this series. You have not seen outrage outright until you've seen Louisa, in the last episode of this collection, testify at the trial on behalf of her friend, Lord Haslemere, pouring diatribe after tirade in all her cockney glory. NOW THAT is a character! This wonderful series deserves to be much better known than it is. Do not hesitate to purchase this set. I can not wait for Series 2!"

b'How to ruin a perfectly wonderful movie? Make a poor quality DVD. The image is so blurred that most of the details are lost and the sound is so low that I had to turn up the volume to 99 only to hear it whisper. THIS DVD IS VERY BAD! Please, just register this gem the next time TCM comes and save your money. It is a pity that such a wonderful movie has been treated in such a poor way.'
b'I LOVED this show, but it is definitely not worth the DVD box set. They must release all the series!'

b'It could be said that this is the most fun movie of Vacation. Years later, the real test of a good comedy is howling about the movie, and `` Christmas Vacation \'\' is more than that for me. But this works the other way around: instead of the Griswolds, prone to disasters, traveling abroad to places like Europe or Wally World, they are anchored to the starting line since the calendar marks the Christmas days. Obviously, Chevy Chase is in its element to repeat this time his role as Clark, the well-meaning but hopelessly awkward matriarch, who naturally goes overboard creating "the perfect Christmas". The dependably good Beverly D\'Angelo is here as well as Clark\'s support wife to whom the annoying relatives, the whining children and their hurting wives press their buttons. The late John Hughes completes the script full of Christmas satires and references, punched with the brand `` Lampoon \'\' slapstick and lowbrow humor. Okay, sometimes the humorous tanks, but it is a nobler effort than the previous unequal "Holidays in Europe". This only challenges you not to laugh when the efforts of the Griswolds to have "the best Christmas" turn into a long train accident, which can tickle the funny bone of any "Scrooge". Look for familiar faces Juliette Lewis and Johnny Galecki (the latter currently in the hit sitcom `` The Big Bang Theory \'\') as the Griswold children; a pre-Seinfeld Julia Louise-Dreyfuss as half of the snobby yuppies neighbors who suffer at the hands of Clark; and Doris Roberts, Diane Ladd and William Hickey are some of the problematic family members who come to visit us. But in reality it is Randy Quaid\'s reprisal for the pathetic and mischievous cousin Henry Eddie who steals every scene in which he finds himself. If you want a serious version of a Holiday classic, look at `` It\'s a Wonderful Life \'\'; If you want to laugh hard and often, definitely look at this!'

b"I have been a FIRM Believer since the 80s, and while I understand that some of the previous comments on this tape are too easy, I recommend giving it a second chance. At first, because the choreography can be challenging, the training may not seem too intense. You're too busy trying to figure out what's next. But once you get down the stairs, you can maximize your effort and the training will be difficult. In addition, you can always gain weight (within reason) during dumbell exercises. This will also increase your heart rate. I am a FIRM veteran, and I look forward to this tape. : o)"

b"After reading the wonderful `` Doc '' book for the book club, my husband and I saw `` Tombstone '' a few days ago, and `` Wyatt Earp '' last night, in preparation for the next club's meeting week. For all those who say that there is some controversy over which film is better, I can end the controversy: `` Tombstone '' is better. Seeing `` Wyatt Earp '' was like watching a squeaky community theater (no offense to the community theater) of opening scenes with Wyatt (Kevin Costner, with his anachronistic hairdo and long hair) drinking a cup of steaming coffee like the cauldron of a witch, as if the stagehands put a piece of dry ice in the cup. With the exception of the excellent Gene Hackman as the father of Earp, the performance of the male protagonists is silly, or melodramatic, or wooden, or incredibly, all three at the same time. I just saw the strictly controlled and super-masculine interpretation of Kurt Russell by Wyatt Earp in `` Tombstone '', Kevin Costner's performance on the same character reminded me a bit of Forrest Gump, no offense to Forrest Gump, crossed with Costner The character of `` Dances With Wolves '' (the same hairstyle). I love Dennis Quaid, but after seeing the definitive portrayal of Doc Holliday's Val Kilmer in `` Tombstone '', just a few days before seeing Quaid's version in `` Wyatt Earp '' it was probably completely unfair to Dennis Quaid and his great sunglasses, which did not even come close to me. I LOVE the westerns, but this film mounted on a clich\xc3\xa9: a tight blow of the bottle just before a bullet explodes, anyone? - It made me roll my eyes. To sweeten the deal, it lasts more than three hours! Recommendation: Observe `` Tombstone '' instead."

b'Imagine a documentary with a disclaimer that allows the viewer to know that he will not hear ANY real U2 music during the movie. Imagine a documentary without any interviews of any importance, especially not of members of the band, but with interviews of exciting people like someone who knew the members of the band at school in Ireland or of some people who saw them play once. WOOHOO ! I think the only people who should watch this documentary are those who do not want U2. After hearing all the ridiculous pontification of these nobodys, I began to question my own loyalty to this band. But, fortunately, I remembered that it IS NOT AUTHORIZED and, at least in this case, it meant, not scathing and nervous, but corny and lacking in content. The discography was the only thing worth looking at.'

b'Pssst - hey, listen - have you seen BLOODRAYNE? Do not ? Then, quickly and silently, click with the mouse and exit this web page. If you have not seen this cinematic albatross yet, do yourself a favor and do not do it (it\'s already too late for me, but continue and save yourself, and - remember - do not look back!) I saw it, and now I completely hate it for my amazing lack of judgment, so much so that, today, I find myself guessing each of my decisions, all because of BLOODRAYNE. Obviously, this disease of mine can only be cured with an attempt to alleviate the turbulent world situation in some way; After thinking a bit and realizing that I do not have wealth, power, political prowess or a leading role in the Lara Croft films, my contribution should come in the form of this preventive review. Hoping to dissuade you from seeing this piece of disaster, my hope is that you do not turn partial against innocent Romanians or harbor an intense resentment against Sir Ben Kingsley (although it is okay to resent Michael Madsen). Trust me, it\'s not worth spending an hour and a half of your non-refundable time, time that could be better spent watching the SON OF THE MASK higher. Ewe Boll, as it turns out, stinks more than his vampires. Ewe Boll is directing what H.P. Lovecraft is a casual sketching comedy. Normally, this is the point where I would reveal something of the cinematic plot, but, no ... I do not want to do it. Suffice it to say that there are vampires who are not inventors, free sangria, uninspired and uninspired fighting scenes, f / x cheesy and lackluster performance, except that "lack of brightness" could be too complimentary an adjective; the descriptive apt to act here is `` f * cked up. "The two most credible actors present are Michelle Rodriguez (GIRLFIGHT) and Ben Kingsley (GANDHI), and, frankly, what the hell were you thinking? In addition, I am in favor of formal and forced dialogue when it warrants it, and I guess the configuration of the period takes place sometime in the eighteenth century (apparently, before the invention of contractions), but every word that reluctantly emanates from the lips of the actors unbearably horrible and delivered with the cinematic charisma of a victim of coma or a brother Baldwin Here\'s the thing: I do not like to give negative reviews I\'m a pretty positive person Normally, with the books I\'ve read and the movies I\'ve seen, if I do not like them, I do not bother writing about them. Why bother, when I can write brilliant backs for things I really enjoy? What this question asks: what kind of movie is so stinky that I really enjoy the trash? BLOODRAYNE seems, on the surface, a delicious caramel for the eyes, full of caramel goodness, but, in a real reading, tastes like caramel full of strychnine, two-month cabbage salad and finger jam. And that is BLOODRAYNE.'

b"Having played the two games `` BloodRayne '', I am a fan of the series. Then, when I heard that they were making a movie, I was somewhat interested. But deep down, I knew it would probably stink. It was more than good. Unless you are interested in a ghost that is so terrible that it makes you laugh, DO NOT BUY THIS MOVIE! It is a total disaster! Movie Rayne is nothing like his video game counterpart. The fight scenes were slow, nothing at all like the fluidity of the game. And do not make me start with spilled blood ... I've seen better settings in a haunted house. Nothing was done realistically, and the ten-minute summary at the end of the movie (which was done for some reason that I'll never understand) just shows how sloppy it is. The acting was not great either, and the brief sex scene ... let's say I found myself laughing at most of this mess. Unnecessarily, the plot was also missing (and that's very simple). If you want a vampire movie, pick up the `` Underworld '' movies. If you are a fan of `` BloodRayne '' looking for something to satisfy your fandom, play the game again. You will get more satisfaction than you would with this horrible interpretation."

b'The Italian Job is the best movie ever made, without a doubt. In general, I agree with Leonard Maltin, but sometimes it is off the scale and without doubt it is in this case. Well, you may feel that the characterization is poor, but they are meant to be stereotypes. This movie was ironic before Kevin Williamson and his class were born. It is worth knowing that the censors of the United Kingdom in 1968 did not allow the publication of any film that made it appear that crime pays, so the end was linked to that condition. If you only buy an Amazon video sometime (and that would not be good, they have a wide variety of good quality movies, could I recommend The Quiet Man, for example?) Do it here.'

b'For years, I have not bothered too much with the "movies", since I did not like the Hollywood clich\xc3\xa9 very much. But since I got a DVD player, I also found myself going to the movies. What a delight to see SNATCH. Brightly funny writing, superbly executed by the actors, realistic dialogue, credible characterizations. Fast movement, secondary weaves neatly interlaced, brilliant casting, ultimately excellent. I left the cinema having laughed at myself and, at the same time, I enjoyed a story that was simple to follow but complex in makeup. Guy Ritchie has done a great job in this, the cast was superbly chosen, including Brad Pitt, who, until now, has not been one of my favorites. Now I also bought the DVD, two discs, lots of extras, I\'ve seen it four times, I can not look again, my ribs will not tolerate the blows they take. I recommend this to everyone. To our American cousins, I think it was just launched recently, go and look at it now, you\'ll love it.'

b'In a few words: style on substance. There are some excellent sequences, but that is all that this film seems to be, well planned and executed sequences, but with nothing consistent sticking the whole set. The `plane near the accident and the last minute of rescue \'is performed extremely impressive and the machine gun ammunition that hits Supe\'s chest followed by the bullet in the eye is magnificent. My jaw was dropping and I almost wanted to cheer up. That\'s what Superman is about: watching him defeat the bad guys in new, attractive and even fun ways. But that\'s where the fun ended. As what Superman is not about is to love children and ridiculous heroic shots with kryptonite. I find that both are so terribly implausible that both should be ridiculed. As Brodie (skilfully played by Jason Lee in Kevin Smith\'s Mallrats) points out, "It\'s impossible! Lois Lane could never have Superman\'s baby." Do you think the fallopian tubes could handle your sperm? sexual intercourse, he probably unloads a load like a shotgun blast ... through his back. "So, other than Lois Lane being alive after intercourse, then it would be impossible for a human being to conceive and bring the child to term. of a foreigner. "Do not forget that just because Clark Kent looks and apparently acts like a human, he is an alien, he is a completely different species, and completely different species can not mate, just think of the havoc it would cause in the animal kingdom if a lion falls in love and mates with a crocodile or a guinea fowl The other issue that makes me tremble with anger is the cretin concept that Superman is physically capable of to rocket a whole continent of kryptonite towards outer space. As the internet blogger dpogue21 expresses it so skillfully (much better than me, so thank you, digegue) in his immediate criticism, `` My next big complaint [is] that Superman raises a continent made of kryptonite into outer space. You do not have to be a Simpson-type comic to point out what\'s wrong with that. I do not know how many comics Bryan Singer has read, but when Superman is exposed to even a small amount of kryptonite, he barely has the strength to stay on his feet. Whoever had the idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bblowing up a large island made out of its greatest weakness in space, has nothing to do with any project related to Superman. The concept is as ridiculous as making a Dracula movie where the title character has a stake in his heart and still manages to fly a spaceship made of garlic in the sun. Why does not it just cause Superman to eat kryptonite? He can eat it and then brush his teeth with it, and then go to sleep in kryptonite pajamas. That is no more absurd than taking it to a continent of kryptonite in space and then falling powerless through the atmosphere without burning in the reentry or splashing the entire central park when it falls to the ground. \'\' I need to say more? I do not think so. ** [...]'

b'Max Beesley has everything going. His and Mariah\'s chemistry was electric. I smiled, I laughed and I cried. The first time I saw it was "It\'s okay", but times 2-10 I still see something new every time. This has become one of my favorite movies. It all comes down to what was a romance, a success story, full of emotion. I recommend this movie as a sweet entertainment. You will feel the emotion throughout the entire movie. Give credit to the actors and do not blame them for a less than perfect script, they did the best with what they were given. Max Beesley is dynamic, throughout the film his eyes only tell the underlying story.'

b'Poor Bellini! It went out of style for a century and was rescued from the darkness by the genius of Maria Callas only to be shattered by this horror. What are we going to do with the absurd production of Zimmerman? Bellini in some kind of office loft of the big city, the characters, the action in total disagreement with the Romanesque bel canto, the opera reduced to the near farce. It could have been saved by a higher song, but even that is missing. It\'s almost as if the singers were asking themselves: `` What the hell is this nonsense and why are we here? "Every operatic performance should be a tribute to the composer, but in this case it is nothing more than a reverence to the director and his obvious need to be seen as bold, scandalous and inventive." One can only shudder at the thought of what he has in store for him. Future performance of the opera (if there is one) Can we wait for his Norma set in Detroit, a metaphor for the collapse of the downtown? I would not be surprised.'

b'Okay, so these guys had NO RETURN access to the most anticipated band meeting, well, sometime ... and this is it? This is all they do? Do not get me wrong, it\'s nice to see the boys playing again and see Kim get sober on the road, wander through the cities, etc. But the main problem with this document is that it is absolutely BORED. And they look for the key questions in the minds of all true fans: the reasons for the break and the possibility of new music. In fact, the best part of this movie (apart from the music) is the impromptu interviews of the fans that Kelly does. She starts asking questions! What a concept! This is a wasted opportunity. The filmmakers were inept or too impressed and "honored to be chosen" to make a film in any depth. We are left with a lazy and face-to-face love letter. Tipto film. Look, I love all the Pixies things. Period And on a certain level, this is nice to see just because I love this band. And if you\'re a big Pixies fan, you probably enjoy it to a certain extent. But, again, from the point of view of the MOVIE, and what this piece should have been, this is a gigantic disappointment.'

b"From the trailers and the presence of Julia Roberts in the cast, I entered CLOSER waiting for a light romantic comedy. (My preconceived ideas have not been so shattered since I saw Bambi's mother being shot by hunters in the Saturday marathon!) CLOSER opens when Alice (Natalie Portman), a New York stripper on a visit to London, she is stunned by a car after she has looked to the left instead of to the right walking off the sidewalk. She is taken to the hospital by a stranger, Dan (Jude Law), an aspiring writer with whom he begins a relationship of coexistence. Then, Dan sits down for a formal portrait of the photographer Anna (Julia Roberts), whom he hits unsuccessfully. Later, Larry (Clive Owen), a dermatologist, meets Anna, whom she marries, and then divorces after discovering that she had recent sexual relations with the once despised Dan. In the rebound and in need of physical comfort, Larry looks for Alice, who now strips naked in a London strip club after leaving Dan, whom he had previously met at one of Anna's photographic exhibitions. But Dan is still in love with Alice and is emotionally devastated from having sex with Larry. Is this dirty or what? (The timeline is dark, apparently all this happens in a couple of years.) CLOSE is a movie, painful to watch, sexual manipulation, possession and obsession in which the four main characters inflict emotional cruelties on each other. It's not a party to spend the evening at the movies with your old mom. The language is sexually graphic and, in a sequence of scenes on the London strip, visually obscene. CLOSER is, however, one of the best films of 2004. Julia Roberts is perhaps the biggest surprise, since it shows that she can transcend radically, even beyond ERIN BROCKOVICH (2000), her usual cute roles; I was very impressed. It would be difficult to choose the lead and the supporting parts of this movie. The four (Portman, Law, Roberts, Owen) have approximately the same screen time (although I was not following the stopwatch). Anyone, or all of them, could get an Oscar nomination. I started to doze about a quarter of the movie, but then I woke up almost with a start when I realized that CLOSER is an exceptional adult movie, without visually explicit. Sex or violence, which brutally shows adults in dysfunctional relationships behaving in the worst way. Truly, as indicated by a line in KINSEY: '' Sex is a dangerous game. If you're not careful, you can cut yourself wide. ''"

b'If you do not have a TV and a multi-system DVD player to use PAL, you can use a computer, a PC with a DVD program or a Mac to view the DVDs you get from Amazon UK. I do not know why, but the full 5 seasons are available in the UK, and I thought Ally McBeal was one of the most delicious television shows of recent years, and sad when it was canceled. After having traveled extensively with the USN, I have a multi-system television and a DVD player. But you can also use a MAC or a PC to look.'

b"From the end of the 50s, a series of country music films was produced, perhaps in reaction to the successful series of rock films of the year B from the same period. Most of them presented some kind of argument that involved rubes and got into all sorts of problems. But these films were not just the crazy extravaganza of hilarious hillbillies; They were the extravagant and funny hillbillies that had the famous stars of country music as friends. In other words, the weak plots and the failing movie stars were just an excuse to show a lot of stars of country music of the time. Many of the performances were synchronized, although some were recorded live. The sound of Nashville, which was recorded in 1969, was different. Perhaps influenced by the Pennebaker documentaries of the time, this film did not have flimsy or scathingly cheesy plots. Instead, it was a serious look at Nashville and the country's reigning stars of the day. It is well filmed, it is meticulous and fascinating to watch. Much of it was filmed at the Grand Ole Opry, but you also get invaluable material, such as Loretta Lynn playing for a lunch crowd of people from the radio and the record company, the shy brother Oswald singing a Mountain Dew choir out of Record Ernest Tubb's shop, an essay by the newcomer Mother Earth (with Tracy Nelson), a performance outside the house of Shelby Singleton, a recording session with Doug Kershaw and a young and beardless Charlie Daniels, and much more. There are also many great images of Nashville. All the performances are exceptional, and the film does an excellent job of capturing the essence of country music at that time: artists, fans and industry people. I've been waiting a long time for this to appear on DVD!"

b"Action films remind me of the true beauty of movies, how a story can be told through visual arrangement and movement through the frame, rather than the motionless dialogue and conversation of two immobile actors. Those films are like filmed plays, while others are inspired by their black silence & amp; White roots, tell stories without words. Road Warrior contains one of the best examples of this: such a small moment, a minor obstacle overcome, but that dances boldly across the screen like a painter. Here is the magic, shot by blow. Halfway through the final chase sequence, a red hotrod approaches the back of Max's big truck with the intention of killing him. In a shot that has been copied many times, Max leaves the cockpit and pushes his shotgun against the camera: forced perspective, moving to the right and then to the left, back and forth zigzagging across the screen. The bad guy's head explodes like a firecracker, and we receive a shout of joy from Max's wild wolf friend, an animalistic reaction to the violence ironically given by a child raised by animals. Now we have a series of jumps. cuts that tell the little story that the red car lost control and hit other bad vehicles. That little story closes with the famous and almost peaceful shot of a man who turns on his head in a horizontal fall, again in forced perspective flying towards the camera. Now another series of jump cuts as we go back to the red hotrod and we struggle to keep away from Max's huge wheels. In a beautiful movement game, the car dances in front of Max's truck, coming and going in front of Max and our screens like a dangling carrot, until we have a third masterful chance of forced perspective: the camera approaches the grill of the truck, then moves up and into the cab in Max, when Max finally ends the misery of this car by driving it into a gasoline explosion and pieces of metal. Such sick and twisted beauty ... Did you know that George Miller, the director of Road Warrior, also directed Babe?"

b"The Ruff Ryders have become street legends in multiple ways throughout the Hip Hop culture and have set a quality standard in delivering a product that is often harsh and does not apologize at hardcore levels. This documentary about it is a small exception. The quality of the tape was: Gyarrbage. The main man in sight-Wink 1100 is a skillful ryder without a doubt, but he does not show much in terms of tricks on this tape other than wheeleez, wheeleez, and yes more wheelez with some ryders sitting on the handlebar, stopping the bikes with the nose down, up, and yes -more wheeleez. All this for the glory of saying that you can go for BLOCKS with Wheelee in your mind. Wink's comment and the few personalities of comic characters he has created for himself are fun but short. They are funny in a strange and too long way. There are many scenes with repeated sequences. It's only an hour, but by the time you see your 100th wheelee, you're done, and with Wink's words, you feel like `` Gyarbage '' for buying this tape. My recommendation would be to wait for Biker Boyz to come out on DVD and just continue with the scenes in that movie where the main character and his team are letting the professional STUNT Doubles do tricks. There's nothing like that in this RR project and with all the fuss they put in there, there should be. Maybe RR guys should stop smoking and drinking that oil so they can concentrate on more than wheeleez! -Seriously -RR has the flyest logo and support team with music, clothing and movies to boot, so it offers more and invests in some camera men and quality editing. OUTSIDE ."

b'Once I saw that the DVD was made by Paramount Pictures, I had high expectations of the quality of this image for Blu-ray. I was not disappointed! b"It only takes a few minutes to see how horrible this is. The movie starts with some jets involved in a high-speed transcontinental race. Well, our pilot hero Grant (Antonio Sabato Jr.) decides that he needs to be refueled. Have you ever seen a pit crew load fuel on the track during a NASCAR race? No ... not me either. It would be a bit dangerous, I imagine. Well, Grant's plane is filled with fuel with another plane while they are in the direct flight path of the other racing jets. What happens ? Duh ... there is a horrible collision and three pilots (along with 11 spectators ... huh?) They end up dead. Good move guys. Maybe the most fun and pathetic event in the movie happens a bit later. Several years have passed since the tragic incident of the jet race and we are listening to a network executive who had done a live broadcast of the race. The executive says ... are you ready? ... he says the footage of the planes that collided during the race was the best rated news recording they had shown for the past four years. Amazing ! ! Talk about a future world in which nothing exciting happens. It must be boring. Other things to look for are people who somehow make a coughing sound while their mouth does not even move. In addition, a scene in which a shirtless Sabato Jr. is about to put on a tank top. He picks it up but the camera changes angle and now you can not see it anywhere. Then, the camera changes angle again and is passing it over the head. Great edition! Everything is a bargain basement in this movie, except for the half decent performance. However, with a fine plot like paper and terrible effects, I recommend that you do not waste your time watching this disaster. One final note ... without nudity and graphic violence, I have no idea why this is qualified as R."

I can not believe that everyone was so tied up in cash, all of them are billed by the television actress Kristianna Loken (who last saw the big screen while playing the monster of the bad boss in Terminator 3), in the main role of The movie, a half human vampire half that is about to kill Kingsley The character of Kagan, because Kagan killed Rayne\'s mother The fact that he is also her father does not seem to make her question her motivation too much. This film has enough character to have a lot of motivation, that does not seem to bother Boll, who cuts this movie in exactly the same way as the others: a lot of action, touches of sex that could actually be interesting if you care enough to explore those scenes, a useless script, a camera work that is just this competent side, and Boll\'s rather impressive ability to squeeze the worst possible performance from anyone who throws. And yet, despite all this, the most depressing thing about Bloodrayne is that the movie went well enough abroad (predictably, it fell like a nightmare in the United States, earning two and a half million, well below a fifth of your budget) that Vivendi gave the green light to Bloodrayne II. At least none of the original cast, including Loken, was strong enough to sign up for what can not help but be another Boll monstrosity. (zero)'

b'This is my favorite movie about Bernadette and Lourdes. And now this new remastered large screen version, just released by Ignatius, has a high quality image and higher quality, along with so many bonus additions, including the first available version of the French version (original) and the wonderful movie and Radio interviews with the wonderful Sydney Penny. Those interviews add a lot to this movie package. It\'s great to see and hear the lovely Sydney Penny speak in person about what it meant to play this role. (This film was actually filmed in English and French, with two shots followed by Jean Delannoy, and both versions are on this DVD.) ALSO: the glorious voice of the incredible singer Jenifer Warnes and that deeply moving song that she and Leonard Cohen wrote, "Song of Bernadette", on the extra CD in this package. Now I hope that many, many more people will listen to this beautiful song and tribute to Bernadette for this fabulous Grammy winning artist. She also has a second beauty sung by Jennifer Warnes on the CD, her song `` Prairie Melancholy \'\'. Another jewel of the music of this celestial singer. In this 150 year anniversary of the Lourdes apparitions, this new remastered film recently, with the audio CD and the songs, Penny\'s interviews and the 16-page Collector\'s Brochure, is a wonderful way to honor the story of Lourdes and this inspiring movie.'

b'The cultural revolution that shook Paris from 1905 to 1930 is well documented in this fascinating two-hour DVD documentary, which includes photographs, film archives, literary excerpts and analysis. The focus on the arts, from classical music and jazz to sculpture, from poetry to dance, from canvases painted to novels. The rise of modernism from the post-impressionists to Fauvism, Cubism, Dadaism and Surrealism and its many works of art and literary pioneers is seen as an extraordinary period of free experimentation and interdisciplinary interactions, particularly between poets and artists. Paris was the fermentation pot and the vanguard was strong, sharp and multiple. Watching this documentary can cause envy. Or to have lived in that moment! Of course, I and many of my generation experienced such a revolution, albeit of shorter duration in this accelerating society, when the Bay Area of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bSan Francisco circa 1965 to 1980 was the center of scientific, musical, artistic, noetic, ecological and scientific innovations. of another type. and explorations. What brings up a small deficiency in the documentary: the absence of mention of developments in science, especially physics, and its influence on the arts, when the concepts of time and space and matter were subject to a radically new thinking . Otherwise, the survey is a wonderful cultural story, from the optimism of before the First World War and the engine of cynicism and creative criticism after that carnage. The viewer can immerse themselves in the many books that cover this exciting period for further study. This DVD is an excellent introduction in art history and cultural studies.'

b"We should all congratulate Uwe Boll. It's like a kind of cinematic cockroach. No matter how little talent he has, and no matter how bad these films are, he manages to keep doing it. I know, he funds them all through some kind of strange German background, but even so, his ability to continue making films despite total and absolute failure is one of the great mysteries of the universe. It would not be so bad except that video game developers continue to give their best properties to this guy. I really enjoyed the Alone in the Dark series of games. Even the last one, the New Nightmare, was good for a few hours of play. There was a good movie to make of the adventures of Edward Carnby, but this is not all. Now Uwe Boll has in his hands Bloodrayne and Hunter: the Reckoning. What's next, Silent Hill? Doom? I can only imagine the range that this guy is going to cut through game-to-movie adaptations if he does not stop. Someone has to take away your line of credit, or these video game publishers must realize and realize that when they make a bad movie of a game that kills the franchise, no one is interested in that title anymore. Think about it. , is House of the Dead or Alone in the Dark a viable game title? No way . A new game of House of the Dead goes out for XBox and nobody cares about it. The title is dead, and all for Uwe Boll. So, if one of you works for a game editor, or knows a game editor, or has access to a game editor ... please let them know. This movie in itself does not even deserve to be reviewed. I can not separate what I did not like from this pile of manure from the rest. Literally, everything about that sucks. Writing, acting, music, CG effects, editing. I thought that if I waited until it came out on DVD and then I rented it with few expectations, I would not be disappointed. Even the $ 5 you will spend on this DVD if you buy it used at one of the Amazon sellers is too much. You will regret it . This movie is just a bunch of Boll."

b'There are many scenes in this movie that really tell the truth about how secretaries are treated in the American workplace. Anyone who has ever wanted to get ahead but has been a victim of class snobbery and arrogance in the workplace will relate to this movie. Weaver is perfect as the ice queen executive who makes things difficult for Griffith. Ford is friendly in his role. Watch Kevin Spacey in a small role.'

b'This musical still delights us and we love it ... more than 40 years after its creation. We win our old-fashioned applause, with good solid music and dance entertainment. Robert Preston shines like Professor Harold Hill ... an unscrupulous swindler who intends to cheat the entire population (around 2,400) of River City, Iowa. He works his way into their hearts (and their pockets) and manages to stay one step ahead of the authorities. Along the way, he (Prof. Hill) touches the lives of an old maid (Shirley Jones as Marian the librarian) and his extremely shy little brother Winthrop (played by a very young and adorable Ronnie Howard) and, to his surprise, It is in the unknown territory of a good doer. His planned escape stalled, he got caught and must, um, face the music. Throughout the way we are given quite a few memorable and fun songs and some delicious dance routines. The filmmakers showed some waste ... using some imagination and taking a risk ... and they gave us a lot of entertainment. My favorite places are the opening sequence of the train and the excellent dance scene (and song) inside the library. The people of River City are stubborn and narrow-minded ... but in reality they are producers of comedies. Virtually all the adult characters in the film deliver their share of the work load ... and add humor to the general fun of the film. Paul Ford, like the bewildered mayor George Shinn, is particularly good ... and Hermione Gingold, who plays his wife Eulalie, is also funny (though in a different way). Shirley Jones is pretty good here. She has always been a great singer, but she also makes some effective and fantasy steps. Pert Kelton, like his Irish mother, is a delight. But the program belongs practically to Robert Preston. A very skilled animator, he is light-footed and equally agile (and agile) as he handles his lines. He is not a great singer ... he speaks most of the lyrics of his songs ... but they (the songs) work, and they work well. I heard that, in the pre-production phase of making the film, they wanted to replace Robert Preston (the star of the theatrical version of "The Music Man") with another person. Meredith Willson, the writer of the original story, gave them an ultimatum ... either Robert Preston stays or ... there is no movie. And, seeing him act (Preston) here, it is easy to understand that feeling. He is a delight.'

b"This shows that, until the end, the King of Pop possessed all the elements that made him a superstar. Here we see the preparation of his failed London Comeback, but although we all know how this story ends, you can not help but smile when you see Michael in his element of home and just have fun. The most intriguing part of this documentary is the lack of real dialogue of Michael Jackson, but you can feel totally in their expressions the gears that work busily in their interior; He was pouring every ounce of effort he could muster in this final effort to thrill the world. This is Michael Jackson, unlike what he has seen in years. Here he sings all his songs live, even the fastest ones like Jam, They Do not About About, and Smooth Criminal. This element also really shows the fans how really exhausting it was for him to give the crowds dancing and singing, and this footage makes it obvious why for Dangerous and History tours he had to synchronize several numbers faster. Many of MJ's dance moves are omitted, and I wish I could have seen some of the essay sequences without the occasional distraction. of the 3-D short films (I wish they had put it on a split screen so we could watch that footage and the acting on the stage at the same time). The highlighted performances of the essay are definitely the following: They do not care I can not stop loving you. I'll be there. Thriller (totally new production that the one that was used in the tours of Dangerous and History!). Beat It (for the first time in years I have seen it dance the same as in 1982!) The others are also good, but none are as crisp or polished as those trial numbers. The key point of this rehearsal recording is getting to hear him sing his hits live, and it would have been better if the album This Is It included those instead of the studio versions ... Also, Michael's new female guitarist is great (in the eyes and in the ears). Many dance moves of MJ are omitted, and I wish we could have seen some of the rehearsal material without the occasional distraction of the 3-D short films (I wish they had put it in a screen division so we can see that footage and the performance of the stage at the same time). Therefore, to be fair, it is not at all an MJ concert experience, but it does have all the elements of one. The slogan of `` Know the man you never met '' is not really accurate because there is very little of Michael Jackson's true dialogue outside of seeing him say `` God bless him '' to everyone on the production team and point out when he thinks that something must be changed about the way something is done. Everything and all this is probably going to be remembered as the best concert that ever happened in the history of music. From these few vague fragments of what is the concert of This Is It Real, we can see that Michael would have had a great comeback through this series of concerts, and that once again he has demonstrated that he was and always will be the King of Pop. It is recalled that although the tabloids tried to throw him into the light of evil, Michael Jackson's ONLY message was of love. LOVE . clear and simple"

b'I found this movie completely entertaining. The story is simple and, in some way, quite important: Camille, a well-known Parisian actress, returns from Rome to perform in front of her local audience in a play directed by her new lover Ugo. The work is Come Tu Mi Vuoi by Pirandello, a classic (written for his lover Martha Abba) about a woman trapped between the yin and yang forces of reality and illusion. Throughout the film, Rivette switches his camera between the play and Camille and the "reality" of Ugo, as if to ask who the real Camille and Ugo are. What do they really want? What makes them work? Can I, the viewer, enter his universe without scriptures? Rivette (and his excellent actors) show us that delicacy can be robust and inventive, that the desire for another can never be fulfilled and that compliance does not really matter, because in the process of the struggle to achieve it we become alive and creative . . What matters is the style; style is substance We are also offered a brilliant description of the incestuous relationship between the Italians and the French, and there is a delicious succession of nuances, suggestions and games with national stereotypes that made me smile. I can see why some - those accustomed to Hollywood clich\xc3\xa9s with their happy endings and predictable diagrams - might not find the film so hot. Well, that\'s a shame ...'

b'Toilet training is part of the parenting process and, although it usually begins in the young child\'s years, it can take more time with some children than with others. Potty Power tries to accelerate the process by presenting a DVD that encourages children to use the potty and leave their diapers or diapers forever. He achieves this through his talk, songs, sketches and optimistic attitude about the use of the potty. Jessica, the narrator of Potty Power, is encouraging and extremely cheerful. She talks about pee and poop, slang terms for bodily functions, and more, while managing to keep a smile on her face throughout. She really wants the children to learn to use the potty, and her enthusiasm, hopefully, will be passed on to the children watching the DVD. This DVD is certainly useful and I know many people who have had great success in showing them this training session. Small children. But it gets a little cheesy and many adults will roll their eyes while they listen to the dialogue and the songs. Songs like "I\'m proud to wear my underwear, clean my ass" and others are certainly attractive to young children, but even some young people will find the material too dumb to be true. One of my babies is already trained to go to the bathroom and she laughs out loud when she watches this DVD, due to her silly and often cheesy style. Leaving aside the important thing is the effectiveness of the DVD and, in my experience, Potty Power has made a difference. My youngest likes to repeat the lines he has heard from this DVD and he likes to sing along with the songs. She has been going alone, to the potty, so the DVD seems to have a positive effect, even if it sometimes becomes annoying. Potty Pot, despite its foolishness, is an effective means of weaning children. your diapers and pull-ups. If you manage to pass the foolishness of the whole experience, the excessive perplexity of the narrator and the parody at the end, Potty Power seems to have something in favor. Children will remember the melodies and the message, making this DVD a good complement to training for the bathroom.'

b'This series of detectives in particular is above the large number of whodunnits. Only another series of detectives in his class comes to mind, and that is the Sherlock Holmes series that starred the wonderful Jeremy Brett. There is something terribly interesting about the relationship between Lynley and Havers. It is always strictly platonic and professional, and yet it is something more ... a friendship. I affectionately refer to Havers as Lynleys\' "working spouse". Those familiar with the series and the newcomers will see that, to a certain extent, this is true. Leaving aside friendship, there is a lot of hard core detective work in this series. I enjoy the brainstorming sessions of Lynley and Havers and even their arguments, which can be scathing. I must mention a word about actor Sharon Small. It is necessary to say that Mrs. Small adapts perfectly to the role of Havers, it is almost incredible. In general, this is a series of high quality and very entertaining detectives that only appears from time to time.'

b'Former government agent Edward Carnby (Christian Slater) must solve the mystery behind the events that happened when he was a child in order to save the planet from being destroyed by monsters from another dimension. Well, I\'ll admit, `` Alone in the Dark "It\'s not in my best movies of all time, but it\'s not in my worst movie list either." It can be directed by Uwe Boll, who is considered by many to be the worst director of all time, but if all of Boll\'s other films are like that, then Boll has been underestimated, because I\'ve seen many films that are much worse than this one ( for example, `` The Stepford Wives remake \'\'). The script is based on a video game, which gives `` video game \'\', moving from level to level, feel that you get with many movies of this type (like `` Resident Evil \'\' or `` Doom \'\'), but that did not discourage me so much as to want to go out and play the game. . Not being a player, this was my first encounter with `` Alone in the Dark \'\', and I found that the story was interesting enough to keep my interest in the length of the movie. The performance is unequal in quality. Christian Slater and Stephen Dorff (as another government agent) give decent shows, but Tara Reid is as unconvincing as she is a scientist who actually contributes to the entertainment value of the film. My main criticism is that some of the battle scenes are too long. There is a fight scene around the 1 hour mark that comprises about 15 minutes of people firing at monsters with very little dialogue, which became tedious after a while. Despite that, I still liked the movie and would be prepared to see it again.'

b'This is a masterpiece of a film by an inspired John Landis who takes a subject dozens of times before - lycanthropy - and adds a little sauce and spices to the kettle. Here we have a movie of werewolves with adventures, black comedy, some meat [both pressed and torn like bloody pieces], laughter, "oh-my-gods" and even pathos. This is a great imaginative and inventive film with excellent special effects that you will never forget, since I have not seen it since I saw it in 81. It starts with a couple of young Americans who travel through the eerie European countryside at night. I love the scene where they enter a pub and are welcome like the plague. Both leave the place and are quickly attacked by a werewolf with a man who is killed and the other, the places where David Naughton [who plays David] survived only to become a murderous werewolf. All hell breaks loose later, while David falls in love during the day, kills at night and constantly runs into his backpack partner "with his back to his death", Jack, with torn and torn flesh. He shrugs with shame and laughs, because with each one of Jack\'s post-mortem appearances he is increasingly deteriorated until, in the end, he is nothing but a skull and a fascia. The scene in the theater when Jack presents David to each of his dead and devoured victims, complete with open holes and lost limbs, is a beauty. The scene of the transformation in which David becomes a werewolf in his living room is absolutely AMAZING and UNFORGETTABLE: this is a classic horror scene of all time. Greetings to the special effects and makeup professionals here. EXCELLENT filming by John Landis with refreshing originality and a wonderful and cunning variation of a stereotypical horror theme. I\'m sorry Naughton did not become the star he should have. If you have not seen this, DUE before the next full moon. Lon Chaney Jr would have been proud of these guys.'

The character of Miss Pross, played by Edna May Oliver, is incredible. We went from disliking her, admiring her and then loving her for her sacrifice that saves Mrs. Manette's life. b"A Faustian turnaround through the postwar New York and Louisiana, 'Angel Heart' tells a very old story from a surprisingly original and wonderfully chilling angle. The plot, which focuses on the case of an increasingly violent disappeared person, is reasonably simple, but the background story that triggers it is remarkably complex. When you reassemble the pieces at the end, it makes sense, but it's only fair. De Niro is excellent as Louis Cyphre, the 'businessman' with some collateral to raise, infusing the role with the right balance of sardonic humor and demonic threat. Mickey Rourke gives what will probably always be his best performance as Harry Angel, a shocked and disheveled war veteran P.I. The supporting cast is excellent, especially Charlotte Rampling as an occultist, and Lisa Bonet as a teenage voodoo witch. But the real star here is the writer / director Alan Parker. He has an extraordinary talent for the simple but powerfully disturbing image: a slow zoom on the outside wall of a New York hotel; a New Year's Eve crowd in Times Square; a descending elevator; a sweeping staircase; the rotating blades of a fan. These images are simple, cold, but positively filled with an infernal threat. The music of Trevor Jones is the perfect accompaniment, his saxophones waving wildly over the threatening rhythms and the ubiquitous beat of a throbbing heart. It is a completely disturbing marriage that will be afraid of surrounding you with the same grim certainty as the protagonist's destiny."

b"It is difficult to find words to begin to describe this fantastic show. First, the writing is excellent. There are elements of this story that make the viewer jump online or go to the local library to get more information about what is presented. There is a richness in the narrative that is not often seen on television today. For all that we are told, there are about twenty things that do not tell us ... what really involves the viewer in the program. It encourages active visualization, speculation, debate and research, among other things. That does not mean that one could not simply look at the show and get a supreme level of enjoyment from it. The first season, I was an almost active spectator, and I still thought it was the best show I had seen in my life. The image that creates the dialogue is incredible. And, of course, what is a great script without great talent to deliver the lines? In the forefront, there are powerful actors such as Clancy Brown as the troubled Brother Justin, and Nick Stahl as the quiet but intriguing Ben Hawkins. Seeing the seemingly disconnected stories between these two characters evolving is an incredible event. The show also features Tim DeKay, Clea Duvall, Cynthia Ettinger, Amy Madigan, Michael J. Anderson, Toby Huss, Brian Turk, Adrienne Barbeau, John Savage and even Pa Walton himself, Ralph Waite. If one is a fan of any of these actors, their talents stand out in this series. Emotions are high throughout the first season, and these actors know exactly how to portray them. And what is an excellent writing and a beautiful performance without a spectacular fall for the action to take place? From the windy sandstorms of Dustbowl Oklahoma to the beautiful countryside of rural California, each set is perfect. The eyes receive beautiful images to absorb. Finally, and most importantly, the great participation of history alone. As I mentioned earlier, this program makes one an active spectator. If ever, for a moment, you believed in the era of wonder ... the magic of the past ... this series is definitely worth the money. The elements of our daily life are put into question and a completely new world is created before their eyes. I challenge every person who buys the DVDs of the first season to watch only one episode at a time. Look at one and wait a week before seeing another. I bet you can not. You will be anxious to see what happens next. If you do not think this is possible with a television program, remember ... it's not television ... it's HBO."

b'I have to admit with shame that before this movie, I did not know who Harvey Pekar was. But that did not limit my ability to enjoy this movie, which was one of the most interesting I\'ve seen in a long time. The theme of the film as a whole is brilliantly summarized in the first few seconds of the film. Several guys go to a house on Halloween, all dressed up as Superheroes except for one guy, who is dressed just like him: Harvey Pekar. The film as a whole is about Pekar\'s attempt to tell his own worldly, boring and disappointing life in a comic. Instead of a comic about superheroes, he imagined a comic about himself, a file clerk at Veterans Hospital in Cleveland. The film tells the story of Pekar\'s life in varying degrees of detail, highlighting his encounter with R. Crumb in the 1960s and Crumb that inspired him to start a comic, despite his inability to draw. Taking incidents of his own life, involving his friends and colleagues, designing frames for comics, and then hiring artists to illustrate their stories (many by Crumb himself), Pekar manages to create something unique, fun and, in itself, strange, triumphant and beautiful. The film implies that we can all be the heroes of our own history. Not much happens in the movie, but it manages to be fascinating despite this. The big events in the narrative are the meeting of Pekar, R. Crumb, his decision to write his own comic, meet his wife, a series of special appearances in the late 1980s on the Dave Letterman Show and his fight against cancer. Throughout this, there is no attempt to make Pekar look better than him. He is described as physically unattractive, a bit odd, a chronic low performer, more than a little neurotic, and extremely self-absorbed. But despite all this, there is an honesty in looking at your life and practically representing it as it is, warts and everything. The way he handles everything with an indefatigable sense of humor and his determination to do something to give his life a focus and purpose is heroic in a very real and concrete way, as opposed to the false and fictional heroism of Superman, Batman, or Green Lantern. It would be difficult to surpass Paul Giamatti in the role of Harvey Pekar or Hope Davis playing Joyce Brabner, the woman who marries Pekar. Both the real Pekar and the real Brabner also appear in the camera, as do most of the real life models of the Pekar characters. In fact, the way in which the narrative of the film flows smoothly between real-life individuals, actors, comic book representations is one of the film\'s strengths. In one scene, Paul Giamatti playing Pekar and Judah Friedlander playing Pekar\'s friend (and minor MTV celebrity) Toby Radloff are on screen while the real Harvey Pekar and Toby Radloff have a conversation. Elsewhere in the film, Hope Davis and Paul Giamatti are supposedly behind the scenes on the Dave Letterman show, but when Giamatti as Pekar comes out to take the stage with Letterman, he cuts images of the real Pekar interviewed by Letterman. I remembered the famous Margritte painting, where he has a painting of a pipe with the words "This is not a pipe" underneath. Going from the real Pekar to an actor who plays it, is a way of saying "This is not Harvey Pekar" when Giamatti appears on the screen. In addition, he suggests that Giamatti is the cinematic equivalent of the various Pekars drawn in the comics. It\'s a great movie, and I hope it gets the attention it deserves. It\'s very different from the CRUMB movie, but I imagine it will especially appeal to those who enjoyed that strange but fascinating documentary.'

b'I\'m not going to destroy Hilary Duff as a previous critic, because in fact I think she was the best part of this movie, hence the only star. It\'s fun and feminine, but I could not enjoy it because of the constant stereotypes (ie, the blonde girl enters the business world and knows nothing apart from how to use color, as well as the consistent way in which female characters judge to men for their "hot abs" or "tight ass"). I was also a little concerned about the sexual references (that is, painting the bodies of others with chocolate and then "burning it" after a date, talking about climax, etc.). b"I believe that Waitress's excellence is independent, but my desire to please was undoubtedly intensified by the post-production tragedy of the murder of the writer and director Adrienne Shelly. I think that the co-star Cheryl Hines says it best in the film: Shelly's tragic and senseless death forces you to see the film from another perspective. I was surprised that Keri Russell was not nominated for any award for best actress. I thought she was outstanding. She is in every scene. His acting takes the movie. Actually, it's a series of interactions between her and her husband Earl (an incredibly nasty Jeremy Sisto), she and the client / owner Old Joe (a dyspeptic Andy Griffith) and she and the doctor / suitor Dr. Pomatter.
