b'In movies, as in most other forms of art, the larger works often come in smaller packages. Such is the case of `` The Five Senses \'\', an independent Canadian production that chooses for its subject nothing less profound than a meditation on what it means to be human. Writer / director Jeremy Podeswa has created a work of great poetic form and vision centered on a group of people who share the universal need to find true love and acceptance in a world where wounded and shattered relationships too often result in loneliness and magnified despair. Like all of us, each of these characters gropes for the dual goals of intimacy with others and the acceptance of oneself that are essential to human happiness. Some are successful, while others fail, just like in life, but none of the characters remain unchanged from experience. `` The Five Senses \'\', although it has a plot, is more an emotional piece than a narrative drama. Blessed with an excellent ensemble cast, Podeswa is able to draw us to the center of his world through the use of sensory images and a deliberate and methodical rhythm. In fact, one of the strongest themes that the film goes through is its examination of the part that our senses play in the definition of our world and character. Podeswa understands that we have become insensitive to our senses. As a result, use this movie to reconnect with that crucial element of our being. The quiet and silent tone, the dull autumn colors, the slowly moving camera, the disturbing music combine to create an atmosphere in which the public can become aware of every vision and sound that is presented to us. In our effort to establish meaningful intimacy with other human beings, we generally trust the sense of touch; however, this can serve, Podeswa shows us, both to trap us in a false intimacy and to lead us to one that is genuine. and durable Several of their characters use sex as a substitute for true closeness, while others establish a physical connection at a much deeper level. One of the most moving moments of the film occurs when a gay man, most likely an AIDS patient, breaks down to mourn during a massage session, with a broken heart because nobody has dared to touch him in a long time. This film recognizes the vital part that tender physical contact plays in the totality of a person\'s humanity. In a similar way, the film explores the beauty of sound, since one of the characters, ironically, an oculist, a man dedicated to preserve the organ of a sense, faces the prospect of imminent deafness and longs to create a mental catalog of all the exquisite sounds of everyday life that you will soon no longer be able to hear and that we so routinely take for granted. However, like all other characters, it is their spiritual emptiness and their inability to establish a meaningful connection with another human being that bring them their greatest obstacles to happiness. Podeswa also examines the smell that the part has when making that vital human connection, since one of the characters, a lonely gay man, revisits his former lovers to inhale his scent in an effort to discover if he can smell "true love." " `` However, `` The Five Senses \'\' is not simply a movie based on an ingenious \'\' trick \'\'. "On the contrary, breathes with the fullness of humanity because each of its many characters emerges as a fully developed and instantly recognizable human being." There are adolescents alienated by their own inability to fit into the accepted norm of society and made to feel guilty There are mothers who are terrified of losing their children, in one case, literally, when their daughter goes away and disappears and, in another case, in a figurative sense, since her teenage daughter seems to slip into inexplicable "strangeness". "There are adults who can not understand a life full of failed relationships that despairs for that last chance of happiness, often with the result that they end up farther than ever from that universally desired goal. One of the most daring aspects of `` The Five Senses \'\' is that it does not succumb to the temptation to provide a `` happy \'\' ending or even a conclusive ending for all its characters. The film recognizes that life is a messy and endless process of changing fortunes and personal growth and remains faithful to that theme until the end. This brave, disturbing and hypnotic film definitely stands as one of the real movie finds of recent years - a true work of art!'

b'`` The Exorcist \'\', along with films like `` Rosemary\'s Baby \'\', `` The Shining \'\' and `` The Ring \'\' stand out to me as some of the best horror films of all time. Not only were they good movies in themselves, but they `` broke the rules \'\' and stepped on new ground. This DVD contains many deleted scenes and behind the scenes you can see the making of the film. I know I\'ve heard that after a screening of the film a few months before its release, some screen executives thought that the movie should not be released. It was too scary. When you really look at the movie for the first time, you will be really scared ... ... if you assimilate it enough. Some people remember him for the "pea soup" incident, but this movie did not use gore to show his point. Like the other films listed above, he used intelligent images, dialogues and symbols to express his points. Most people who read this review know that the story was based on a case in 1947 in which a 13-year-old boy was supposed to be possessed. . Obviously, some details of the movie were changed. I would like to see a film of the "true" story of 1947 made in which no name is revealed, but the facts of the case are given. The Exorcist really deserves the 5 stars. Perhaps more writers and filmmakers today should go back and look at it before trying to make another stupid teen movie that calls itself a horror movie.'

b'The Enterprise collects several envoys from several planets to deposit them in a planetoid called Babel. His plans are to discuss the acceptance of Coridan as a member of the Federation. Some members of the Federation are strongly opposed to accepting them. Reasons range from bloody enmities to criminals\' desire to steal valuable Dylithium crystals from the planet. The protection of the Federation would put an end to such criminal adventures of other members of the Federation. Among the delegates there are Vulcans, Andorians and an alien delegation with pig faces. They look like crosses between Bassett Hounds and the Ugnaughts of `` Return of the Jedi \'\' with eerily empty eyes and a bad temper. The makeup of the Andorians was remarkably well done during the period of time. When the ambassador of Vulcan Sarek and his wife Amanda board the Enterprise, there is an obvious tension and Sarek asks that someone other than Spock be his "tour guide" on the ship. It is then revealed that Sarek and Amanda are Spock\'s parents. Jane Wyatt is the wife and the loving mother who has subjected many of her emotions to accommodate Sarek, but still lets them sprout from time to time. Mark Lenard begins his life-long career as Sarek, whom we continue to watch until his death in one of the last seasons of `` Star Trek: The Next Generation. `` Sarek has not spoken to Spock in 4 years. Angry that his son refused to study the same subjects that he and his father had studied, there are angry silences, but muted between them. Amanda must run from one place to another to placate the two in her gentle way. One of the pig-faced aliens, a tough guy named Gaz, confronts Sarek in the room and threatens him when Sarek declares his intention to vote for the acceptance of the Coridans. Shortly after, Gaz is found, murdered. An autopsy reveals that his neck was broken at a point that would cause instant death. Spock recognizes this as a form of death penalty used in Vulcan centuries before, preferred for its speed and painless delivery. A method called Tal-Shaya, well known to his father. An interesting fact is that the Romulan equivalent of the KGB is called Tal-Shayar in the Next Gen episodes: the Romulans are distant cousins \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bof the Vulcans and their languages \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bundoubtedly have common roots ... perhaps the English translation of Tal- Shayar be `` the neck killers \'\'? Anyway, it is believed that Sarek is suspect, but is removed when it is obvious that a defective heart valve has kept him out of service. A risky operation requires Spock, the only Vulcan on board with the same rare type of T-negative blood, to provide almost half of its blood during a transfusion. I do not know why they could not take a pint a day. Spock prepares to be the source of blood for his father when Kirk is attacked by an Andorian. The Andorian clearly stabs Kirk in the lower back, near his kidneys in the attack just before Kirk returns him and knocks him unconscious. Kirk leans to one side and raises a bloody hand and uses the wall-mounted intercom to call for help just before he loses consciousness. In the infirmary, we see Kirk with a bandage around his bare chest. Now they tell us that his lung was perforated and the Andorian barely missed his heart. Considering he was using a small knife that could not have come from his ass to his heart, I think they should have re-shot the scene of the fight, but that\'s the way I am. It is as if the lung injury was a reflection on the battle scene and perhaps the writers thought that the audience would not "suffer" a kidney injury in the same way that they would understand how a lung injury would take their breath away. Eh, whatever. Bad continuity in those scenes, in any way. Spock suddenly refuses to help in his father\'s surgery. Instead, he must command the Enterprise because there has been a murder aboard the Enterprise, an assassination attempt, discussions among the delegates and there an unidentified alien ship has been chasing them, just out of reach of their sensors and weapons. Like a pain, disoriented Kirk wakes up in Sick Bay, tells him the news and must find a way to get Spock to the operating table without violating Federation regulations and Vulcan\'s stubborn oath to duty and logic. A subsequent interrogation and the search for the Andorian who attacked Kirk results in some interesting finds that will make it on the edge of his seat.Despite some cheese here and there, this is one of the most exciting episodes of the ancient series. An excellent show'

b'Stephen King is best known for his books of the macabre, but what some people do not know is that he is also a master of comedy, as is the case of `` The Langoliers \'\'. The book was very complex and hilarious study of the human mind. The film goes even deeper, showing how funny people can be when faced with eminent destruction. Both the film and the book ask the question: "What would you do if you fell asleep on a plane, but everyone who was awake died? , and that one of the people on your plane is a psychopath, and another is a blind child who can feel bad, something like Haley Joel Osment in `` The Sixth Sense \'\', then you seek refuge in an airport, but all the carbonated drinks are flat and the food spoils, then you discover that these Pac-Man creatures (`` the Langoliers \'\') literally consume the past? `` Well, what would you do? It is a difficult question, and to be honest, I do not know what I would do. But I can say one thing, Bronson Pinchot (in a performance that is quite different from his beloved character Balki Bartokomous on the popular television show "Perfect Strangers") does not know how to answer the question either. Man, he goes crazy, and I\'m not talking about Riggs in "Lethal Weapon", "crazy", I mean he really goes crazy. It can be said that Pinchot really adopted this role for what it was and took the method of acting at a completely new level. Still not convinced? After all the laughs and slapstick routines (the scene in which Dean Stockwell drinks beer at the airport is absolutely great!), You are offered a fantastic suspense scene in which the Langoliers chase the fast plane by the fugitive . Just when the plane is preparing to take off the sharp teeth of Langoliers ... I\'m sorry, but you\'re going to have to watch the movie to find out how it ends. That is, if the Langoliers do not reach you first.'

b"This biopic, based on Take Me Home, An Autobiography by John Denver, will be enjoyed by hardcore fans (like me) but it is still horrible in many ways. The story begins in the early 60's when John (Chad Lowe) begins his career as a folk singer. Meet Annie (Kristin Davis) at a concert and fall in love on the spot. They get married and move to Aspen, but as John's career takes off, tension builds up in the marriage. They divorce, have a brief second marriage, and discover their love of flying, something that finally wins the respect of their stern father (Gerald McRaney). This movie is a summary of Cliffs Notes of John's life; It is badly written and amateur and lacks depth or emotion. Lowe (who puts on a disgusting clown wig that makes her look like Dana Carvey in `` Waynes World '') attacks without shame on all sides, playing an innocent lascivious who never seems to grow up. (In fact, although the film covers thirty years, nobody ages). Davis is very pretty, but the horrible script does not give her many opportunities to develop. McRaney plays the only character that seems real, and he is the villain of the piece. The story is superficial and Lowe's Denver is not particularly nice. His hair is so laughable and annoying that the movie has no chance. Although we hear Denver sing many of his songs, Lowe is terrible at lip syncing. The extras of the DVD are useless; Where are some images of the real JD that we love?"

b'Wish You Were Here was the follow-up album of Pink Floyds\' fucking commercial album, Dark Side Of The Moon that, among other great songs, contained perhaps its characteristic song, `` Money \'\'. Launched in September of 1975, Wish You Were Here is the favorite album of many of the members of the band and fanatics. When it hit the streets, it went directly to number one on the album charts in both the United Kingdom and the United States in 1975. From the first four notes, the basis of the song, invokes sadness, which was the story of Syd Barrett . Recorded at Abbey Road Studios in London during numerous sessions. Although some of these sessions were problematic, it was Roger Waters\' idea to split the central song "Shine On You Crazy Diamond" in half and join each half with three new compositions. `` Shine On \'\' was a tribute to Barrett, who, coincidentally, made an impromptu visit to the studio while it was being recorded. Wish You Were Here is the second conceptual album of Pink Floyd written in its entirety by Waters. It reflects his feeling that the friendship that united the band was, at that time, largely absent. Deep on issues of absence, the greed of the music business and Barrett. The album begins with a long instrumental preamble and continues with the lyrics of "Shine On You Crazy Diamond", a tribute to Syd Barrett, whose mental crisis forced him to leave the band several years before. Barrett is fondly remembered with phrases like "Remember when you were young, you shone like the sun" and "You took the secret too early, you cried for the moon". This simultaneous release on Blu-Ray and DVD is the authorized history of the album and was made with the full participation of the members of the band. The film is full of new interviews with Roger Waters, David Gilmour and Nick Mason and archival interviews with Richard Wright. Also included is manga designer Storm Thorgerson, guest vocalist Roy Harper and front man Ronnie Rondell and other staff involved in the making of the album. The members of the band discuss the initial difficulties of the first recording sessions and how the decision to divide `` Shine On \'\' became the catalyst. Other interesting information revealed through the interviews is the fact that before Barrett left the band, he had given up or abandoned the music `` beaten \'\'. he did not want to make music for "Top Of The Pops" and, ironically, band members blame the greed of the music business on themselves as the main impetuous for wanting to make music more commercially acceptable, if not exactly songs "pop". The film is also full of extracts from concerts and performances, as well as fragments of the band that work the parts. Pink Floyd: The story of Wish You Were Here is a fascinating documentary and worthy tribute to the band in the creation of the album of the masterpiece. For casual fans and collectors and musicologists, this is one you\'ll want to add to your collection. If you are an aspiring musician, then you will play again and again just to take a look at the creative concept. Syd Barrett was active in music for only about seven years, recording four singles, Pink Floyd\'s debut album The Piper in The Gates of Dawn (and contributed to the second), as well as several unreleased songs with Pink Floyd. In 1969, Barrett released a single, "Octopus", which presaged his first solo album (of two), The Madcap Laughs (1970), which was recorded over the course of a year (1968-1969) with 4 different producers as David Gilmour and Roger Waters. Almost two months after Madcaps was released, Barrett began working on his second album, Barrett, produced by Gilmour and Richard Wright, to be released in the late 1970s, before entering a self-imposed imprisonment that lasted more than thirty years. Barrett\'s innovative guitar work and the exploration of experimental techniques such as the use of dissonance, distortion and feedback had an enormous legacy not only in establishing the direction Floyd would take without him, but also musicians from David Bowie to Brian Eno and Jimmy Page and more influence of the drawing. After suffering from diabetes for several years, Barrett died at his home in Cambridge on July 7, 2006. He was 60 years old. The cause of death was pancreatic cancer. The occupation on his death certificate was given as `` retired musician. `` According to local newspapers, Barrett left approximately 1.7 million to his two brothers and two sisters. This sum apparently was largely acquired from royalties from Pink Floyd compilations and live recordings with songs he had written while he was with the band. The Dirty Lowdown'

b'Lacombe by Louis Malle, Lucien still impresses, although he tends to wander in the third act just when he is expected to squeeze more. But it remains a casually powerful reminder of the less heroic side of France under the Vichy government (the Nazis are barely seen in the film) since their not too bright farboyy simply moves almost accidentally in collaboration with the German Police completely composed of their compatriots after being rejected by the resistance. The film\'s greatest achievement is to show, like fascism in general, the appeal that collaboration had for the distrustful and marginalized in the community (only one of the "police" is a true fan) and the attraction of the unearned and unearned power as Lucien finds the power he has over people (particularly the tacit threat of surrendering his Jewish "bride" - perhaps somewhat symbolically called "France" - to the Germans) is much more intoxicating than killing animals . Throughout, as with the masterpiece of Melville\'s resistance, L\'Armee des Ombres, there is a mundane sense of reality that enhances the drama. Located in the kind of quaint little town that foreigners find idyllic, but which is a tedious hell to live for the locals, it shows how discomfort and opportunity is much more a driving force than malice. Certainly, it is far from glamorous, its collaborators roam in a local hotel getting drunk and lamenting their luck as war news gets worse (as noted, you have to listen to both German and British radio reports `` and divide the difference \'\' to discover the truth) and little by little the locals go crazy. The only extra on the Criterion album is the imaginative theatrical trailer, so it\'s worth picking up on the Criterion set that also includes Au Revoir Les Enfants, Murmur of the Heart and an exclusive extras album focused mainly on Louis Malle in place of the films themselves.'

b'Tom Hanks is the adult man with the mind of 13 years. As an aboy, he makes a wish in front of a carnival divination machine to be great, and his wish is granted (physically but not mentally). He goes on a quest to find the machine to change the desire; Meanwhile, get a job at a toy company. Hanks, of course, is a hit in the toy company (how old would he be 13 years old?). But he falls in love with a co-worker, which makes the decision to go back to 13 at the end more heartbreaking. Hanks is very good in this child\'s role. It\'s worth looking.'

b'My seven-year-old son wanted to learn piano, so I bought a traditional piano book for children: he ended up crying. I was looking for a way to teach him not to destroy his passion and creativity, or steal his joy of learning. While walking through the library, I was struck by the title `` Piano for Quitters \'\'. In a matter of days, my son was writing beautiful chord progressions and asking that "musical practice" be added to his daily work chart so he could play the piano before his other works were finished. Our whole family is now learning to play the piano and loving it! I am a former piano lover: I managed to survive a year of traditional piano lessons and tried several other piano methods, but when using Piano for Quitters (and it\'s sequal: Piano for Life), I\'m learning to play beautiful music together with my children and my husband.'

Being an artist, you really do not know what will happen to our protagonist, Hitman at the end. I throw the original word in this paper for a couple of reasons. The main character, `` John Anderson \'\' played by Duvall (although as the same character we\'ve seen him play before) is a hit man with a difference, not too macho is used to create this vulnerable, aging and somewhat repentant professional. He does not regret the "works" he did, but as he approaches the twilight of his life he has not established real roots. However, now she has a girlfriend with a ten-year-old daughter, and her love and devotion for this child shines, as does Duvall\'s love for Tango, interpreted so beautifully many times by the captivating camera of very attractive Argentines. Both young and old. The plot of the murder is behind the Tango for a good part of the film, and when Duvall returns us to his purpose of being in Argentina, we feel as much as he does for having to leave this wonderful dance. There are one or two moments in which the scenes of Duvall could have been stricter, but I never felt that they were big negatives. In general, I would recommend this film to lovers of independent film, dance and fans of Robert Duvall.'

b"The Ten Commandments, The Bucanero, Ben-Hur, El Cid, The Planet of the Apes, all the great films of Charlton Heston, no doubt. But this film, the performance of Mr. Heston as the passionate and complex Michelangelo Buonarroti, has no parallel in any of the previous or from the roles he has played. His portrait as the great artist is unimaginable and shows a tender side. In addition, Rex Harrison as Pope Julius II is also extraordinary. The two men create a good chemistry of the rebellious artist and a severe but sensible pontiff who entrusts Buonarroti with the great task of the Sistine. This performance reaches its peak when the two men stand under the great and not yet finished cool late at night and reflect on the images of God and the classical performance of Adam with certainty. Please, buy it, rent it, whenever you see it. If you love art, I'm sure you'll love this."

b'Almost nine years after seeing the film for the first time and almost 34 years since the events it inspired, the movie `` Apollo 13 \'\' seems even more captivating. The history of Apollo 13, for anyone who has followed the space program and especially for those who witnessed it, is as exciting as it has been throughout the history of the United States. It is full of drama, intrigue, plot twists and exciting danger. What\'s more, everything really happened! In April 1970, the American public was already seeing the incredible achievement of landing on the Moon as it passed. and they could not have cared less about the mission of Apollo 13. The interest was so apathetic that the transmission of the astronaut when the ship was about to enter the lunar orbit was not even broadcast on television. The inconstant public certainly aroused their interest when, not long after the emission without surveillance, a simple maneuver to clean the house (removing the oxygen tanks) exposed a fatal flaw that led to a tremendous explosion. That explosion sent Apollo 13 flying out of control, ended with any hope of landing on the Moon, and the fate of the three astronauts (Major Jim Lovell, LM pilot Fred Haise and Command Module pilot Jack Swigert) is in doubt. The heroic efforts made by the members of the Control of the Mission, as well as by the astronauts themselves, to bring the Apollo 13 safely to Earth is one of the best stories that have been told. The acclaimed director, Ron Howard, saw this and, inspired by Lovell \'The personal story of that mission created one of the truly great historical films that once came to the screen. `` Apollo 13 \'\' is a true cinematic achievement. Restarts the imagination and marvels that the space program was held in the 1960s and early 1970s. Using cutting-edge special effects in the service of history (instead of in place of it), Howard can give it to the public a close view of the entire Apollo mission. Using archival images to create the special effects scenes, the director can make the shot look realistic, as if the viewer were standing at the top of the tower watching the rocket about to take off. The scenes in space are well elaborated and are extraordinarily realistic. When the astronauts are forced to close most of the lunar module, and the entire command module, to conserve power, the audience feels the coldness and resentment that these men had to endure. The true mark of the greatness of this film lies in the fact that, although we know from the story that the men of Apollo 13 survived, the final moments during the reentry, as shown in the film, are incredibly exciting and time consuming. Then, the emotional release that comes with knowing they did it is so overwhelming that even the most cynical and hard-hearted viewer will be choked with emotion. The narration and the effects of `` Apollo 13 \'\' are great, but the film would probably have still falls short if it were not for the tremendous cast hired to perform these roles. Tom Hanks is solid, since the imperturbable Jim Lovell, Bill Paxton (who seems to find a way to get into every blockbuster) is good as Fred Haise, the reliable but untested rookie, and Kevin Bacon offers an accurate description of the ultimate replacement. minute Jack Swigert. Gary Sinise plays Ken Mattingly, the astronaut Swigert replaced by fear of a measles infection, with the right melancholy. Ed Harris, who plays the mindless rock of a flight director, Gene Kranz, delivers the other truly outstanding performance. Harris really deserved his Oscar nomination for this performance and no doubt there is a strong argument for him to have won the award for the eventual winner of the supporting actor, Kevin Spacey. `` Apollo 13 \'\', in itself, was a strong contender for the Best Movie honors, only losing to the worthy `` Braveheart \'\'. The only disconcerting question is why Ron Howard was omitted from the Best Director nominations (he would have to wait 7 more years before receiving his deserved by "A Beautiful Mind"). `` Apollo 13 \'\' is not just a great thriller; It is also a revealing history lesson. It allows us to remember those wonderful days of the search to reach the Moon, as well as the drama of that endangered flight. These days, it\'s disheartening to realize how the space program has stalled since those intoxicating days. `` Apollo 13 \'\' demonstrates, without a doubt, that we still have men with the will, the knowledge and the courage to take this space exploration to places beyond the imagination.'

b"Zatoichi Vol. Four is as good as the first three volumes. Like some of the other episodes, they tend to be similar to some of the movies. Despite this, the series is excellent. b"In Barbra Walter's interview with Al Pacino, several years ago, she said that this was Pacino's favorite role. But this film stands on its own despite this proclamation. This is the story of rags to the richness of the underworld with one of the biggest endings of a movie! Pacino plays a Cuban refugee thug, Tony Montana, who spider and drag (taking some lives along the way) to the top of the cocaine world in Miami with the help of his right hand Manny Ray (Steven Bauer). Pacino plays this part with such passion and energy that absolutely fuels this film from beginning to end. You can not take your eyes off the man. He adds humanistic dimensions to Tony Montana. It shows the humor, the machismo, the intelligence, the leadership, the guts and the shortcomings of Montana. It even shows the sensitive side of Montana (the scene with Michelle Pfeiffer next to the pool). Pacino really makes you like a character that is basically a safety ball. Now that's acting! There are memorable moments throughout this movie and some are very graphic, but what is probably the highlight of this movie is the great shoot 'em up scene at the end; Sosa's hit men infiltrated the Montana property to kill him because Montana made a big blow for Sosa. When Montana, full of cocaine, finally turns his attention back to the hit men, he fights again by challenging them with a machine gun / grenade launcher. & quot; Say hello to my little friend ! & quot; Now it's one of those famous movie lines in the history of cinema. He destroys them like dominoes, resisting the incredible shots caused by the cocaine in his system. This is a true & quot; boy is & quot; scene. It is an action driven by high octane adrenaline and Pacino plays it incredibly. His performance is so elastic that he wants to grab a machine gun and fight with him. Pacino ES Scarface! The DVD comes with great advantages such as theatrical trailers, production notes, biographies of actors and filmmakers, the realization of SCARFACE (with Pacino) and 10 shots of the film. The movie is in a mailbox format, but it is not digitally enhanced. It would have been nice to see the movie improved, but it does not affect the experience of watching this movie. In fact, I really do not care. It's SCARFACE!"

b"When Bruce Lee died in 1973, 2 films were combined in an attempt to capitalize on Bruce Lee's madness by splicing some of Lee's best moments from the Green Hornet series, and doing 2 90 min. `` Bruce Lee films '' to the joy of those who were eager to get more footage of Bruce Lee. The only difference was that they spliced \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bthe footage only instead of throwing a double unconvincing with 10 minutes of actual footage. Either way, this is a guardian for Bruce Lee fans, one that will be worth it in the near future. But still, I have to call Green Hornet vol. 1 and Fury of the Dragon (Green Hornet, volume 2) what is ... BRUCEPLOITATION, however. CAN WE PLEASE HAVE AN OFFICIAL GREEN HORNET BOX COLLECTION? THE ONLY ALTERNATIVE TO BUY THESE 2 SPLICE JOBS IS IN THE BLACK MARKET AND NOT THEFT. SOMEONE HELPING A BROTHER. LOL! WARNING WORD: Make sure your DVD player plays PAL discs before buying this DVD. My copy will only play on my Windows Media Player ... it's region 1, it's not piracy, but it's PAL will make all the difference as to whether it will play or not. Be careful ."

b'In my short list of must-see movie titles for 2011, Jose Padilha "Elite Squad: The Enemy Within" was certainly at the top of the list. I first learned about Padilha with the 2002 documentary `` Bus 174 \'\', an unforgettable real-life story of a bus hijacking that was publicly played in the Brazilian media. It was a heartbreaking image that had as much to say about contemporary journalism, rampant crime, local corruption, political maneuvering and the state of the police as it did about the actual event he portrayed. I think it\'s fair to say that some of these same themes have remained constant in all the future film efforts of the writer / director. That said, I want to point out that `` Elite Squad: The Enemy Within \'\' is actually a continuation of the 2007 project titled (you guessed it) `` Elite Squad. "Although the two films are certainly better served as companion pieces, it has an independent story that can be enjoyed on its own merits." If you choose to see this without having seen the first image, you may miss part of the background story The film focuses on the character that returns from Captain Nascimento, actually played by Wagner Moura, Moura is in charge of a special unit of crime and when a prison riot fails, the squad\'s tactics and decisions are questioned by human rights activists (dramatically guided by his ex-wife\'s new husband). Public opinion, however, is allied with the Moura for quick and uncompromising action and pushes it to a position of even more power, making it a mission to eliminate the rampant drug crisis in Rio, points to the lower class slums where the roblema has its strongest point. But by eliminating the obvious enemy, it can give way to a more unexpected nemesis. While corrupt policemen and unscrupulous politicians fight for a new power, Moura begins to realize that she has cut off the head of a monster to see another (more infamous) take her place. Unable to trust those in power, he sees new allies in the media and activists who were once critical of Moura\'s methods. The change is convincing, credible and undeniably terrifying. The film is shot in an aggressive documentary style that makes the unpleasantness even more tangible. While perhaps the narration depends too much on voice-over analysis, it does keep Moura\'s perspective in perspective, since the big story leaves it out of much of the action. In essence, it is a work of morality disguised as a saga of ruthless crimes, but in that sense it is surprisingly underestimated. The character changes are subtle and the action is relentlessly real. It is difficult to imagine that the film can have a happy or satisfactory conclusion, but what we have left certainly seems appropriate, even if it does not end all in a small bow. In the end, the characters distinguish this piece (Moura is fantastic) that has universal relevance in its corruption issues and those that would fight it. `` Elite Squad: The Enemy Within \'\' is a rare image that will make you think while entertaining. Around 4 1/2 stars. KGHarris, 2/12.'

b"Black Sheep (no, Chris Farley and David Spade star in a movie of the mid-90s) is a movie that must be seen to be believed. It takes place in New Zealand as a phobic man of sheep (Nathan Meister) returns to his old family farm to make peace with his brother (Peter Feeney) who is genetically altering the sheep that populate the earth. These sheep end with a hunger for human flesh, and those that bite become monstrous sheep (yes, they were sheep), and before you know it, they are going crazy. Yes, Black Sheep sounds absolutely ridiculous, and of course it is, but the movie is so nice that you can not help but admire it. Not to mention the brilliant effects of blood and creatures courtesy of Peter Jackson's own WETA workshop team, as rookie writer / director Jonathan King throws one visual gag after another on piles of spilled blood. It does not come close to the irreverent horror / fun of Shaun of the Dead per se ', but for what it's worth, Black Sheep is damn fun that fans of horror comedy should definitely see."

b'This DVD was extremely useful to me as a self-taught weaver who started with the socks several months ago. The comfortable format of a mother and her daughter sitting on a sofa discussing knitting and demonstrating various techniques was very useful. It is a pleasure to look on many levels. I love the spirit of Elizabeth Zimmermann and her daughter, the mastery of Meg Swansen. The well-organized index allows easy access to the various techniques for later review. This DVD is full of information, since it is very edited and includes a wonderful interview at the end. I highly recommend this video to new and experienced weavers alike. I also bought the DVD Knitting Workship, but of the two, Knitting Glossary is the most useful.'

b"`` Destination Moon '' and `` Rocketship XM '' came out the same year, but that's where the similarity ends. I consider that `` Destination Moon '' is the father of the modern science fiction movie. The quality of the production and the magnificent Technicolor give this film a quality that few later sci-fi films would reach in the '50s. What helps this movie is the fact that there are no real stars in it, but very competent and very recognizable actors at least. `` Rocketship XM '', on the other hand, was a rushed movie to beat `` ... Moon '' in theaters. The quality of black and white printing is magnificent and has been restored to its original and clear quality. Stars of Lloyd Bridges. The special effects for `` XM '' were decent for their time, but the effects for `` ... Moon '' were ahead of their time. If I were classifying these movies, I would give `` ..Moon '' to B +, and `` XM '' to C +. Both films are nice, and they make nice accompaniment pieces."

b"I love this training! It's a great program that takes about 45 minutes, and I can do it when I do not feel like going out to the gym. I have danced most of my life so most of the low impact training exercises I am already familiar with, but the repetition is wonderful, and I am a little sore the next day every time I do the low impact exercise . High impact training is a different story. I did it once since I had the DVD and could barely walk the next day! ! This comes from a dancer who is in very good shape. High impact training is mainly squats. As soon as I recover from the last time I did it, I will do it again because it feels great and is so good for you! There is additional training for both arms and abs. Each set has Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders demonstrating. Three of the cheerleaders have been selected to perform beginner, intermediate and advanced exercises, so you can choose which one you want to follow. The only thing I do not care about is that the coach who leads the training talks a lot. However, he is very motivating, and especially people who are not very familiar with the training or who are motivated to do so, I think they would really benefit from that. I was not sure about buying a training DVD because of the previous disappointment with them and the lack of motivation to do it more. Sometimes, but this DVD is an exception. It's really fun, it takes less than an hour of my day, and I can choose exactly how intense or easy I want to take it day by day. Highly recommended! !"

b'This extraordinary film, largely ignored, from the 1975 film reunited the star Gene Hackman and director Arthur Penn for the first time since 1967 & quot; Bonnie and Clyde & quot; (They also worked together on the "Objective" of 1985). Hackman gives one of the best performances of his career as a tired P.I of the world. who is confused in a case of ex-spouses who battle and who quickly descends to the most muddy depths of incest, contraband and murder. Meanwhile, Hackman\'s own marriage wobbles, and the script intelligently parallels this disintegration with the layers of deception and corruption exposed as it removes the mystery of his case. The excellent supporting cast includes a very young Melanie Griffith, James Woods and Jennifer Warren. The film features an excellent jazz soundtrack (a vocal version of the disturbing title track appears on Michael Frank\'s album Art Of Tea). Smart entertainment for adults.'

b"Nothing new happens in this movie. It has a lot of action, mainly in the form of explosions, but nothing in the movie really moves the Terminator story line forward. The spectator goes out where he entered. Equally frustrating is that the movie insults the viewer's intelligence with lazy screen devices. For example, there are scenes that involve the movement of huge and noisy machines, but the characters are not even aware of the machines until the machines are on top of them. Or consider that oil or gasoline barrels, or molten metal or liquid nitrogen tubes are conveniently ubiquitous so that the characters can shoot them when necessary to make an explosion or melt a machine. The movie is full of such devices. They play, one after the other, for about two hours. Nothing else happens. We do not learn anything new. My recommendation is to omit this horrible addition to the T series."

b"There is a reason why Uwe Boll is known as the error master. Bloodrayne marks the third videogame of Boll to the film adaptation, and like the previous ones (House of the Dead and Alone in the Dark) Bloodrayne is so bad that you have to see it to believe it. Kristanna Loken, best known for being sexy and playing the TX in Terminator 3, plays the vampire heroine in this incoherent mess, which for some strange reason also presents Oscar winner Ben Kingsley as the evil Kagan. The plot is the typical treatment of vampires VS humans, but the most intriguing aspect of Bloodrayne is how Boll got to attract these actors in this movie? b'+++++ This movie is based on the musical `` Cabaret \'\' (also called `` Goodbye Berlin \'\'). The music and lyrics are by the great John Kander and Fred Ebb respectively. It was run by, and the dance and music numbers were assembled by the late and great Bob Fosse. Personally, I\'m not too much for musicals, but this movie is much more than an excellent musical. I do not understand the idea that they only sing and dance. There is also a good story that delves into the corruption, decadence and false dreams of Berlin in the early 1930s when Hitler was coming to power. The story follows the life of Sally Bowles (Liza Minnelli) during this turbulent time. She is the so-called star of the nightclub Kit Kat who has a naughty master of ceremonies (Joel Gray). The writer Brian Roberts (Michael York) intrudes into Sally\'s world, hoping to take the vacant room in front of hers. He soon learns that it is a ball of fire and energy. Sally tells us her dream: "I\'m going to be a great movie star". That is, if alcohol and sex do not catch me first. `` The film alternates between real life and difficult outside of the Kit Kat nightclub and the carefree life inside, where those who attend can forget their problems and difficult times. The singing and dancing routines within the Kit Kat Klub provide a sharp counterpoint to the drama of real life abroad. Five songs from the original Broadway production did not come to the film as "interpreted" songs, but appear as background music. The music, the costumes, the choreography and the performance are exquisite. Especially impressive is Minnelli\'s performance, impressive on stage and equally compelling. It coincides with the fascinating performance of Gray as the Master of Ceremonies that injects humor and pathos, as well as effervescence and solidity in the procedures. The last scene of the song and dance performed by Minnelli is historical and unforgettable! This film won eight Academy Awards, including the best actress (Minnelli), best supporting actor (gray) and best director (Fosse). Finally, the DVD itself (released in 2003) is perfect in image and sound quality. It has a long list of interesting extras. In conclusion, I would recommend that you go to this cabaret (old friend). You will never want to leave! ! (1972, 2 hours, wide screen, 32 scenes) +++++'

b"Put me in use. That's what the so-called Ritchie boys asked the US Army. UU In World War II, and they got what they wanted. These new recruits, alien refugees - some newly arrived by boat from Europe - were sent to Camp Ritchie to learn how the German military did their part to interrogate prisoners in war zones. It is a story of World War II that had not yet been told, and the Ritchie Boys themselves make a fascinating observation and a wonderful story. These are soldiers with whom most of us can identify, people who were not so good at manipulating firearms, but they became determined in their work to enchant, confuse and terrorize the prisoners of war who appeared and had the information that they wanted This is an excellent addition to the growing subgenres of Jewish documentaries and World War II, and the skilful use of sports for intellectual interviews, music and archival footage. Dvd extras: A total of 43 minutes of deleted scenes and personal accounts complete the disc."

b'For those of us who watch anime and have many different opinions about what is and is not good, I must say that GWLTT was one of the few anime movies at a time that can be sustained without the typical anime movie formula to catch so many people as possible. But for the observer that is not anime, I would say that it is a good option to start if you have not seen much or if you just started. For the anime fan, this is a movie to add to the collection.'

b"Have you ever said & quot; Everyone here is crazy, but I & quot; ? Then you'll love this terrifying, minimalist, low budget, and very claustrophobic 1948 thriller. Detective Richard Carlson enters an insane asylum in an attempt to find a corrupt judge who hides from justice. But before he can catch the judge, his identity is revealed and he becomes a prisoner of his own plan. And the only person who can rescue him is the double woman who sent him there! A hard-edged thriller by director Budd Boetticher (& quot; The Killer is Loose & quot; & quot; Comanche Station & quot; Bullfighter & The Lady & quot;) who would later become famous for a number of existential Westerners (The Tall T, & quot; & quot; Ride Lonesome & quot; Who are men from now & quot; etc) featuring the solitary and moral Randolph Scott adrift in an ambiguous amoral environment. Personal note: in the 70s I met the late Budd Boetticher as a friend. We went on horseback through Griffith Park in his Andalusians and made several trips to Mexico where he still practiced his dangerous and beloved art of dealing with bulls on horseback. In life and in movies, he seemed obsessed with playing the role of male antagonist in constant battle with his surroundings. Boetticher preceded the director Sam Peckinpah on issues that made the latter famous. Boetticher was real. It's great to see this early gem available on DVD. (Full screen, B and W, 68 minutes, unclassified)."

b'Scarlet Street is better than The Woman in the Window. The vision of the nightmare is darker, more grotesquely detailed, more petty. And it does not have a compromised ending, as Woman does. Therefore, Robinson, a lowly humble accountant (who paints street scenes in the kitchen (after having cooked the dishes) is trapped in a claustrophobic marriage with a corpulent witch who thinks that art is a waste of time and money He dreams of escaping his art and tricking Bennett Bennett and his elegant man, Duryea, two intriguing sociopaths, have very different dreams.'

b"He is a clear teacher, and the exercises are presented at the right pace. On the one hand, as with other DVDs of this publisher, he is paying almost thirty dollars for sixty minutes of DVD. Traum is a good teacher too, but it seems too expensive. There are other better offers, and similar information for free on the web, so I'm not entirely happy with that. The second problem is that finger style exercises are pretty basic. I use patterns in the daily game that are more intricate than the ones he gives, and to me these seemed simple (I will certainly do them, though) and had worked harder for me. The only exercise that seemed intermediate was the arpeggios, in third and second position, which are more on the left hand than on the technique of the right hand. The two songs, however, are beyond the beginner, more intermediate. It seems to me that most of the buyers will be disappointed one or the other half of this 60-minute DVD, either boring as it was with the basic level of the exercises or intimidated by the complexity of the songs. What I would have preferred are 60 minutes of exercises, increasingly complex. I guess the average buyer would find it too boring (teach me songs!), But I'm very interested in improving and I know, by learning other instruments, that repetitive exercises are the way to do it. I wanted a DVD guide for them, instead of a printed book of them, and this is not exactly what I expected. As you point out, you could also use a selection with these exercises to work with your right hand. accuracy ."

b'Armand Assante is one of my favorites. I loved all his movies. I was very surprised to see it on a doo-wap paper, but it was fantastic as always. His emotional performance of a man who lost his wife to cancer and is now dealing with the possible loss of his daughter from the same disease is heartbreaking. Her relationship with her two children also brings reality to the love of parents for their children and the torment of their previous career as a singer. He and his group of singers of the 50s were very successful, but they were soon eliminated from the main scene. For the next 30 years, he works as a bartender and his group plays for weddings. If you love doo-wap and Assante, you will love this movie. Nostalgia at its best. I recommend getting the audio CD and playing it before watching the movie, then you will really enjoy it.'

b"For the great admirers of Manhunter, I would advise you to stay away from this DVD if you plan to have ... What has been announced as the & quot; Theatrical & quot; the version is in fact a poorly spliced \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bversion that awkwardly edits two scenes that had appeared at the theatrical premiere, including one of the most crucial scenes, and still has within it the most banal footage restored from the floor of the cutting room . These cuts are badly made and do not make sense to them, since they do not represent the theatrical presentation and destroy the impulse of what had been a finely edited film. I do not know if it was ignorance or arrogance, but this is the worst hacking work I've seen trying to pass itself off as a product. Whoever was in charge of this in Anchor Bay was an idiot and if I were Michael Mann, I would be calling my lawyers. & Quot; Director's Cut & quot; it is even worse in the sense that it includes the & quot; Not theatrical & quot; launch And the so-called & quot; Director's Cut & quot; - a compilation of some interesting and not so interesting shots. As a companion to a true theatrical premiere, this would have been a fascinating addition; BUT here once again, Anchor Bay finds a way to ruin what a good product should be. All the film that has not been processed in video, is stained and blurred, as if it had been transferred from a VHS tape, and a very worn one. - It is incredible that someone can have the audacity to offer this kind of cheap for the hard earned money. I saw this movie when it first came out in the theater and I considered it one of the best of that year; and I rushed to buy the LaserDisc version when it came out. When Anchor Bay released the Director's Cut DVD this year, I was on the waiting list, ready to receive the enhanced THX version with wide screen. Being intimately aware of the movie, imagine my disappointment. Do not waste your time. Wait for a better version to come out. As for those people who wish to compare the Silence of the Innocents with Manhunter, they usually prefer one above the other and their minds are practically invented at this time. I'm in Manhunter's camp. For me, I enjoyed the Silence, but I could never take it seriously, since I found the reader's notebook so caricatur- ally superhuman and, therefore, unrealistic and not very instructive. However, the Manhunter Reader is a chilling but more realistic description that impresses me every time I see it in how an evil genius manages to manipulate events outside his cell through the simple device of a telephone. This Reader is safe behind closed bars, and still manages to be a powerful presence to consider. I hope every fan and future fan of Manhunter sees it the way it came out, a fine piece of art that was slim and stylish, but that flowed with style. Siskel and Ebert rated it as one of the best films of all time, years after its release. But for now, I'm going to have my LaserDisc."

b'It\'s my fault that I had higher expectations of this movie, but I guess this movie was not made exactly for guys like me anyway. The acting is fine, the character of Matthew McConaughey Ben and Kate Hudson\'s Andie really just have to act and react. The dialogue does not matter. The character of Kate Hudson always has the top, which is fine for a while, but after an hour it becomes exhausting. She completely invades every aspect of Ben\'s life; We never see Andie\'s world, apart from her two friends and place of work. So, while both characters have a similar agenda, there is a complete imbalance of superiority, and this is the biggest deficiency of the movie for me. He endures all his attempts to "lose" him, but all this only produces frustration in Andie and drives her to do more crazy things. As a spectator, you\'re dying to see her fall on her face only once. But that is an illusion. Ben\'s resistance to Andie\'s antics barely entertains me, and Andie\'s total lack of shame does not make her his. Of course both look great, and Hudson smiles positively when he smiles, but man, 112 minutes is a long time to endure this game. I can imagine some people thinking that this movie is great. Girl Power and everything. I do not know . But I think we can agree that the film was conceived as a vehicle for Kate Hudson\'s rise to stardom. This film reminds me a bit of WHAT WOMEN WANT (with Mel Gibson) for a variety of reasons, especially because it was written and produced by women, that in the film world dominated by men is a much needed perspective, but Nancy Myers (the producer / director of What Women Want) is definitely much smarter than the \'brains\' behind How to lose a man in 10 days. You just have to look at the DVD extras to see evidence of this. We met two of the producers, who obviously had facelifts. I\'m serious . It is creepy . They talk about the material as if it were Shakespeare. Then there is the director Donald Petrie, who completely lacks charisma. DOING WITH HIM is so cheap that it\'s probably more fun to watch than most of the movie. While he sits there chatting, a television monitor behind him shoots still images of the film, and an office worker (with her back to the camera) stares at a static PC screen biting her nails and shaking her head. She does this for the duration of the interviews with Petrie. Oh, and did I mention the background music that accompanies the extras? It\'s music from the department store. Or elevator music. Anyone who hate more. I did not bother with the comment. Donald is boring. There are no discarded songs, which is unusual for a comedy. The deleted scenes are really good, Andie shows some honest emotions and we have some quieter private moments between the two protagonists. Look, it started well. It felt like a spongy and harmless romantic comedy, but the romance lasted about 10 minutes. I can summarize my criticism with this observation of director Petrie\'s reason why he was interested in directing the film. He says it was because he discovered that Kate Hudson was attached to that. Aha. So, basically, if the movie works well at the box office, then it will launch And its career in Hudson. I\'m sorry, Petrie, but that\'s not good enough for me.'

b"This is the romantic comedy by which all other romantic comedies are now judged. Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan have undeniable chemistry and a first class rhythm. And surprisingly so do Bruno Kirby and Carrie Fisher, who really have great moments that add fun to the movie. This film knows that no one knows how to present Manhattan better than Woody Allen and takes much of its traditions. Including the choice of romantic pop standards. As in Annie Hall, & quot; It had to be you & quot; it is the musical centerpiece for an inevitable coupling. The dialogue is fast and rhythmic with an ear for the sensibility of New York. And he also knows how to show favorite New York hangouts at their best. Even Billy Crystal is a bit nebbish. This film is still original and its style has been imitated innumerable times by other films with the hope of capturing a bit of its magic. Still none surpasses this. The icing on the cake was the wonderful choice to interrupt Harry's past seasons and Sally's relationship with the elderly couple who tell stories of their first encounter. The way they speak and take over the stories of others is charming and authentic and forces us to smile of recognition. When Harry met Sally it is a cheerful and very funny movie that never tires, no matter how many times you see it. It's a classic The DVD contains about 7 minutes of additional deleted footage. In this case, it is quite evident why it was eliminated. Observe it at your own risk. Rob Reiner's audio commentary seems to have been delivered at gunpoint. Do not look for many happy anecdotes or ideas about where you came up with all these great ideas. The comment track is quite slow and dry. & Quot; Making of & quot; the documentary is much more fun and insightful, so the extras are not a total wash. The sound and quality of the image are bright and exuberant, so the most important part of the album, the movie, is as pleasant as possible. When Harry met Sally he has a lot of fun with men and women trying to understand each other and makes us laugh a lot and even cry a little in the process."

b"I do not understand what constitutes a comedy these days. They act like children, running between them on the walls and throwing gum into each other's hair. We return to their meeting (Kutcher hitting her in the face with a soccer ball) and the subsequent romance. He is a cemetery turn traffic reporter for a radio station, while she has had all the education possible and is an avid art lover. The honeymoon is in Europe. You should immediately realize what some of the jokes will be. How about we try to connect something from the United States to the wall when the outputs do not fit and the power is twice as strong? ... LOL . Then there are the jokes about European hygiene, with huge errors that creep on our heroes when they are in the next hotel. Driving in Europe? Then you have to buy one of those European cars with suitcases that can not be worse yellow. Oh, and there are no extra points to guess that an old Murphy flame will appear and try to steal it. In general, this movie is bad. It's not the worst I've seen, and that's why it has two stars instead of one. But this is a completely brainless narrative, we've seen it before. In general, we have seen it better."

b'Although history surrounds the Spanish Jesuits who build a mission in the South American desert, the real action takes place in the heart. Robert DeNiro gives his best performance as a completely depraved and tormenting slave merchant who truly repents. This is a beautiful story of grace, since DeNiro tries to pay the ransom of his guilt and begins to discover the mercy and unconditional love of God. At the same time, questions arise about the reasons for missionary work. They should be inspired by the love of God, but other aspirations have been the impetus for many throughout history. As in the Crusades, there were some very good Christians with intentions, but there were also many who killed and conquered in the name of a loving God. This exemplary historical film will provoke thoughts and enrich the spectators!'

b"So 'Ally McBeal' is definitely over, although this compilation of episodes reminds us how great it was. Focusing on Ally (Flockhart), perpetually single, slender and crazy, the audience is attracted by her hallucinations (brilliantly done through an impressive computer animation), her loves, her losses and her work in a law firm that seems embrace the strange. What made this show great was that it was very different, with the crisp writing of David E. Kelley bringing a mix of well-placed observations on modern relationships and absolutely hilarious characters. Who could forget John Cage (McNicol), the diminutive lawyer with a pet frog and a crush on Barry White? Add to this Richard Fish, who seems to wallow in his own male chauvanism, 'Subzero' Nelle (diRossi) and the deliciously nasty Ling (Liu) and you have a hot cast that is very nice whatever it is you are doing. Although the last episodes have been criticized for not being funny enough, this might seem unfair, although there is always a tendency to feel nostalgic for the older episodes offered here. Balances gracefully, fun and romantic, and these previous episodes were genuinely revolutionary, paving the way for other more experimental shows. Still, it would be nice to see the stations in their entirety, as they are available in the UK."

b"Down Argentine Way is a type of light and delicious food from the early 1940s that should delight anyone who loves this type of film. We have excellent performances of great stars like Betty Grable, Don Ameche, Carmen Miranda and the incredible dance of Nicholas Brothers! The plot is advancing at a good pace and the performance was quite convincing. The action begins when horse lover Glenda Crawford (Betty Grable) and her mother Binnie Crawford (Charlotte Greenwood) are on the racetrack once again. It seems that the Crawford family has always loved horses and they also compete with them. Glenda sees a good racehorse and wants to buy the horse; however, the problem is that the horse belongs to the bad-tempered Don Diego Quintana (Henry Stephenson), who has a long and somewhat stupid personal resentment against Willis Crawford, the patriarch of the Crawford family. Anyway, Glenda and Binnie go to Argentina after their first attempt to buy horses from Quintana does not work very well. It is not long before Glenda falls in love with Quintana's son, Ricardo Quintana (Don Ameche), who is equally delighted with Glenda. The young couple tries to pass Glenda Crawford to Don Quintana as Glenda Cunningham in the hope that she will like it and then does not care if she is a Crawford; but that also has its complications. Meanwhile, there is a horse bred to compete: Don Quintana will let the horse race take place? It's a weak subplot, but the few horse races we see in this movie improve the action; And that's fine by me! Look for some excellent numbers of songs and dances, remember, these plots were practically excuses for the studio to record fabulous numbers of songs and dances. Rumor has it that after the audience first saw The Nicholas Brothers dancing, they applauded so much that the projectionist had to rewind the film to show his scene again! Charlotte Greenwood also scores big with her almost incredible ability to kick with her legs while dancing happily in another number. Betty Grable also dances very well. In addition, this film marks the cinematographic debut of Carmen Miranda; She sings a couple of songs during the movie, as well as a short song at the beginning of the movie. Carmen shines even when they were not performing as much as they did in later films! The DVD comes with a superlative extra about the life and times of Betty Grable. She really looked like an especially sweet girl who did not really want too much of life and enjoyed her private family life as best she could. The quality of the photographs in the Betty Grable extra is excellent. There is also a commentary in progress but optional for people who want to know what happened behind the scenes while filming this movie. Excellent ! In general, Down Argentine Way is a musical that is worth seeing. I usually reserve five stars for an MGM musical; But this time Fox really did it right! Fans of movie musical classics can not miss this one!"

b"It seems that no other Broadway musical was transferred so intact to the screen with every facet of its brilliant and gloriously theatrical production in its staging. River City, Iowa, of course, does not look more realistic than the Land of Oz, but that's how it should be. It's a satire, and fortunately director Morton DaCosta keeps everything in perfect condition, preserved to play exactly as he did on stage, even with respect to the opening number aboard a train where all the vendors sing about a certain scoundrel posing as a music teacher. The music of Jeremy Willson never sounded so good and was given singing and dancing by ROBERT PRESTON, SHIRLEY JONES, PAUL FORD and HERMIONE GINGOLD on the tracks, all of which are helped and stimulated by some of the best. singing and dancing you could ask in a musical of this type. Gingold is outrageously funny and Paul Ford, like her husband, the mayor of River City, is equally boisterous in a comedic role. But it's Preston's show from start to finish with her co-star Shirley Jones in good vocal form as the skeptical librarian. One of the best prepared numbers is the number `` Marian, The Librarian '' which takes place in the city's library where poles and sliding balconies become part of the intricately organized dance routine. All the musical numbers are interpreted with professional charm by a talented group of actors / singers / dancers who are part of the citizenship of River City. Little Ron Howard, the child with lisp, who later went on to fame as a director, is a standout as Jones' little brother. Muteness: Ancient and exceptional musical with your heart in the right place: Americana in the best tradition of the word. Finish: it has more charm than the law allows."

b'To be honest, I saw the movie because of the talent behind it. Unfortunately, I was disappointed with virtually every aspect of this movie. There are times when the action bounces back and forth between two sets of characters and situations (the Fifth Element) but there is little or no connection between the two situations, which leaves me dizzy and confused instead of entertained or stimulated. There is a development of extreme character, like the many times we see Peggy (Laura Dern) gliding to take a bite of her flask or pour herself a drink. The idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bher alocholism is hit in my conscience to the point of annoying me, and then I discovered that the fact that she has a problem of substance abuse has nothing to do with the plot, the interaction of the character or anything else. Why did Robert Altman make a big part of that then? Filling? The obsession with the Kennedy family by Connie (the character of Tara Reid) is another case in which a great deal of time is spent trying to show us this side of the character and is never followed for any tangible purpose later in the film. . Oddly enough, she is probably one of the most "normal" women in the picture. All this would have led to a mediocre movie, but the ending really killed me. I have no idea what the end is supposed to mean. In fact, it reinforces the idea that the whole plot was derived by the writers who completed several pages of Mad Libs and then edited them in a script. There really is no other explanation for why so many aspects of the film seem to be so random (or chaotic at best).'

b'Every time a film shoots for "realism," it generally opens the door to a predictable set of signifiers: handheld cameras, real locations, a naturalistic lighting scheme, street dialogue and tortured theatrical methodology. In only two functions, Funny Ha Ha and the new Mutual Appreciation, the writer and director Andrew Bujalski has reconfigured the language to something much closer to the real one. His dialogue of aesthetic DIY and semi-improvisation has earned him a frequent comparison with John Cassavetes, but he does not care so much about acute emotion; the characters in his films are clumsy and inexpressive to the point where they can not say what they feel, at least not without first having found out. Mutual Appreciation is not much more than a refinement of Funny Ha Ha, following a similar group of idle twenty-somethings while struggling with relationship problems and trying to give some life to their lives. And yet, it\'s equally strange to see, because Bujalski\'s stylized dialogue type sounds genuinely fly-on-the-wall style. The carelessly charismatic Justin Rice plays a musician who moves to New York right after his band breaks up, which puts him in a strange place, as he will play later in the week. Once in town, Rice reconnects with her friend Bujalski, a good-natured graduate student, and Bujalski\'s girlfriend, Rachel Clift, whom Rice begins to develop a tacit (and, by the way, mutual) attraction. Meanwhile, Rice finds a champion and more in the attractive college radio DJ Seung-min Lee, but gets into trouble when he brings Lee\'s brother as his drummer and tries to get away from her romantically. All this intrigue creates a romantic atmosphere. encounter between Rice and Clift, and a serious rupture in its relation with Bujalski, but nothing in Mutual Appreciation goes in agreement with the habitual script. The scene in which Rice and Clift finally vocalize their feelings for each other is the perfect example of what Bujalski does so well: any other romantic melodrama would make them fizzle with passion, but these characters are painfully hesitant and credible, given that They both betray someone they care about. What ends up happening between them is completely unexpected, but totally true for who they are and how the most affectionate people would act. But such things seldom happen on screen, and Bujalski\'s willingness to move on makes him a unique talent.'

b'God, this movie really stirred my stomach for its entire duration. Like atmospheric films, this is undoubtedly a masterpiece. It is quite a cooler and depends on the mood and a spooky atmosphere instead of frights and violence. The film is set in an old Jersey house shortly after World War II. Nicole Kidman plays the owner of the house, who lives there with her two children all the time waiting for her husband to return home after the war. At the beginning of the war. Three servants of the film arrive to help. They are still the only characters that really care about the movie. Nicole Kidman is excellent on paper, as are the two small children. Children suffer from a rare condition in which they can not be exposed to any strong light. This causes the dark scenes where the film is almost completely set in the candlelight. To prevent children from being exposed to any light, all doors in each room must be locked and unlocked when entering. the film is spent with the opening and loss of these rooms, as there is a strange presence in the house. In many ways, some of these scenes recall scenes from The Sixth Sense. As the story reveals the background of these char servants, it also begins to unfold. It gives the movie an incredibly intriguing feeling that made me feel constantly on edge during its duration. He never seems to be sure where this whole story leads, so the sense of mystery is quite unique. When they leave the house, the outside is covered by this almost surrealistic fog, which recreates a beautiful atmosphere. It reminded me of those Basil Rathbone Sherlock Holmes movies that used to give me chills as a child. the sun would rise only to temporarily raise the atmosphere to give the spectator a break from all this tension. The rhythm really accumulates when the film reaches a very, very dramatic conclusion. Beautifully filmed, really Gothic, brilliantly acted and worth seeing.'

b'Right up there with `` Planes, Trains & Automobiles \'\' and `` There\'s Something About Mary \'\' is my favorite Billy Murray comedy .... `` Goundhog Day \'\'. Murray (as TV Weatherman Phil Connors) is easily the only Hollywood star in the film, since the rest of the cast is much less known in the field. Andie MacDowell was probably best known for her modeling career in 1993, that as an actress ... she does a simply wonderful job as `` Rita \'\', the television producer. Chris Elliot does a good job in a less annoying role than he used to as "Larry" the cameraman (it has come a long way since it was "The Man Under The Stairs" in David Letterman). The other actor that really impresses is the man with the recognizable face, but what\'s his name (Stephen Tobolowsky as life insurance salesman Ned `` Bing \'\' Ryerson). Oh, and Scooter the marmot. As for the story, Bill Murray is stuck on the same cold day (which happens to be Groundhog Day) in Punxsutawney, PA that covers the now famous celebrations. He keeps reliving the same day, again and again. Every day he sees the same things. Every day he meets the same people ... the man in the hallway early in the morning, Doris the waitress, the mayor of the city, etc. He decides to get the best out of the situation and do what he wants ... only because he knows that he will wake up the next day and will be the same day one more time. While he tires of reliving the same day over and over again, Connors changes his focus to Rita. First, trying to impress her. So, trying to really take care of her. When it finally reaches her, the spell breaks and appears the next day. I classify some of Bill Murray\'s movies as classic ... that is. `` Caddyshack \'\', `` Stripes \'\', `` Scrooged \'\', `` What About Bob \'\', etc ... but I put `` Groundhog Day \'\' at the top of the list. An easy choice for my favorite movie Bill Murray # 1. It\'s also an easy choice for one of my best 4-5 comedies of all time. *****'

b"This is a fantastic movie, but please read other reviews about the acting, the camera work, the plot, the story, etc. This revision is only about the DVD version. The DVD itself is a big disappointment. Bad transfer, no extras, no surround sound, only full screen, and just a menu or chapter selection. Like the other Stanley Kubrick DVDs in this white box series, this Full Metal Jacket is more or less a VHS copy of the movie, only that they are put together on a DVD. I'm surprised it's not double-sided like the original commercial DVDs. Considering the advances in DVD technology when this album was released, there was no need to sell such a lackluster product, in addition to trying to get as many Stanley Kubrick films as possible in a large box before Christmas 1999 This film, The Shining and, to a lesser extent, A Clockwork Orange, all suffer from this same extremely poor DVD treatment. Fortunately soon this movie will be relaunched in a better DVD package, much like Goodfellas or The Shining. Until then, buy this DVD only if you are a big fan or if you are in the basket of negotiation."

b'One of the most delicious movies of recent years, `` Calendar Girls \'\', a far-away version of `` The Full Monty \'\', is the true story of a group of middle-aged English women who became international celebrities when They designed and posed for a nude fundraising calendar that sold millions of copies worldwide. Julie Walters and Helen Mirren head a wonderful cast, with Walters as a woman whose husband dies of leukemia and Mirren as her best friend, who comes up with the idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bthe calendar as a way to honor her memory and raise money for the local hospital. . The risk of any "feel good" comedy is that it will become cloying, shy or corny. Fortunately, `` Calendar Girls \'\' has an enormously ingenious script and top-level performances by its highly talented cast. Each one of the `` girls \'\' is given its own unique personality so that we see them not only as a group, united in this inspiring effort, but also as people who work through their own personal demons to complete the project . Women face expected roadblocks in the form of "disapproved" and disapproved voices in the community, but their belief in the wisdom of their cause rules out all those problems. This charming film offers laughs more genuine and direct than any other comedy of recent times. `` Calendar Girls \'\' is comforting, touching and inspiring, and what more could you want from a \'\' feel good \'\' movie than that?'

b"Seeing `` The smell of green papaya? it's like listening to a harmonious song. There is not much dialogue in this movie, but you will not feel bored. I enjoy the calm, elegant and elegant humor of the film. It uses many simple melodies and close-ups in the film to reflect the mood of the characters. The visual and auditory beauty provides comfort when looking at it. The first part of the film takes place in 1951, when the French authority almost came to an end. French has occupied Vietnam for more than 30 years before 1954. During the French administration, people in Vietnam had been influenced by the French. In the first half of the film, Mui lived in a traditional family as a servant. The grandmother lost her husband when she was still a teenager and she insisted on praying for her husband every morning and staying faithful to him. The father left home with another woman and took all the money a few times, but the mother never blamed him. Instead, the grandmother blamed her for not knowing how to please her own husband. In the second half of the film, Mui moved to a musician's house as a servant as well. The musician, who is also his teacher, called Khuyen, has been influenced by the French and knows how to play the piano. His house was decorated in French style, colorful and bright. Unlike the previous family, simple, old and all in wood. Khuyen was engaged, but then discovered that Mui was very attractive after getting dressed. He fell in love with her and then broke up with her boyfriend? and he married Mui. This film shows the difference between a traditional Vietnamese family and a modern Western family. Not only the environment of life has a great difference, but also the perception of relationships."
