b'In general, I do not use the space provided for product reviews to comment on the condition of a particular piece of merchandise, or draw attention to a buyer who is not reputable. In this case, however, I will make an exception. The DVD that I received today, sold through Amazon LLC, which appears as `` Passport to Pimlico \'\' (Remastered Edition), is obviously a work done at home. The outer label is a color photocopy, the one on the DVD is black and white, for God\'s sake. Turn the DVD over and you can clearly see the band that makes the home recording on a recordable DVD. The manufacturer, A2ZCDs, seems to be a professional team, with a significant catalog, a nice website, etc. But I\'m not sure why this sale was not included in the list as coming from an external provider. (At least it comes from Amazon and makes it easier to go back). But what is more important, is not DVD home production just, well, illegal? Is not that piracy? My guess when I read the word `` remastered \'\' is that the print is made of an existing negative, or was significantly cleaned; I certainly hope that the studio, the filmmakers or at least the film historians have something to do with the production of the album. Maybe the one that runs A2ZCDs has done such a job on the home computer, but this is no excuse to cheat the general public.It might be that I\'m out of place and that the copyright in `` Passport to Pimlico \'\' ran years ago Maybe nobody owns the film and we all have so much right to photocopy it and sell it as the next guy. If so, my (saved) apologies to A2ZCDs. However, I believe that buyers should be aware that they are not receiving merchandise that somehow reflects what most of us who collect movies have come to think of as "remastered" or even professionally produced. I have a Panasonic DVD recorder and I make my own movie DVDs that I recorded on TMC video. In my wildest dreams, however, it would never occur to me to sell them. Maybe that makes me an idiot. If so, at least I\'m honest.'

b"This 1955 release is one of those smaller films by Akira Kurosawa that is overlooked in favor of his larger films like & quot; Rashomon & quot; and & quot; Seven samurai & quot; but it's still worth seeing. The great Toshiro Mifune plays an industrialist in post-World War II Japan, who is slowly going crazy with the idea that a nuclear war is looming and tries to convince his family (and his lovers) to flee from Japan with him. Mifune's obsessive image is a great tragedy, especially when he vainly begs his greedy family to leave and Takashi Shimura, the samurai leader on & quot; Seven samurai & quot; , is also effective as a counselor who tries to help straighten out the disaster. The film captures the Japanese fear of the atomic bomb, a theme that Kurosawa would also address in his masterpiece, & quot; Ikiru & quot; , very well and with the greedy family approaching a delirious patriarch, brings to mind & quot; King Lear & quot; , a story that the director would return years later in & quot; Ran & quot; . This is a small movie by one of the best directors in the world but very good."

b'I had been anxious to see this film version of H.G. Wells\' classic novel, as the producers claimed that they would remain true to the original location and period of late Victorian Britain. Initially, I had been delayed in purchasing this film since its original release in 2005 due to the initial and significant amount of complaints. of low production values, poor effects, below-average performance and "endless walking scenes". Suffice it to say that my passion for the novel and the courisity took hold of me and I had to watch this movie on my own. Basically I was aware of the shortcomings and had no high expectations of production, therefore, I can say in all honestly, I enjoyed the film despite the flaws that are too numerous to list here and that have already been addressed by reviewers a lot. more eloquent than me. The editing of scenes and events would confuse a viewer who has not read the original novel and would soon lose the plot when the film changes between the scenes of the narrator in Woking and his brother in London. At one particular moment, the brother is supposedly on a London street and suddenly witnesses the attack on the Elfinstone ladies on a country road and runs to his rescue. Mario\'s red grass appears right after the attack on Woking and Shepperton without explanation within the film at any time as to what it really is. Much has been said of the encounter between HMS Thunderchild and the Martians when the brother escapes from England in a `` steamboat \'\', suffice it to say that it is really horrible and it would have been better to have been omitted altogether. There is a much-anticipated scene in which the legs of a tripod move towards and over an artillery battery, which is probably the best effect within this film and shows what could have been. Act? There is a really horrible dialogue between the characters. I challenge anyone, for example, not to end up shrinking when they see the exchange between the Elfinstone ladies and the brother as they "discuss" how they are going to escape from England. He would also award the James Doohan Award for the worst Scottish accent seen in the film since Brigadoon when the narrator converses with a soldier on Horsell Common. In contrast, when he observes the interaction with the actors trapped in the ruined house, and also the meeting of the narrator of the dead woman in a street of "London", he regrettably recalls what could have been. I gave him this. 2 star movie that is generous and for the following reasons. The score of the music is fantastic. It is refreshing that the film is true to the events of the book and has strived, albeit wrongly, to establish the book in Victorian England and not yet another updated version in the United States. Unfortunately due to cost constraints, British-style buildings are digitized and configured Monty Python style within a field in the state of Washington to represent Woking, Shepperton or London. I liked the design of the combat machines, also the manipulators in the pit scenes. Especially My 17-year-old daughter who saw this movie was not impressed at all, but was intrigued with the location and location of the films. As a result, he has endeavored to read the novel and, to my surprise, read it from beginning to end. The irony is that H.G Wells has won another young admirer despite the very poor quality of this film and for this I am really grateful. However, would you recommend this movie to a friend? Unfortunately, not if I wanted them to remain friends.'

b'Anyone who is reading these reviews will have seen the production of TV and will know it closely; therefore, I will limit my review to the quality of the DVD image, or rather, the lack of it. It is a pity that what used to be a beautiful and memorable television movie has become a battered and vanished shadow of his former self. It is painful to see that something that has a special place in your heart is treated with such misery. For years, the only version that millions of people had seen on television had a faded color and a contrast so low that it almost seemed shot in black and white. If that is what you are used to, & quot; restored & quot; The version of this DVD (and the one shown on TV for the last 3 or 4 years) looks marginally better, but is barely restored. You just have to look at a deleted song in the extras section to see how beautiful and bright the original production was: crisp, clear, pristine, with highly saturated colors. The time and money SHOULD have been spent to bring the rest of the film to this standard. It is morally wrong to put a defective product on the market, then have the courage to collect money for it. As many of our parents probably told us when we were young, & quot; Everything worthwhile is worth it! & quot;'

b'THEY COME EARLY IN THE MORNING. Have you ever seen a movie and thought after \'\' that man is real \'\', but not as a documentary, but simply as a piece of cinema that seems taken out of real life? If you have ever felt this way, chances are you were seeing this right here. `\'Eat Early Morning \'\' is a wonderful little movie made wonderfully by Joey Lauren Adams from` `Chasing Amy \'\' and starring the great Ashley Judd and, of course, Jeffrey Donovan. Honestly, it seems that the cameras were installed throughout the city and this is what was captured, it feels real. The film follows Lucy Fowler {Judd} on her journey through her thirties waking up each morning with one useless guy after another. She is also dealing with a father with whom she is desperately trying to pass the time even if it seems that he does not care. The story says that she is a desperate and confused woman who only seeks love and acceptance. Of course, you could say that her problems with men are due to her estranged relationship with her father. Still, he ends up meeting at least one decent guy named Cal Percell (played excellently by Donovan) who seems to want a relationship with her despite her problem. This is the relationship here that is the driving force of the movie, although the time spent with his father and roommate also adds an interesting dynamic. The best of all this is how everything ends. Screenwriter / director Adams shows that all the time he spent with Kevin Smith was worth it because it\'s a wonderful debut movie. His address is excellent, but it is his writing that really makes this movie so good. Like I said, this has to be one of the most real movies I\'ve seen in a long time. I like the fact that it did not romanticize the main character and his problems, things do not end up as you want. This movie has an ending that is probably what will really happen, how good is that? Even those who have not grown up in a small town can relate to the things that happen in this movie. Ashley Judd is of course brilliant as the lost thirty-year-old trying to find her way. And you know that Jeffery Donovan is excellent as the boy that should have been for her. Laura Prepon of the fame of "That\'s 70\'s Show" is as good as Judd\'s roommate and best friend, she even finds love. Scott Wilson is also brilliant because she finds her father in the religion who seems to be as out of touch as she is. As a matter of fact, the entire cast is excellent and deserves all the credit in the world. Apart from that, the film was also filmed very well and for such a limited budget it seems that the film showed the whole city, although it was not like that. I would have to say that this is one of the best films that has come out in a while, and a wonderful debut for a filmmaker. For those who seem to have this, I say spread the word and review it now. And for those who have not yet seen, I recommend this as a purchase, but I guess you can try to rent it. This is a wonderful movie with a great cast with real problems that everyone should be able to relate to. I would love to go on this movie, but all you can imagine is to see it, if it\'s not your thing, it\'s fine, but for those who like this kind of movies you will enjoy this a lot.'

b'I was waiting so long to get this movie remastered on DVD. Here it is. Danny Kaye is a talented singer and actor and this movie is great for him. The court jester is also very good and obligatory for all who liked Merry Andrew. I am a big fan of the circus and also a circus artist. the film shows what a true circus is about. It is not a circus factory like today, it is not a family tradition. Colorful and fun!'

b'The Banks family needs a new nanny for Jane and Michael. Fortunately, one arrives at the wind in the form of Mary Poppins. She is everything the children want, fun and magical. But while he takes them to chalk painting countryside and tea parties on the roof, his father is less happy. Can he be seen beyond the tip of his nose? Ok, then this movie is really little more than an excuse for the singing and dancing numbers. It\'s still great! The plot is very thin, and you lose your place in the middle of some of its fantastic scenes. Of course, part of that is because the film is based on a book that is nothing more than short stories. This movie is still more about fun than anything else. And he has that in spades. What child would not have fun imagining that they would do all the things that Jane and Michael do in this movie? It is said that Walt Disney poured everything he had learned to make this film, and it shows. Many of the special effects are remarkably well maintained today. There were some that I had not discovered until I saw this special edition. And music! Any Disney fan knows these songs by heart. And you can not help but find yourself humming "A Spoonful of Sugar", "Jolly Holiday", "Let\'s fly a kite" or "Chim Chim Cher-ee" for days after seeing it. Those who want to have a great DVD of this movie will not be disappointed in this two-disc game. Disc one presents the film in all its widescreen splendor. I can not see how it looks better. The soundtrack has many different options, but the Home Theater mix will leave you in awe. It\'s fantastic . There is also a comment track with Julie Andrews, Dick van Dyke, Karen Dubice (Jane) and Richard Sherman. The comments of others are sprayed, including Disney itself. Also included are some emerging facts to read along with while watching the movie. Disc two features a new documentary about the film, a deleted song and more about music with Julie, Dick and the composers. And make sure you watch the animated film "The Cat that Looked at a King," a story adapted from one of the later books in the series. One thing that comes loud and clear in this set is the fun that everyone had. doing it and how much they respect Walt Disney. The fact that this film has lasted 40 years is testimony to his genius. With this set, it will be enjoyed by future generations.'

b"I would not go as far as the previous critic by saying it is a kind of liberal conspiracy movie (and if it is, I'd hate to hear what people say about films like Ferngully and Once Upon A Forest). I doubt that the fact that most humans care little for our impact on the environment is a notorious news for anyone, not the fact that some of us kill other living creatures for a number of reasons ranging from fun to reality. Having said that, however, I can not give this movie a better rating. The CG animation is of a quality * much * inferior to the one made by the cover (more in line with a Saturday morning caricature than a real length film). I do not think I found a single funny joke in the whole movie, and more than a few scenes were so rude that I preferred to look the other way instead of seeing them. The images are often dark and untraining (the woman who tries to decapitate a cat with a chainsaw comes to mind), and the outdoor scenes look very easy. The animation has several parts that are notoriously poor compared to a good (or even decent) CG movie. In addition, humans are distorted almost beyond recognition. In summary, there are many good CG titles, but this certainly is not one of them."

b'This movie begins with a simple question from Richard Lobb of the National Chicken Council: `` Somehow, we are not producing chickens, we are producing food. What it does is produce a large amount of food in a small amount of space at a very affordable price. Let someone explain to me what happens with that. "Well, this movie explains very well what\'s wrong with that, the first point is that it\'s not good to treat animals as if they were mere objects. * You\'ll see chickens and calves up to their knees in their own droppings. in their cages, unable to carry even their own weight.The animals are kept in the dark all the time, even for us.It was very difficult for the filmmakers to obtain some images from inside the chicken houses.The second point, linked in a way to the previous one, is that our food can be easily contaminated with E-coli, due to animal excrement, continue with your skin.This is how food poisoning can occur in the slaughterhouse.Barbara Kowalcyk, mother of a child of 2.5 years, lived the most horrible experience that anyone can suffer: the death of his son ... The reason: eat a ... hamburger ... `` We trust that our government will be protected, but it is not We are being protected at the most basic level, "she says. This is not an uncomfortable truth, although this film was produced by the same company that brought us the documentary with the same title. This is an ugly truth. Can we do something about it? Absolutely `` You can change the world, with every bite. \'\' Change to organic It would be even better to connect again with the source of your food, what you are eating, what you are putting in your mouth! The best thing to do is to get involved with a local farmer you know and can trust.'

b'Alfred Hitchcock\'s Spellbound Criterion release has a small flaw. At 74 minutes of the movie, we have a picture of J.B. (Gregory Peck) holding a razor blade, while we hear the line of Brulov (Michael Checkov) "Are you, Mr. Brown?" Then we cut off Brulov for his next line "Oh, I thought it was you. Well, the Criterion DVD cuts the razor blade too soon, and then has the recording of Brulov speaking his second line, while overwriting his! S t! Then we get the 2nd line appropriately.In other words, the video of Brulov\'s line "Oh, I thought it was you" is spliced \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8btwice! So far I do not know if the Criterion disk is the only affected version If you do not mind the problem, then the Spellbound version of Criterion is the version to compile (great extras and image quality) And if you can still find it somewhere (since it is now sold out) do not hesitate to buy it, it is still a very good disc and those extras really make this DVD a real article of collection. throw away that old VHS tape!'

b'I love the Murder She Write Series and I anticipated the launch of the program on DVD. I have both Season 1 and Season 2. I love watching the episodes, but I am very disappointed with the quality of the DVDs. I understand that it does not happen with every DVD set, but many of the sets (including mine) have DVDs that skip and stop. I have to skip entire chapters of the shows just to get to the next episode. The problem is using both sides of the DVD to store the episodes. If some research was done on the two-sided DVDs before presenting this wonderful show in the most economical two-sided format, then we would not have so many DVD sets skipping. I really wish they had gone for the best quality route and not for the cheapest route.'

b'The Sons of Paradise by Marcel Carne is successful on so many levels that they deserve to be called one of the best films of all time. Carne filmed the film in parts during the Nazi occupation of Paris. His film was officially supported despite the occupation, since the Nazis wanted to show that they were friendly with the arts. This created the ironic situation in which Carne was taking money from the government to support a daytime film and channel aid to the French resistance at night. An actor was supposed to be a Nazi collaborator. He disappeared mysteriously during the filming and had to be replaced. Despite all these obstacles, Carne has managed to recreate magnificently Paris of the nineteenth century. In this way, the film itself is a triumph of the creative spirit. The title refers to the poor, who could only afford such high seats in the theater that they were almost in the beams ... and yet these were the real audiences. the actors showed up for. The story is a series of crossed lives that revolve in one way or another around the bohemian and tired Garance (played Mona Lisa style by Arletty). Beyond this, the film also revolves around the theater life of 1840 in Paris: the actors, the public and everyone in between. Garance is almost a courtesan: she conveniently moves between four men who love her, apparently unaffected by any of them ... in the end, she falls in love with the mime Baptiste (Jean-Louis Barrault) ... but Baptiste is married to another woman after losing her chance with Garance years before. Will they come together? In the end, we, the spectators are both the Sons of the Gods, or the Sons of Paradise, that the title refers to the theater audience in the film. In fact, both opening and closing credits are played against a theater curtain. We are the spectators in the Gods, and the actors are performing for us living their lives: loving, living, dying ... feeling pain and joy. The Meat movie lasts more than three hours, but it never gets delayed. The stories cross each other and can not be adequately described in a simple review like this ... Four men love Garance, and somehow all their lives intersect in and around the theater. The cinematography is incredible. There is a crowd scene at the end of the film that resists anything filmed: it is simply magnificent. Baptiste is lost (in many ways) in a moving mass of humanity. This single scene is reason enough to see the movie. I suspect that this is a movie that people love or hate. Long duration can discourage many people, but it is a pity. The movie is not for those who want instant gratification. Instead, it is something to enjoy and savor. If all this makes it seem too serious, rest assured that it is not. Children of Paradise is a tragedy in some aspects, but it is also a comedy in the sense of Shakespeare. This was a movie made for a company like Criterion, and they do it justice in their DVD edition. The two halves of the film are presented on individual discs, so the film never suffers compression failures or other problems. The restoration is perfect: you never know that this movie is almost sixty years old. The audio is cute but very clean, without whistling or static. Criterion has also included some supplements, interviews, filmographies, trailers, etc., but the real pleasure is the film itself. It is timeless'

b'I want to start by saying that this is the best Blu Ray release that I have bought to date. The packaging is wonderful, with its hard cover "souvenir" aesthetic, and the additional bonus features alone make it worth the low price they ask for. See the actual footage of Linda Blair (with all the makeup no less) on the set is priceless and definitely outperforms the extras from previous releases. As for the important things ... THE MOVIE. I have to say that this has become my favorite movie of all time. I am not in any way a fan of terror. I have some favorites of the genre ... but I opt more for comedy and / or fantasy. I like to laugh or get away from reality completely. Questions: "So why in EARTH would you consider The Exorcist as your favorite movie?" "Simple.It\'s a modern parable and it\'s one of those rare movies that really produces the desired effect in every frame." `The Exorcist "Like a horror movie, it\'s a bit short-sighted." It\'s a spiritual drama, a psychological thriller, and a supernatural story ... all in one.37 years later, it\'s still valid and as relevant today as it was then. The difference here is that we now live in a society that is, as Blatty says in the documentary Fear Of God `` completely jaded and depraved. \'\' Nothing here seems to shock and 14-year-olds now see this movie as "laughable." It\'s a shame, because there\'s so much more than pea soup and rotating heads here, it\'s really about the terror of the unknown ... the fear and the restlessness that all metaphysical and spiritual things imply, it\'s about the mystery of faith and its capacity ad to ultimately triumph. The sights, the sounds and the history ... they all mix here. It is incredibly well written by Blatty. Friedkin\'s sense of documentary realism serves the plot well. The performance is first class by a cast that could not have been more perfect. The makeup of Dick Smith is innovative, not only with Linda Blair, but with Max Von Sydow, who was between 40 and 40 years old at that time. Also worthy of mention is Owen Roizman\'s use of various clear textures and, of course, his masterful and iconic image of Merrin\'s arrival. I was fortunate to see the screening of Fathom on September 30 and, seeing this movie on a big screen with digital sound was fantastic, I have yet to say that it works better and provides more disconcerting feelings when you look at home ... in the darkness. That\'s the really scary angle in this movie ... it reminds us that no matter how safe we \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bthink we are (even in our own home with all the lights on), there\'s nothing the real evil does not do and nowhere go to manifest.'

b"Let me start by saying that I love & quot; Oh My Goddess & quot; and I was really looking forward to the DVD release of the series. It's very sweet, fun and easily one of the most charmingly romantic series I've seen. I am very happy to spend some time with Belldandy, Keichi, Skuld and Urd. Having said that, I am impressed and disappointed to discover that they divided the series into two DVDs, each one for sale separately. The episodes are very short, totaling a little over an hour per DVD (I think it's 82 minutes for Vol. 1, and 62 minutes for Vol. 2). There are no additional features included. Oh! That's a lot for two and a half hours of viewing. I find it hard to believe that Animego could not do more justice to this excellent series, or provide more value to its customers. The six parts & quot; Moldiver & quot; OAV managed to find its way on a DVD at a good price. How disappointing is that & quot; Oh My Goddess & quot; I could not do the same. I am sad to say that this is an excellent series to rent (but not to buy)."

b'Maduro is not an exploitative Lolita sex movie as super-saturated art might suggest. Instead, it is a challenging and unconventional exploration of female sexuality and maturity, imaginatively directed and well acted by its three clues. The script sometimes becomes rudimentary like many indie movies (too many bad words are a curse in independent scripts), but the film is visually stunning, and the accumulation of small moments is delicious, when Violet discovers adult magazines, for example , or when the abrupt man who takes the sisters has to explain the menstruation. And the final scene with the two sisters is devastating, a strange amalgam of suspense, family drama and psychosexual connotations. A wonderful musical score by Anton Sanko (ex-Suzanne Vega Band) increases this aesthetically excellent film, curiously moving and finally very dark. .'

b'The Iron Giant is a loose adaptation of a wonderful book of the same title, by Ted Hughes (written in the late sixties). In the book, the origins of the giant are unknown, and he is initially buried under the ground before being attacked and, finally, befriended. The enemy in the book, which becomes a common enemy for both humans and the giant and the cause of their alliance, was a giant dragon-like creature (as big as Australia!) To which the giant ends for cheating. In the film, set during the Cold War, and presenting a wonderful portrait of the atmosphere of the 50s, the enemy is EE. UU and our tendency to fear what is strange, and shoot first and ask questions later. I think this is, in the end, deeper. Of course, the original author may have had some of those allegories in mind when he wrote the original book, since the dragon from outer space ends up destroying and enveloping a large part of the planet in darkness, almost like a world war. But in that case, is it supposed that its alliance with the giant means an alliance with military technology to prevent a world war? In the film, the robot is just a fantastic robot from outer space, which humans can choose to make friends or establish as enemies. In any case, this is easily one of the best animated films to leave the United States. States in the last decade (and one of the others is by the same director, Brad Bird).'

b"I do not remember the last time I was so entertained with a movie that I saw it three times in 24 hours. STILL CRAZY took me out of my bleak and somewhat fertile middle-aged existence and transported me back to my college years in the seventies, when I was in a part-time ragtag band. Make no mistake: the film shows the chaotic, extravagant, self-centered, authoritarian and irresistibly dysfunctional behavior of rock musicians. The antics of the characters, even in middle age, when they try to revive their careers, brought a plethora of memories. I can also remember concerts that had gone wrong; members of the band shouting chords to each other during a song; the frequent & quot; artistic & quot; disagreements; improvised impromptu sessions in barns, garages, empty rooms of the high school band; and the excitement of connecting with an audience (usually a drunken audience). Buy this movie ... rent this movie ... watch this movie. It is more than just a comedy; There is a very real human component that transcends even the tumultuous world of the music industry. You will laugh, you will remove a tear from time to time and you will be entertained. The flame still burns. God bless rock 'n roll!"

b"I have a VHS copy of ALICE IN ACIDLAND, purchased from Something Weird years ago. I'm a big fan of the 60's drug / exploitation movies and ALICE IN ACIDLAND has always been one of my favorites. Finally I upgraded to DVD and was completely disappointed. This ALICE DVD is a cut and censored version of the movie. Ten to fifteen second pieces have been raised from time to time, leaving jarring jump cuts in place. And near the end of the movie, a whole scene has been eliminated. The cut footage is all shots that contain full frontal nudity and / or the most brutal violence. The cuts are obvious; no attempt was made to make them flow with the movie ... the narration of the music and the voiceover cut clumsily with each instance of clipping footage. The runtime information in the box is even incorrect ... in the box, the original ALICE runtime appears in the list: 62 minutes. But the DVD version only has 53 minutes with all the cuts. I've been an admirer of Something Weird for years ... But now I'm disappointed with the company. They used to be a refuge for unfiltered exploitation, without PC, totally obscene, horrifying, psychedelic and just a completely strange cinema ... things that the masses would not care about. So, why CUT a movie to (supposedly) attract the masses? ? ? I hesitate before buying another DVD Something Weird. I give this DVD 2 stars instead of one because the other material on this DVD is pretty good. But I do not think this DVD is worth your money."

You do not have to be a Simpson-type comic to point out what\'s wrong with that. I do not know how many comics Bryan Singer has read, but when Superman is exposed to even a small amount of kryptonite, he barely has the strength to stay on his feet. That is no more absurd than taking it to a continent of kryptonite in space and then falling powerless through the atmosphere without burning in the reentry or splashing the entire central park when it falls to the ground. \'\' I need to say more? I do not think so. ** [...]'

b'I was surprised that the editorial revisions of this film treated it like one more movie, which is definitely NOT. I would describe it in several ways: like the film that John Waters would give his left hand to make; as a shipment NEAR dramatic, intense, tear-filled dance films such as Red Shoes, which takes off its hat at the concept of `` camp \'\' without throwing away all the experience to maintain consistency with attitude; like a comedy that, if you understand the joke, will leave you speechless with laughter at times. There are times when I was not sure of the movie I was in, like the plot listed for Flashdance and then Cinderella. But this is the kind of movie that it is; it embraces operatic emotion and high melodrama, and while it recognizes the ordinary, it never is. And it communicates wonderfully the essential madness of all inclusive endogamic subcultures. (The constant exhortations of the old guard to the hero not to indulge in "movements that please the crowd") are hilariously absurd, and at the same time totally typical of such subcultures, where the most sensible question is always "Who? the earth, these rules?! `) is a strange and intense film, which keeps you unconsciously out of balance, and asks you if you take it seriously or as an elaborate dream of filmed comedy (think of Rocky Horror Picture Show). good is that you never have to decide, you can enjoy new aspects in multiple visualizations.'

b"Ridley Scott's Alien must be considered one of the best thrillers ever put on celluloid. It is classified there with films like Hitchcock 's Psycho and Tod Browning' s Dracula (1931). Alien is more or less a classic movie of the haunted house, but instead of an old tenebrous Victorian manor house, we have an old, lugubrious and massive space freighter and the endless darkness of space itself. Alien exceeds her B movie credentials - this film is really a B movie in the background - with a very tense and intelligent script, and an exceptional direction from Ridley Scott. From the long opening sequence of the Nostromo that fills the screen, the audience knows that it will be treated with an exceptionally filmed film. Ridley Scott has always been known for his artistic direction and the biomechanical aspect of Alien sets helps to increase the sensation of terror and terror. Help Scott and his team decide to hire the famous Swiss surrealist H.R. Giger to design the look of the sets and the creatures. Anyone who has seen Giger's work can easily see its influence on the stage design for Alien. The final design of Giger for the main creature will become one of the best creations in the history of cinema. For now, everyone knows what to imagine in their heads when someone mentions the words Alien and they film together. The group of actors chosen for the film is excellent from top to bottom. The captain of Tom Skerritt. Dallas is a solid base on which the rest of the characters revolve. The slow decline of Veronica Cartwright's personality to hysteria - totally appropriate to the situation she and the rest of her classmates face - is like a barometer of the growing fear that permeates the film from beginning to end. The standout of the cast must be Sigourney Weaver. The fact that this was her first important role in the cinema is a good omen of what the public could expect from her when her career exploded. His character from Lieutenant Ellen Ripley is more or less the antithesis of Lambert de Cartwright. While Lambert slowly descended to a paralyzing hysteria, Ripley took control of the situation and became the de facto leader after Dallas. The overall tone of the film owes much to the past: terror / sci-fi thrillers. But instead of constant scares and false leads, Scott slowly increased the tension and fear with slow slow taps of empty hallways and cargo holds. For a movie that is considered one of the best horror movies ever made, Alien does not have many dark areas where the monster suddenly jumps. The monster will leave well lit and spacious areas. Scott also used the Spielberg trick to prevent the monstrous creature from appearing on the screen for more than a few moments. It is not until the end when we see the alien creature of Giger in all its splendor. This new version of the many editions of Alien DVD has finally arrived with re-edited scenes that add more impact and horror to the film. I have to agree with Scott's reasoning to eliminate the scenes themselves. It reduces the speed of the roller coaster, constant rhythm in the last part of the film. But in the comfort of the home theater itself, these re-edited scenes are easier to assimilate. The look of the cut of the original and theatrical film has been remastered and it looks great, especially when seen on a DVD player with progressive scanning capability and a dedicated panoramic HDTV. Sound and music also received a 4-star remastering treatment to make better use of home theater systems that grow in number. Alien is the most superior entry in Alien Quadrilogy, even though Aliens is a more exciting movie. Alien takes the genre of science fiction horror and sets a standard that many have yet to achieve to this day."

b'Yes, I am using all the Interjections of SchoolHouse Rock to sing your praises. I grew up with Schoolhouse Rock, but to be honest, I thought about it only when my husband and I laughed nostalgically at memorable songs like Conjunction Junction. Then, she bought our daughter\'s 30th anniversary edition (she was trying to qualify for free shipping when she bought the Belleville Tripletts!). My 3-year-old son LOVES it, and I can not say enough good things about the creative letters that teach grammar, numbers and how the body works (maybe I should stick my hand in my bag of adjectives, which my daughter calls charmingly "magictivos"). \'\'). It is the only DVD that we have that I do not feel any apprehension about evil or terrifying characters, dark plots or questionable influences (which are surprising in many videos for preschoolers). If you wonder about how to get this video, do not hesitate. It is a timeless winner that will not disappoint (unless you are looking for dark plots and questionable character influences).'

b'Good video, it has a good configuration, that is. battles before Guadalcanal. It covers all the naval battles around the island, island of Salvo, etc. It covers the air force of Cactus and its aerial battles.'

b"The last robbery of a professional thief and his team goes terribly wrong, and the organizer of impeccable plans receives more than he expected. The agents and the mobsters chase him, but he remains calm under pressure, frustrates the plans of others and can always get out of the mud. This is a standard story format for the action movie. It looks clich and eacute; d and predictable, but it works well with good pace in action and with the director's safe guidance. But `` 7 Seconds '' does not have them. Wesley Snipes plays the thief named Jack. Jack's failed robbery in Bucharest, Romania, leads to a new problem because his girlfriend / partner in crime is kidnapped during the shootings. He takes a NATO military policeman (Tamzin Outhwaite wearing his British accent) hostage after the chaos (and also saves his life), and gets involved in the pursuit of urban cars with familiar surroundings. The story does not make much sense (why steal casinos' money in Romania?), But the earlier part of `` 7 Seconds' 'is fun, with decent acrobatics and a bit of humor. The actions are confusing and you do not know where these cars are running wildly, but at least the acrobatics are not bad. Then, in the tedium of the central section of the film settles, which stops the actions and begins to introduce superfluous characters, plus an unnecessary twist of the plot or two. We do not need to see Wesley Snipes walking in the station and placing a wallet in the coin locker there. Or, in reality, we do not care what the briefcase really contains; and we do not even want to know if something in it (whatever it is) is real or not. We want emotion and action, or fun dialogues. Except for some short acrobatics of martial arts and mildly fun jokes between Snipes and Outhwaite, `` 7 Seconds '' does not have much to show, particularly in its second part, where the film has another sequence of doubles involving trams, but it is marked by a choppy edition. We often hear complaints or criticisms about direct movies to video, but in reality some of them are quite good, offering fun 90 minutes like the films of Jean-Claude Van Damme and Dolph Lundgren. Unfortunately, for all the pretty good acting of the stars, `` 7 seconds '' of Wesley Snipes is not one of them."

b"The Crucible, based on the work of Arthur Miller, is an entertaining, though not always accurate, version of the events at 1692 Salem Village. After having read numerous books on the subject, I still can not say with certainty what it was that led to the events that so many men and women were accused of witchcraft and that so many young people seemed distressed. One may wonder why it was only the Salem 's females, and not the men who seemed afflicted with screams, catatonic states, hallucinations, etc ... In any case, a conclusion that could not be drawn was that of a woman scorned, in this case Abigail Williams played by Winona Ryder whose advances are rejected by the married John Proctor (Daniel Day Lewis). The Proctors are also much younger in the movie than in real life. John was sixty years old when he was hanged. Elizabeth would be around 40 years old at the time of testing. The pregnancy saved her from the hangman's rope. The film maintains a good dose of precision in the treatment of the slave Tituba and his part in the whole affair, as well as the accusations against some of the `` creators of problems '' of the city. like Goody Nurse and Giles Corey who was pressured to death for refusing to testify. The scenes in the audience room were the most dynamic and exciting, and reminded those vintage paintings of ancient books that represented the trials with severe judges and Puritans who pointed fingers at the accusers. The film also did a good job of capturing that stifling 17th century, repressive environment and costumes was the first rate.The best performances for me came from those men who portray the various ministers and judges, especially Bruce Davison as the Reverend Parris and Paul Scofield as Judge Danforth. Although it is not a completely accurate movie, it continues to do a good job of capturing one of the most important events in early American history. Reviewed by Tim Janson"

b'This film starts fast and quickly immerses the viewer in a very strange world with dialogue and action that burns making it difficult to keep up. The important thing is to stay there and the pieces will begin to fit together. The film is based on a novel by Philip K. Dick who is known for his very original imagination and who has contributed ideas for different stories to anyone else. This is another one of those original stories and takes the viewer to an unbridled journey. Fortunately the pieces begin to fit together and do so with the dramatic use of surround speakers and lots of action on the screen. The basic premise of the film is that a technology has been developed that allows you to see a crime before it actually happens, so that the police can intervene and stop the crime before it has taken place. Just as this system of crime prevention is ready to go to the whole country, something happens that changes everything. The character of Tom Cruise, a policeman named John Anderton, suddenly finds himself plunged into a situation that threatens his own life. Now you must use the crime prevention system called Precrime to discover the truth and find out who is willing to incriminate you. Your search for the truth provides the basis for this exciting action movie. I urge the viewer to give the film a chance because, although at first it may seem confusing, it quickly becomes a good science fiction adventure movie.'

b'Some people in Germany have accused this film of trying to "render harmless" the crimes of the Third Reich. This could not be further from the truth, and I will explain why. Bruno Ganz interprets Hitler as the man. Hitler, the man who loves his dog, who is kind to his secretary, who loves his friends and spits at people who think he is betrayed, who tells those he cares to save himself even as he prepares to take cyanide, commit suicide and then be burned This is a guy that, while he is not talking about the Jews or world domination, it would not be so difficult to live with him. HOWEVER, this is still Hitler\'s monster. Being a vegetarian does not absolve him of being directly responsible for the death of millions or of throwing the whole world into war. Hitler, the two-dimensional monster, is inseparable from Hitler, the three-dimensional man, and that\'s what this film reminds us every time it makes you feel sorry for him even if you know, and the movie reminds you that he was a monster. All the monsters in history - past, present and future - were, are and will be human beings. We like to imagine Hitler as a kind of inhuman monster, but he was only human. Too human. That\'s why this movie makes people feel uncomfortable; Reminds them that any "man who looks like a good partner" leader of men could turn out to be a monster if the right questions are never asked or the ideas are never questioned. The warning is uncomfortable: no ideologist can be trusted at face value. Not one, never. And / that / is the true importance of this film, if `` Never again \'\' is to have some kind of real that is, next to a slogan. If I were a history teacher, I would show this movie followed by / Schindler\'s List /. Both are equally true, and equally important in history: all this horror comes from simple humans.'

b"I have been and continue to be a faithful admirer of Xena and Gabrielle. Let me remind you of those who liked the end of something. Real life is full of sadness, misery, loss and tragedy. I think it's very unpleasant, very tragic and pathetic that Xena has had to die. And if dying was not enough, decapitating her made my stomach churn. I own the whole series. b'Director Jon Reiss and producer Tracy Wares take us on a graffiti world tour in `` Bomb It \'\'. The film is more favorable to the art of graffiti than against it, but interviews people whose mission is to free neighborhoods of graffiti and graffiti artists on 4 continents. There is a background that questions who should decide what we look at in public spaces, a provocative question but that is not really the focus of the film. `` Bomb It \'\' covers a lot of ground in the history and scope of graffiti art, but with good results, since we can see that graffiti artists are not all the same. Graffiti has evolved over time, and its purpose is different in different cultures and subcultures. `` Bomb It \'\' begins by interviewing Cornbread, a Philadelphian whose campaign to label everything with his nickname in 1967 could make him the first modern graffiti artist. The film avoids the debate of who did the former, but follows the progression from simple labeling to more elaborate lyrics that led to the transformation of graffiti from a lower class counterculture movement to one that encompasses a broader artistic movement. New York graffiti artists in the seventies and eighties talk about their exploits before the city began aggressively cleaning up graffiti on public property. Other cities whose artists present themselves are: Paris, France; Amsterdam, The Netherlands; London, United Kingdom ; Berlin Germany ; Barcelona, \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bSpain; Cape Town, South Africa; S\xc3\xa3o Paulo, Brazil; Tokyo Japan ; and Los Angeles, USA UU I have always thought of graffiti as a means of frustrated, energetic, but mostly irresponsible youth, attacking what they perceive as the status quo. Now I learned that graffiti has a different meaning in different cultures. In South Africa, graffiti was a tool for political change. In Los Angeles, he has been part of the Chicano movement and has adopted the trap of a lifestyle in some neighborhoods. In some cultures, the emphasis is more on placing works of art in public spaces than in countercultures. It is not surprising that these artists have a less conflictive relationship with communities and the law. The fact is that graffiti and vandalism have a profound effect on the rate of more serious crimes. And many of the artists interviewed consider themselves extremely important people who inflict their fright on others because their lives are not what they would like. On the other hand, it can not be denied that graffiti is sometimes an improvement over monotonous and decaying buildings, or that artists are talented, or that some of the graffiti opponents are politically Philistine. `` Bomb It \'\' provides an introduction to graffiti and its controversies by showing us art, ideas and differences of opinion. The DVD (Docurama 2008): there are 3 functions and a comment. In `` Behind the Scenes \'\' (14 min), the director Jon Reiss talks about the genesis of the project, the shooting in different nations, the editing of the film and some themes. `` Long time lapse sequences \'\' (15 min) are 3 sequences, 5 minutes each in England, Brazil and Japan, where we can see the creation of the artwork in accelerated time. There are also "Extended interviews" (26 min). The audio commentary of director Jon Reiss and producer Tracy Wares is constant and informative. They talk about what they did and did not include in the film, their intentions and more details about who and what we are seeing.'

b"Well, if you have not seen this, something great awaits you. This is one of the funniest movies ever made, certainly abbot and costello, and that's no small thing. But he also has Bela Lugosi and Lon Chaney Jr., both in the roles that made them famous, and both playing totally direct, which is one of the things that makes it so classic. This is the original classic that has inspired HUNDREDS of imitations, from Bowery Boys to scooby-doo. This is terror / comedy in its heyday: you can not do better. It is a fact that the legendary rock guitarist, Jerry Garcia, considered that this was his favorite movie of all time (seriously) and for very good reasons. For the atmosphere, the monsters of classic movies and hilarity, this movie is the best of all. It really deserves six stars, but you can only give five. It's the terror / comedy Casablanca. Often imitated, never duplicated."

b'This is a sequel very well made and very well filmed. The opening sequence and the sequences with snipers firing indiscriminately at the fleeing crowd were very memorable and well executed. However, he was completely upset about how simple it was for the father to access his wife, who was supposed to be in some kind of quarantine. I know there are often flaws in logic and suspensions of disbelief in many movies and I am guilty of succumbing to some of them. But this for me was very evident. To shout out loud, or the US Army. Instead, the installation was deserted. It was too simple for the father to access her with a pass card or not. If it is still found that a person is alive 28 weeks later without symptoms in a quarantined area in the real world, that person would be locked up and monitored 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, if not weeks, because they want to know how she survived and how she was "immune" to this virus. Those precautions would never be taken so lightly, especially when it comes to a virus that almost annihilates an entire country! If they did not have strict protocols, we would have disappeared as a race a long time ago. The suspension of disbelief in this movie really prevented me from enjoying a fairly well made movie.'

b'... first, I was looking for a DVD that would give me useful instructions on how to perform certain poses to finally reduce my neck / shoulder pain. b'I bought this DVD because I was impressed by Ghislaine Thesmar\'s commentary on the documentary `` Etoiles \'\' about the Paris Opera Ballet, but I had never seen her dance. I\'m still not sure I\'ve seen her dance, because there were no close-ups and the image was, as another critic noted, blurred. b'The third season had new directors and new writers. Only one episode was written by a writer who returned. This seems to have completely changed the tone of the show. The seasons one and two are science fiction, the third season seems more like Gilligan\'s Island or Lost in Space. The focus seems to be to throw out the fantastic characters that writers can think of, no matter how stupid or out of place. The third season features Medusa, a caveman, The Flying Dutchman, The Abominable Snowman, a spitting dinosaur fire, a two-headed dinosaur and a beetle whose bite makes you evil. Logic, continuity and characterization all go out the window. They speak Sleestak and Chaka, Enik does stupid things in the name of "logic". The only thing better this season is the performance. The only reason to watch this season is if you want to see all the full episodes. If you liked the first two seasons, you probably do not like this.'

b"After being disappointed by Spirited Killer, I set my expectations much lower for this movie. Unfortunately, it's even worse than Spirited Killer. The story is not worth reviewing. Basically, there's a guy who knows where a valuable stone is. An evil general and his men want the stone and are trying to get it. There is also a group of good guys trying to find the guy who knows where the stone is. That is the history. Tony Jaa plays one of the bad guys and looks great in his 2 fight scenes, but all the other fights are really bad. Some of the stunts are good, but not on par with most of Panna Rittikrai's other films. The good ones have a person of the Rambo type on their side and he drag the film because his movements are very slow. But, in general, the main reason why this movie is so bad is because there are not many fights. I can handle a bad story as long as the fights are good, but this movie does not provide that. Even the grand finale is not worth staying. There are some decent explosions, but there's nothing to get excited about. Classification: 1/5. This movie really makes you appreciate how much effort you put into Panna's 2 films Born to Fight. The quality of the images is surprisingly good (well, good for Videoasia). There is a HORRIBLE dubbing track in English, but fortunately there is also a track and subtitles in the original language. The only reason why this two-disc DVD gets more than a 1-star rating is because of the special features. Minute interview with Tony Jaa. about Tom Yum Goong. There's no new information here, but as he talks, they show a really cool demo he did on a television show. 6-minute interview with Jaa talking about his inspiration to enter movies and some other interesting topics. 10-minute interview on Thai comedies TV show with Prachya Pinkaew, Jaa, Panna and Petchtai Wongkamlao. Entertaining demonstration and 5 minute interview that Jaa did in Hong Kong. Here there are good things, but nothing that you have not seen before if you are a fan of Jaa. 22-minute interview with the producer of Pechpanna Films and a director / actor of the company. Awesome interview! They talk about great things, like a new Thai movie called The Brave. It's not subtitled and the dubbing is really cheesy, but that actually makes it more enjoyable (at least for me). And there are some good action scenes mixed in the interview. Tony Jaa interview It seems that they are just trying to accumulate the special features with this. The only thing to talk about is a 1 minute demo that they show at the end of the interview. Finally, an interview with Christoph Kluppel, a great German Rambo starring Battle Warrior. He talks about his film career. I guess this would be interesting if I were a fan of him."

b"The 1922 `` Prisoner of Zenda '' is surely one of the best silent films ever made. His main actors knew that they should not over-thrill and obviously had a very competent director in Rex Ingram. Although the plot, the costumes and the stage are taken from an operetta, the players mostly come out as natural, showing that good acting was not something that somehow arose with the advent of sound. Even Ram\xc3\xb3n Navarro as the villain Rupert of Hentzau shows himself as something more than a pretty face while turning his role into a fun and animated tour de force. The image begins in the manor of the Englishman Rudolph Rassendyll, the camera focused on the extremely beautiful eyes of Lewis Stone, now a 43-year veteran who, in most other respects, looks like a fairly ordinary middle-aged man and with a good physical condition. But, of course, there's nothing ordinary in Stone's histrionic talent and, in addition, it has all the charm that made him as beloved as Judge Hardy some 15 years later in the series `` Andy Hardy ''. Rassendyll decides to attend the coronation of his cousin, Rudolph of Ruritania, [whose twin could be] and discovers that his relative is a dissipated disaster. Lewis Stone plays both sides, needless to say. The future weak king has an ambitious but evil brother, Duke Michael, who conspires to seize the throne and kill Rudolph in the process. On the eve of the coronation, the duke arranges for his brother to be drugged so that he will not be able to attend the ceremony. Therefore, the king's loyalists persuade the British Rassendyll to take his place for a day and prevent Michael from getting away with it. The Ruritarian Rudolph has a beautiful fiancee played by the luminous Alice Terry. The couple does not have much use for each other, but she is a popular princess that would serve to reinforce the unstable position of Rudolph. However, Rassendyll and the lovely girl are taken at once and, feeling an unexpected change in their intention, the princess no longer sees her role as future queen as a mere duty. Of course, the plot is complicated and there is another woman involved, played by the seductive but less natural actress, Barbara La Marr. Rudolph Rassendyll can not return to his home in England after the coronation, but must remain to help rescue his real cousin in danger of extinction. There are also a lot of skulls and a game of swords. They are all a fascinating movie and it is a true revelation to see how effective the younger Judge Hardy's younger version is in love scenes. Pretty sexy! It is probably not accidental that the actor who played the double role in the next `` Prisoner of Zenda '', Ronald Colman, looked a lot like Lewis Stone."

b'While "Singin \'in the Rain" of 1952 is definitely the most accomplished musical film, I believe that this 1949 classic optimist is the best example of what MGM produced during the golden age of Hollywood when talents were at their peak. Co-directed by Gene Kelly and 25-year-old Stanley Donen in his film directorial debut, the film has a constant power of propulsion thanks mostly to the extraordinary choreography of Kelly and Donen, the perfect blend of Leonard Bernstein\'s family music with Oboe studio Roger Edens\' original compositions, and the sheer effervescence of the performers.Written by the estimable team of Betty Comden and Adolph Green, the threadbare plot is simply about three sailors - Gabey, Chip and Ozzie - on a 24-hour permit in New York and women who know and romance. Based on a subway poster, womanizer Gabey falls in love with Miss Turnstiles and spends her time looking for her. Ozzie, assailed by the phobia, finds romance with the anthropology student Claire, while the shy Chip focuses on sightseeing despite the persistent attention of the aggressive taxi driver Hildy. The closest thing to dramatic tension lies in the deceptions of Miss Turnstiles, who is not the big celebrity that Gabey assumes is an aspiring dancer named Ivy, who has to work at night as an exotic dancer in Coney Island. It is obviously at its best when it focuses on the musical sequences, starting with the actual locations used by `` New York, New York \'\' to establish the energetic arrival of the sailors, continuing the elaborate number \'\' Prehistoric Man \'\' . at the Natural History Museum and bouncing through the whole melody of the title with the six directors singing and dancing from the Empire State Building. Everyone has the opportunity to shine, although like Gabey, Gene Kelly clearly dominates with his athletic agility. Like Chip, an eclipsed Frank Sinatra gets mainly to sing to Betty Garrett, who admirably contains his brassiness as Hildy. Although Hardly Credible as an academic type, Ann Miller gets to play impressively during the "Prehistoric Man", and the Rubber with Jules Munshin\'s face provides greater comedy relief as Ozzie. When she dances instead of acting to fool Gabey, Vera-Ellen dazzles as Ivy, from the whimsical "Miss Turnstiles Ballet," to her superb duos with Kelly on "Main Street" and "A Day in New York Ballet." \' The only sour note is the condescending attitude towards Hildy\'s shrill, shrilly floormate, Lucy (played enthusiastically by the original Gladys Kravitz of `` Bewitched \'\', Alice Pearce). Harold Rosson\'s color-saturated cinematography has held up pretty well in the transfer of print on the 2000 DVD, although the only extra is the now battered theater trailer.'

b'My expectation for this movie was that it would be more or less a compilation and reinforcement of the information I had obtained from seeing the movie `` Fast Food Nation \'\' several years ago, and that I had just read the excellent books `` Animal, Vegetable Miracle \'\' and `` In Defense of Food \'\' among others. b'`` Elvis: that\'s how it is \'\' captures King Presley at an interesting crossroads in his career. With his true talents largely wasted after too many years in Hollywood, Elvis was usurped as the "King of Rock and Roll" by people like The Beatles and The Rolling Stones. This documentary, filmed in the summer of 1970 while preparing for a commitment at the International Hotel in Las Vegas, finds Elvis ready and in the best condition to regain his throne! The documentary shows him at age 35, fit and fit, and he has a lot of fun! Seeing Elvis having fun, that in itself is a joy! Elvis had a good sense of muscianship and his craft. I expected a lot from the people I worked with; and he knew exactly how to get the best out of everyone. Here it is obvious that Elvis loved to work with his band and backup singers; and they loved working with him. Elvis gave criticism in a smooth and funny way. When his band struggles with the middle section of `` Bridge Over Troubled Water \'\', Elvis comments: `` If it goes that way, it goes that way, but we do not have to emphasize it. "The footage of the concert itself shows that it is very possible that Elvis was the most hard-working man in the world of entertainment. It also proves that Elvis had `` that \'\' - that undefinable X Factor, often indecipherable (or in his case, factors) that marks the difference between an artist and a superstar. Elvis was a superstar with a capital "S", who possesses a powerful combination of charisma, sexual attractiveness, musical expertise and talent for the show. Elvis\' charisma, in particular, burns the stage quite a bit. Elvis does everything he can to please his audience. During a long performance of "Love Me Tender", he comes out to the audience, kissing so many women and shaking hands with as many men as possible. Sing a Greatest Medley Hits largely to laugh (changing lyrics to "forget about the past, before kicking your a # # \'\'). Halfway through the concert, Elvis has just started, presenting performances of" In The Ghetto ", "You\'ve lost that Loving Feeling" and "Polk Salad Annie." "Your extended, super-charged and sweaty version of` `Suspicious Minds \'\' will probably leave viewers as tired as Elvis at the end. As the final credits advance, we see Elvis greeting celebrities after the performance. Sammy Davis, Jr., clearly amazed, comments: "Man, you have revealed yourself and you have never stopped!" When congratulated on a wonderful show, Elvis responds modestly: "Well, it was a sweaty spectacle. \'\' The special edition DVD includes two versions, but continues with the most recent restored edition and omits the original 1970 theatrical version. The 1970 theatrical version has fantastical testimonials that are unnecessary.The restored version has more images of Elvis in action. : this is how it is "is the way Elvis should always be remembered.'

b'If you have never seen a movie, this is the one you should choose. One of the most critically acclaimed gay movies, it is a sensitive, affectionate, tender and sweet story with an excellent score by Mama Cass. The film has also been hailed as a good representation of the working class in British society. The film, directed in large part by Hettie McDonald and based on the screenplay by gay writer Jonathan Harvey, portrays the relationships of people in a large complex located in East London (he was physically there). Most of the British, working-class, low-income, the film revolves around three families, all broken houses. Ste, from a father and a family of abusive brothers; Jaime, a mother and a boyfriend\'s family; and Leah, a British black girl with her mother. The story is the development of a gay love affair between two children, Ste (played by Scott Neal) and Jaime (played by Glenn Berry). Both live side by side. Both are 16 (also in real life to maintain accuracy). It is also the story of Leah, sometimes a drug user, a problematic and abandoned teenager. She is a catalyst with her obsession with the music of Mama Cass, constantly singing her songs and making a lot of noise around the apartments. I have read messages about her in this movie chat room, without understanding why she is the movie. His character contributes to the greatness of the film. His father and brother beat him several times. He takes refuge in Jaime\'s house. Jaime\'s mother, Sandra (superbly played by Linda Henry). b'I bought this thinking that I would receive a delivery from one of my childhood favorites, Hollywood and the Stars. This is not everything. (Oh, the dangers of online shopping ...) b'`` Lost Highway \'\' is not so linear and, therefore, satisfies our narrative desire, like `` Mulholland Drive \'\' because, in fact, it seems to try too hard to be weird. But David Lynch is one of the only directors who understands how strange dream cinema can be. Like Hitchcock, exploits this situation with all its value, but in the manner of the classical surrealists, and I think that this film can be better experienced on the stage of a real theater. The terrain of this film is even more deeply unconscious than `` Mulholland Drive \'\', because its final theme seems to be the fact of seeing a narrative film in itself, channeled through a paragon of truth in our society: photos of the crime scene. This is what makes it interesting. It is so open, however, that it allows each viewer his own personal interpretation, because the "superficial plot" is mixed with his own interpretive tracks ... My opinion is that Fred Madison believes he was convicted of murdering his wife in base to the images contained in the last videotape delivered to him and to Renee (Patricia Arquette); during the first act, the most crucial line is his statement that he does not like cameras because he prefers to remember things his way, "not necessarily the way they happened". "This whole first section of the movie is the way Fred remembers his life before being imprisoned, and it takes place in the space of a second, after the police officer who stops him punches him in the He believes in the mysterious tapes that preceded the murder is his way of trying to convince himself that he did not, that the Man of Mystery (Robert Blake as wifekiller - ironic, huh?) He really did. Part, less effective due to its lighter tone, is the way Madison escapes from the reality of the electric chair.The light on his cell flickers and buzzes as presumably someone is being executed, which triggers his fantasy of escaping by physically becoming In another person, however, even in the life of this younger man, Renee returns (as a double ...?) and he is free to start a life with her without the memory of his marriage, but he finds out about the sordid truth about s u life ... Mystery Man reappears, this time helping him commit a conscious murder of his ex-pimp, and allowing him to videotape himself to convince himself that this murder (which Fred may have committed before the movie began) It was right. But who the hell knows ... The plot? I mapped this movie after I saw it for the first time, and there are too many doubles whose nature we, as spectators, can not trust either as a physical reality or as a mental projection. Each interpretation points to the other, such as the Moebius strip that Lynch claims to embody the film. It is more like a puzzle structured around themes, mainly a subtext that involves photography: the photo of the twins, the pornographic films, the horrifying video tapes that appear on their doors as evil calling cards. Make sure you get a mailbox version of this movie; Lynch\'s visual compositions are based on horizontal angles everywhere, and there are many extreme close-ups in which the top of the heads are truncated (I\'m sure they are bad intentions). The cinematography is great, and the soundtrack (not the music, but the atmosphere that Lynch always does meticulously) is as important as the images, as in `` Eraserhead. `` And after watching a particular scene in this movie, you\'ll be very careful with the crystal tables with sharp edges for the rest of your life ...'

b'By the time this album came out, the Spice Girls were everywhere. They were on all magazine covers, they carried lollipops, books, even had several series of dolls and 5 hits # 1. This album was only added and to this day has sold more than 15 million copies worldwide. Accept it, they sold more albums than anybody since the Beatles and nobody still has to sell more than the Spice Girls did. They are a milestone in pop music, a legacy and without them, there would be no Britney or Christina.01. Spice Up Your Life (10/10) Another hit # 1 for girls, this song has great lyrics. And it was an intelligent way to market them. I was impressed with the video, it\'s very good. Great song.02. Stop (10/10) The song that did not reach # 1 in the United Kingdom. I love this . The voices of Geri are in my opinion the best part of this song. She sounds so sweet and perfect in her verses. Catchy lyrics ... a perfect pop song.03. Too much (10/10) One of my favorite songs of all time. Like 2 Become 1. I love the message and the story behind it. When you have it, it\'s too much ... when you do not have it, it\'s not enough. Song lyrics by GREAT.04. Saturday Night Divas (10/10) Another one of my favorites. I love the part of Melanie C on the bridge. Your voice here surprises me. Emma\'s verses are also perfect. Beautiful song with original and different verses. Love it ! 05. Never give up in good times (10/10) Many fans agree that this would have been a great single. This is a great song with a great message for everyone. Especially the girls. Stay safe and do not get pregnant ... live young while you can. Move to Over (8/10) The Pepsi song, but in general it\'s great. A kind of filler in this album, but its smooth rhythm and raw voices make up for it. Although I prefer Pepsi\'s other song `` Step To Me \'\' about it. It is available in the Japanese version of this album.07. Do it (9/10) Another song with a great message! My mother did not believe it when this album came out, but I agreed with everything they say and I still do. `` The rules are meant to be broken, do what suites, not what they want you to do. \'\' 08. Deny (10/10) It reminds me of my ex-boyfriend denying that he was really gay. This is one of my favorites . `` You are not foolish but yourself. \'\' So true.09. Viva Forever (10/10) Wonderful! Beautiful lyrics and melody. Saying goodbye to true love ... I can relate to this deeper than many other songs here. This song really gives me chills, it\'s a disturbing song. One of his best.10. The Lady Is A Vamp (7/10) It is not one of my favorites, but it IS different. And it\'s a great way to end the album as a concert ... \'\' Ladies and gentlemen, we hope you enjoyed the show! "In general, this album is as good as the original with as much spice as the previous one - Geri, Emma, \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bMel C, Mel B & Victoria have the same voice in this case and they all sound amazing anyway. This album is probably my favorite of the three, and I LOVE all three, so if you still do not have it, buy it or something like that It\'s fun It makes you dance, cry and think a lot It\'s not just a soundtrack, this is a ALBUM. Get it!'

b'OK ; Let\'s be clear about something. This is a work of fiction. It is well crafted, slippery and tempting in its message. But it is fiction. However, let\'s also be clear on some other things. First, many of the points that are made here are TRUE. Which ? Well, I\'ll avoid spoilers, but suffice it to say that people often ask me if I\'m an atheist. No, I say, I do not deny the possibility of a superior being. But I deny the church. This story clearly shows how organized religion has routinely destroyed the best messages, but corrupting them with greed, cravings for power and cruelty. Groups of men made human decisions and wrote human words to describe a system that would keep them in power, and this story delves into that. It delves into the little-known facts surrounding the so-called "holy" bible ... the idea that what we know as today\'s bible differs greatly from what it once was. And so . I do not seek to destroy the faith, nor this history. What it does is, hopefully, tempt the viewer / reader to THINK for HIMSELF. This is a fun, well-acted and well-photographed story of a well-written and enjoyable modern fiction. I hope that, if nothing else, think THOUGHT about it, and maybe, just maybe, people will start to see formal religious institutions like Christianity for what they are ...'

b"`` Battlefield Earth '' is considered one of the WORST movies ever made. It makes `` Hands, Hands of Fate '' look like a profound, human and moving drama about suffering in the hands of a cult and `` Plan 9 from outer space '' seems like a profound meditation on world peace and the dangers of science `` Battlefield '' has holes in plots bigger than Swiss cheese, and to think that it was a labor of love (!!!) John Travolta saw this film as a tribute to L. Ron Hubbard. But it ended a catastrophic failure. And no wonder. `` Battlefield '' has human beings living in primitive conditions, at the mercy of the dreadlocked psychics led by John Travolta and Forest Whitaker. Human civilization lies in ruins. The special effects, sometimes, especially with the ruins, are convincing. Pity about the rest of the movie. Barry Pepper (who seems to have retired, or something like that) stars as the hero, '' Jonny Goodboy. '' Not inventing that. Being a prisoner of the Psychlos, he manages to learn to read, fly planes, fire guns, all in a remarkably short period of time. As for the psychos, what was their motivation in world domination? Gold ! And yet, they were not able to find Fort Knox after blowing it all to pieces. Silent premise, horrible acting, a horrible makeup scene between Travolta and his real life wife, Kelly Preston ... it's better not to see her. This movie makes you suffer Moment for Moment, and Travolta wondered if his career was Living Live. At least, her taste for camp movies has not changed, as she acted as the mother of Tracy Turnblatt in Hairspray (Full Screen Edition). The love of bad movies is a battlefield."
