b'Every year, when Christmas arrives, I like to invite some friends to enjoy a drink of joy (the powerful recipe of Egg Nog is available on request), put on some good Christmas music, light candles, prepare delicious douves and gather around me. Humble but enough cinema and see a wonderful holiday favorite. This year I\'m going to see Die Hard and for me Christmas would not be complete without him. The classic story of John McTiernan (Predator and The Hunt for Red October) that spawned three explosive sequels never seems to age. , no matter how old-fashioned the hair, clothing and image of cocaine addicts in California. Die Hard follows John McClane (Bruce Willis) to the Christmas party of his quasi-wife (Bonnie Bedelia) in a skyscraper on the west coast. He is a New York policeman whose wife and children moved west while taking a great opportunity and adapting. Obviously, they are having some marriage problems, but it is minimized enough. The building is empty, with the exception of the group that is celebrating the Christmas party on one of the highest floors. `` Terrorists \'\' led by Hans Gruber (Alan Rickman) take over the building and chaos ensues. Gruber\'s plan would have gone well if John had not escaped and slowly began to eliminate each of his henchmen, while informing the local authorities. The federals soon enter and the film explodes in an action classic ... and also in a Christmas classic. Maybe he has a hero as nice and convincing as John McClane and Bruce Willis surpasses any other action hero by making John not only smart and funny, but also easy to relate to very little drama. It\'s an effortless performance that I can only compare to Harrison Ford as Indiana Jones. Only a few intrepid observations along with a cynical look on his face make John go from being a typical good guy to what every boy dreams he could become in these circumstances. It\'s fantastic and it\'s corny, but that\'s forgivable because it\'s a holiday movie and, most importantly, the action remains the priority at Die Hard. On the other side of the coin, the greatness of Die Hard is completed by his formidable and accessible antagonist, Hans Gruber. Even after we discover that Hans is not there as a political terrorist, but simply as a thief, he does not lose the credibility of the villains at all when he responds to the criticisms of Holly McClane by saying: "I am an exceptional thief, Mrs. McClane and since I am moving to kidnapping you should be more educated. "Although we know that Hans is capable of vile acts, he actually sees them as merely means to a greater and somehow justifiable end." His disposition is almost humanitarian and you would imagine him as A gentleman out of the context of the crimes he commits in the Die Hard arc In the end, however, Hans is a pure sociopath with whom even the public feels sympathetic, I would have liked him to escape if his opposition was Van Damme, Segal or Stallone ... maybe even Arnold, the cast of support is another great strength and it helps to highlight the humorous background of the film. Fun and rich sonajes, especially Reggie VelJohnson as Los Angeles police sergeant Al Powell. The villains are purely chaotic thugs with enough variety to be a little more than just the count of John\'s bodies. It is also worth noting the performance of William Atherton as a reporter, as is the limo driver of John, Argyle. It is even worthwhile to enjoy the edited versions for television where the oath is replaced by wonderfully clear little curses like * ditch slug *, * melon farmer * and * bad mother cruncher *. Those of course make it fun and accessible for all ages and Die Hard is one of the best examples of hilariously edited television movies. But that, of course, is not what makes it a great movie. In fact, I would say that Die Hard is the best pure action movie ever made. Yippie-ki-yay * muddy braggart * and happy holidays.'

b'Putting in my two cents: The girl who jumped through time has been on my watch list for a while, but I never took the time to check it until yesterday. I (like most other critics) did not expect too much, but after watching his new movie "Summer Wars", I decided to try it. I must say that despite being a slightly older film, this exceeds Summer Wars in almost every respect (except perhaps in computer animation). There are literally no weaknesses in this movie. The quality of the animation is still high in everything. The characters are beautifully hand-drawn and the backgrounds are very elaborate (most of them drawn by hand too). The use of computer animation is kept to a minimum and occurs mainly when we see a \'jump\'. The characters are strong and nice. Makoto is your typical clumsy teenager. A casual encounter followed by an (almost) horrible accident allows you to \'jump\' in time. Instead of using this ability for the so-called "evil" (it would be receding and investing heavily in certain populations ...), Makoto uses the ability to improve his life and that of his friends. However, this begins to cause unforeseen and terrible circumstances. And this is the point where the film goes from being cheerful and somewhat comical to totally dramatic and sad. I will not divulge any event or ruin any plot, but let\'s say that at the end of the film I was moved (though not with teary eyes!). The performance of the Japanese voice is strong, especially considering at least 2/3 of the main characters are voiced by a voice actor for the first time. It will show how in Japan, they take the voice acting seriously and emitting well (instead of the majority of American dubbing firms that have a core of 5 or 6 full-time actors that HAVE to match a main character in each series or movie - often does not achieve the best combination for the character). So the story is strong with a little science fiction, the characters are nice and well portrayed, the voice acting is wonderful, the animation is beautiful ... why have not you seen this yet? If you\'re not an anime fan, this could be a good movie to help you change your mind.'

b'It\'s a rarity: a low-budget supernatural western with a pretty good cast, an eye for winter scenery and, most notably, a really spooky atmosphere. b'What I liked most about this movie is its lack of & quot; message & quot; or agenda After telling a great story, this movie had nothing to do with & quot; try & quot; . One could see by the admirable performance of J.P. Pitoks that the character was more than just a meatloaf. Gabriel could not keep quiet, and Mark could not speak. But he laughed in the right places. A great film. The fact that it does not & quot; message & quot; It is necessary to show that the gay community could begin to feel more accepted.'

b"The classic tale of demonic possession of all time, based on the best-selling novel by William Peter Blatty. Linda Blair is Regan MacNeil, a twelve-year-old girl who is manifested by a truly malevolent spirit. His mother, Chris MacNeil (Ellen Burstyn), an agnostic, seeks the help of a young Jesuit psychiatrist, Father Damien Karras (Jason Miller, God rest his Irish soul!) Who has demons of his own and is tormented by the recent death of his mother, and his loss in faith in which he sought refuge. After facing the demon within the girl (and himself), Karras, although skeptical of demonic possession, receives permission from the church to help during the exorcism. The priest selected to perform the ritual is a mysterious and elderly Jesuit, Father Lankaster Merrin (Max Von Sydow) who has seen such a diabolical work before. While the two clerics confront the devil, a police detective, Lieutenant William F. Kinderman (Lee J. Cobb) finds some links that connect the girl to a disconcerting death and desecration in the local Catholic church. William Friedkin directed brilliantly, and Blatty adapted the script (receiving an Oscar for his efforts) and produced. The cast offers extraordinary and sensitive performances (Burstyn, Miller and Blair were nominated for the Academy Awards) and the special effects are impressive and still have an impact, with veteran actress Mercedes McCambridge giving the voice of the evil entity. (The movie also won for Best Achievement in Sound). The underlying theme of much of Blatty's work is obvious, his philosophy is, if there is all this evil out there, why is there so much good? Metaphorically, all fight against their own demons, and even in his last moment of self-sacrifice, Karras returns to find his faith and heroically gives his life to save this innocent child. How significant can it be? A truly terrifying, absorbing and ultimately moving film that deals with faith and human frailty."

b"As I'm sure most of the reviews of the clone wars make clear, these are better than the previous movies. b"This story caught my attention immediately and held throughout the film. The movie is based on the life of John Nash. He was a brilliant mathematician who became famous when he was young because of his work in economics. The film covers several decades and begins when John Nash arrives at Princeton University. Russell Crowe does an excellent job in the role of Nash. The part required Nash's transformation from a healthy young man to an aged schizophrenic. Alicia, Nash's wife, is played by Jennifer Connelly. She is very convincing as an intelligent and strong woman who realizes that her brilliant husband is very worried and lives in another world. A particular and charming scene stands out in my mind where Nash and his future wife are staring at the stars. He tells her to think in different ways or animals and that she is able to look at the night sky, with its millions of stars, and join them in any way she mentions. I wish there had been more scenes of that kind and maybe a little bit of information about Nash's family and childhood. John Nash finally received the Nobel Peace Prize for Mathematics, which is a consolation, but the tragedy of his gifted mind is attacked by delusions was something I will not forget. I came out of this movie with a lot of compassion for John Nash. Schizophrenia is really a horrible mental illness. It's worth watching this movie and I think it will stand the test of time."

b'I can not recommend this program enough. For those of us who are new to yoga and for whom exercise is only a tenuous memory, this gently stimulating exercise will have you hooked before you know it. Four levels of intensity are shown for each pose. This accomplishes two things: 1) not scare people who can not put their ankles behind their heads at the moment, and 2) provide incentives to fight for the next level. For those who complain that this program is just an eye wash, remember the three areas that a full exercise regime should address: strength training, aerobic conditioning and flexibility. & quot; Yoga conditioning to lose weight & quot; It is an energizing way to achieve this last thing while I am, dare I say it, ... fun!'

b'I felt compelled to write a critique of this movie for several reasons. First of all, because this is one of my favorite movies of all time. I never get tired of watching this movie again and again and sharing it with other people who have not had the pleasure of seeing it yet. I also wanted to write this review because many younger movie fans immediately dismiss old movies and especially black and white movies. And finally, I wanted to do my bit after reading the criticism of the `` professional critic ... misinterpreted? ? ? HOW could there be a better and more perfect cast movie? ? ? Gregory Peck, whom he had come to venerate as Atticus Finch in "To Kill A Mockingbird" (he is the reason why he wanted to be a lawyer when he was a child), and Audrey Hepburn has the perfect blend of innocence and courage for his role as the rebellious princess. Even Eddie Albert as a side of the comedy was ideal. This film follows a princess who, at first glance, lives an enviable life of wealth, fame and glamor. It has always been difficult for me to find compassion for the complaints of similar people, either in real life or in the film, but somehow Audrey Hepburn takes off and it is not difficult to encourage her, since she experiences things as basic as deciding how her hair should cut and eat an ice cream. While Gregory Peck is undeniably gentle as the dishonest American journalist, he is also able to achieve the sleaze necessary to make his role credible. You have to be able to understand that your initial motivation does NOT come from a "good place", but simply from greed and selfishness ... but you must also believe in your change of heart and its subtlety. And works . He does not wake up suddenly and has a change of heart. You can see its transformation, or its relevance, in the course of the movie. Like a romantic wardrobe, I have to say that I always secretly wait for a better ending (and for `` better \'\' I do not mean in terms of the quality of the film, I mean in terms of a classic \'\' happy ending \'\') . The final scene is heartbreaking, but the only possible way it could end. I always wonder what the hell happened next, despite knowing the answer very well ... and it is not necessarily what we would all like to imagine. But I respect the fact that the film does not spell it and does not wrap it all in a beautiful reverence. It\'s still a tearful ending, but exactly as it should be. Please, watch this movie. You\'ll want to have it later, I promise. And do not be fooled, it\'s not just an old and old-fashioned girl movie. \'\' It\'s just good. Oh, yes, and that * factor sigh * ... HUGE! Enjoy and share with the younger crowd so that this classic never gets lost in the modern box office hits.'

b"Too often, Hollywood has announced a movie 'Based on a true story' to continue with a twist and add to the story of real life that the film becomes a lie. Not here. b'Finally I gave all the hype and really went to see Minority Report. The question that remains for me now that I have seen it is: what was all the exaggeration about? However, what bothered me most was the incredible amount of products placed throughout the film. In general, I spent two and a half hours in the movie during which I asked myself more than once if all the people who walked through the cinema during the screening of the film, were they as bored as I was? The bottom line is, good free special effects and some interesting scenes like the chase at the car factory, other than I can watch commercials on my TV at home for free.'

b"After his son is involved in the murder of his girlfriend, parents Streep and Neeson disagree on what course of action to take. Should the son Furlong tell the truth as Streep advocates or should he go with Neeson, who has already destroyed the evidence on his behalf, and invent a new version of the facts in an effort to stay out of jail? The slogan of how far you would go to protect your own flesh and blood promises much more than it offers. In fact, it never manages to increase the tension, even in scenes that, by right, should be the most interesting in the film, like the revelation of what really happened between Furlong and his girlfriend. All performances are intact and correct; this is exactly the kind of role that fits best with Streep (although it was much nicer in 'The River Wild'), Neeson is also very good in an unfortunate and stereotypical role, although Furlong is often pigeonholed as the problematic teenager plays it better than any other. However, the main flaw is that something that promises emotion never reaches a boiling point and, despite the names of stars, you can not help thinking that everything looks a lot like a television movie. All this and the end does not offer any kind of conclusion or redemption for your character, leaving your audience hanging, but without worrying about anything."

b'Wolverine and the X-Men were a fantastic adaptation of the X-Men for this generation. The episodes were very well written and sometimes it felt like watching a Bryan Singer X-Men movie in animated form. b"The miracle worker is a wonderful narrative of the life of Jesus here on earth. Forget the description of editorial comments of Jesus as melancholic (I do not think they have seen the movie). It also shows how human Jesus was, how he fought with the same things that we fight with. It was God's goal to send him here and this movie really captures him. My son & amp; Husband also loved it. It is more biblically more accurate than any other narrative of the life of Jesus that I have seen, including the greatest story ever told."

b"A long time ago, a concierge named Cropsy was horribly burned by a bad joke that went awry leaving him disfigured. Five years later, he returns to the same camp where he worked as he now seeks revenge with a huge pair of scissors that he uses to cut his victims to pieces, but can campers survive a vacation in hell? Entertaining and bloody for the ultimate slasher movie which is one of the most overlooked slasher movies ever! The makeup effects of Tom Savini are amazing, even by today's standards, since I think he is the master of all make-up artists. The film co-stars Holly Hunter and Jason Alexander before their great film careers, there's some incredible graphic violence such as the infamous raft massacre sequence with more than what Gore was cut and restored on this DVD. The soundtrack is pretty cool, well, it's not for the faint of heart, but a must for fans of `` Sleepaway '' and `` Friday the 13th '' alike.The DVD has some interesting extras like two short films especially in the makeup effects of Tom Savini, photo gallery and a trailer."

b"& quot; The return of the living dead & quot; is a hilarious horror / comedy inspired by George A. Romero & quot; Living Dead & quot; films . I saw this movie when I was just a little boy and I loved it. This is almost like Camp 80 like horror movies. The premise of the film is a nice tribute to Romero. Apparently, the movie & quot; Night of the living dead & quot; It was based on a true story, and was covered by the government of the United States. The bodies of the zombies were sealed in drums of oil and dispersed. Two workers in a medical supply store find one of these drums, pierce it by accident and release a gas that revives nearby dead. Luckily, the store is right next to a cemetery. The rest write to himself, and the movie has some of the funniest moments in the history of horror movies: a corpse running in the warehouse, the head of a zombie being beaten out of the park with a baseball bat, a zombie ordering & quot; more paramedics & quot; As if he were asking for pizza And, above all, an elegant 80's rock soundtrack. This is one of my favorite movies of the party, because it makes everyone (even non-horror fans) howl. At some point it is bloody, but the comedy eclipses the elements of terror. The DVD in question is a little light on the extras, except for a documentary that is fun, but tepid. But the big advantage is the best quality of image and sound in which I have seen this movie. The DVD really makes a difference. Get yourself a copy and see what I mean, you will not regret it."

b"Because this movie is sold out, it took me a few weeks to find a copy. However, once I did, I felt as if I had found the Holy Grail horror movie. The story revolves around a scandalous affair of a bored housewife (Julia Cotton) and her brother-in-law (Frank Cotton). Julia and her husband move to Frank's old house after Frank's sudden disappearance. Of course, Frank has not really disappeared. Instead, the perverted brother-in-law has found a cube-shaped puzzle. The puzzle, when it opens, opens a portal to the world of the Cenobitas. The Cenobitas offer the maximum pleasure, but at a high cost. Now that he can escape from the world of the Cenobitas once a drop of his brother's blood has been spilled on the floor of the house, Frank returns like a walking corpse, needing parts of the body of living beings to be completed again. Frank uses his past relationship with Julia to convince her to bring him new victims. With each victim, Frank becomes more complete, but also more impatient. There are several scenes of omen, praying mantis and evil spider with Julia as she goes out to the bars and picks up random men for the kill. Of course, eventually her actions arouse suspicion in her adult stepdaughter and her husband ... The film introduces the introduction of the Cenobites, which are some of the most frightening cats in horror since the Alien Xenomorphs. As the film progresses, we learn more about these beings, their origin and purpose. Of course, the ending leaves everything open, which leads to several sequels. I recommend this movie to those who like to watch early horror films made by those who now consider themselves masters of the genre."

b"For the great admirers of Manhunter, I would advise you to stay away from this DVD if you plan to have ... What has been announced as the & quot; Theatrical & quot; the version is in fact a poorly spliced \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bversion that awkwardly edits two scenes that had appeared at the theatrical premiere, including one of the most crucial scenes, and still has within it the most banal footage restored from the floor of the cutting room . These cuts are badly made and do not make sense to them, since they do not represent the theatrical presentation and destroy the impulse of what had been a finely edited film. I do not know if it was ignorance or arrogance, but this is the worst hacking work I've seen trying to pass itself off as a product. Whoever was in charge of this in Anchor Bay was an idiot and if I were Michael Mann, I would be calling my lawyers. & Quot; Director's Cut & quot; it is even worse in the sense that it includes the & quot; Not theatrical & quot; launch And the so-called & quot; Director's Cut & quot; - a compilation of some interesting and not so interesting shots. As a companion to a true theatrical premiere, this would have been a fascinating addition; BUT here once again, Anchor Bay finds a way to ruin what a good product should be. All the film that has not been processed in video, is stained and blurred, as if it had been transferred from a VHS tape, and a very worn one. - It is incredible that someone can have the audacity to offer this kind of cheap for the hard earned money. I saw this movie when it first came out in the theater and I considered it one of the best of that year; and I rushed to buy the LaserDisc version when it came out. When Anchor Bay released the Director's Cut DVD this year, I was on the waiting list, ready to receive the enhanced THX version with wide screen. Being intimately aware of the movie, imagine my disappointment. Do not waste your time. Wait for a better version to come out. As for those people who wish to compare the Silence of the Innocents with Manhunter, they usually prefer one above the other and their minds are practically invented at this time. I'm in Manhunter's camp. For me, I enjoyed the Silence, but I could never take it seriously, since I found the reader's notebook so caricatur- ally superhuman and, therefore, unrealistic and not very instructive. However, the Manhunter Reader is a chilling but more realistic description that impresses me every time I see it in how an evil genius manages to manipulate events outside his cell through the simple device of a telephone. This Reader is safe behind closed bars, and still manages to be a powerful presence to consider. I hope every fan and future fan of Manhunter sees it the way it came out, a fine piece of art that was slim and stylish, but that flowed with style. Siskel and Ebert rated it as one of the best films of all time, years after its release. But for now, I'm going to have my LaserDisc."

b'The 3 movies are pretty and sit on the edge of your seat, but most people already know the stories. The first of the 3 movies, The Bourne Identity has excellent videos and a very discreet channel tracking in the audio. The sound mixers did an excellent job of using all the surround channels and did not allow the soundtrack to hide the various foley effects on any of the front or rear channels. Of course, in all the excitement, your subwoofer will get a good workout. The video transfer is quite good, with no video noise, aliasing or artifacts. This movie started the whole franchise and it was a super start. My only question was how Bourne getting shot in the back took out his amnesia in the first place. That was never really answered, since amnesia would generally arise from a severe head injury and not from two bullets in the back. The Supremacy of Bourne, the second film of the trilogy, made much greater use of the handheld camera, and while it did it does not bother me, I remember a friend and professional photographer, mentioning that it made him dizzy. The transfer of video in Blu Ray was excellent in all aspects, but I also noticed much less use of directional audio. Instead of putting money into a more discreet sound edition, the producers increased the soundtrack that enveloped practically the entire sound stage, front and rear. It\'s not that the soundtrack does not fit the film, it certainly does, and it creates the atmosphere of emotion that Bourne\'s film requires, but a greater focus on the 5.1 sound stage for the Foley effects would have been nice. The last of the Trilogy, the Bourne Ultimatum completes the package with the same force in the video transfer. I did not see any weakness in any of the video transfers for the 3 movies, but once again, in the Bourne Ultimatum, one would think that with all the excitement, the use of the front and back sides would be more prominent. I was disappointed that, like Bourne\'s Supremacy, they simply upped the audio levels of the soundtrack, which would eclipse any Foley effect. I am not saying that there is no use of speeches in any of the last two films, but nowhere as much as it could have been or as was used in the first Bourne Identity. To save $ only increase the level of the soundtrack and that\'s a shame. During the scene of the fight things are thrown, crystals are broken and all kinds of chaos are produced that could easily have been directed to the left or to the right, forward or backward. Therefore, in that aspect, I was disappointed. However, this is a great collection and the excitement and pace of the 3 films are excellent. There are many deleted scenes and other \'making of\' shorts, as well as comments with no waste of space for previews and other movie ads. Well worth the cost. Honestly, this review has been helpful and, if so, check the "Useful" button, so I know I\'m on the right track with my comments for you. Thank you .'

b"From time to time a movie appears that has almost no publicity or even a decent release for the general public, oh, the purgatory of film and limited releases. However, in the case of Equilibrium I am more surprised at why this never received a wider version. Seeing the movie, honestly, I did not have many expectations, apart from watching some great shooting games and martial arts as the star of the movie. While this factor proved to be entertaining, the real star belongs to the finely designed script that pays homage to novels such as `` Brave New World '', `` 1984 '' and `` Fahrenheit 451 ''. History places the viewer in the post-apocalyptic world of the future. Having suffered the aftermath of World War III, the survivors were banned together to form a new society that would free them from the greatest faults, emotions. Controlled by a drug, which annuls such senses, the future is a utopia free of war, but enslaved to those who exercise power and the establishment created. Art, music, literature, all this is forbidden and the penalty for committing such crimes of the senses is death. The most feared of the protectors of the establishment is the Cleric. A group of men trained in mind and body to be the perfect killing machines and the children of their ideals. One of those clerics, who even executed his own partner to read a book of poems, begins to see the world in a new light when he misses his usual dose and experiences a torrent of emotions that he had never felt before. While trying to maintain his duty, he finds the cruel sadism of his appointed task almost more than he can bear. In a desperate search he tries to find the resistance and put an end to the madness he has safeguarded. Christian Bale, playing the cleric, is amazing giving depth and emotion to a role that did not demand any. In this, it makes the film even deeper. The cinematographic style and the edition, lent by filmmakers like John Woo and Tsui Hark, contribute the freshness enough while they adapt those styles. Art direction is appropriate to create a claustrophobic world of dismal lies. Although the backdrops of the city are not so impressive and obviously are CG effects. The music, sometimes dark and mixed with the conflict that looms, and then a fast-paced techno score that sets the pace of the shot without losing the rhythm. In total, Equilibrium is a dream of science fiction fans come true, but it is also a movie that fans of classical literature can also enjoy. While the ending may seem too simplified, I actually found that it has a deeper meaning, as well as an interesting comment about humanity in general. But most will be thrilled with the final ten-minute shootout, with an impressive sword duel. Equilibrium contains strong language and violence and is recommended for people over 17 years of age. For once, style and substance collide on celluloid."

b'I can not say more about this DVD! ! ! ! I think they did the best they could with the incorporation of music with phonetics. I swear, my 6-year-old who is in first grade had a dramatic improvement in reading and spelling after watching this video. At the beginning of the school year, she averaged 3 out of 8 in her spelling and in her first report card, the teacher said she needed more help with reading. I turned on this video a couple of times during the week for a few weeks for her to look at it and each time I started it in a different chapter. There has been a dramatic improvement in your reading and spelling. Now she got an 8/8 in her spelling. She started coming home with decals every day from school that she said she received for doing a good job in reading. She said that this phonetic video taught her to read. ! ! Just a few weeks ago, we were just getting over the Dora Phonics series and now she is reading books that she got from the library, which are in the second grade. Amazing video! ! ! ! I believe that all Kindergarten and First grade teachers should use this video to complement the teaching there. Students relate to this much better than a teacher trying to teach it.'

It's one of those films that personally affects what drives fans to quote him, and my favorite moment after all these years is (as it is for some of these other writers) that Maude throws Harold's charm into the river, because now she '& quot; I always know where he is. & quot; That was my first experience with the depth of the movie, and I never lost it. If you have not seen the movie yet, you can probably read some of these publications and not ruin it. There is so much to laugh about and marvel at, and of course, those songs. . . ."

b"This is one of the most beloved films by affictionados of the foreign cinematographic scene. Tati provided a brilliant link between the best that the silent film era and the modern movie had to offer. It is a relatively simple story of a clumsy man on vacation on the coast of France. But repeated visits, especially over the years, open up more and more treasures that until now had not been recognized, like a classic novel. I would be surprised if someone got excited about this movie the first time they saw it. Certainly not. But repeating the visits over the years will give you an appreciation of this movie that borders on worship. Every member of my extended family loves this movie, and everyone has a particular reason. Some adore it for its ability to perfectly capture a foreign place and time, which allows one to feel as if they themselves had escaped to the French coast during the afternoon. Some love Hulot's awkward but endearing attempts at romance. Many love bright visual jokes that are funny, no matter how many times you've seen them. But regardless of what a viewer loves most, everyone will feel a bond with the character of Hulot (and, in turn, M. Tati) that will last a lifetime. With this DVD, I can finally feel safe lending my beloved and grainy VHS copy. A classic of the film in every sense of the term."

b"When I was ten years old, my mother's uncle gave me his copy of the book A bridge too far from Cornelius Ryan. This was a very special gift from him, since he was deported to Germany to work for the Reich during World War II and never recovered mentally from what had happened to him. When I got the book, he lived in a small town, a few miles west of Arnhem, on the south bank of the Rijn River. Obviously, I was young to read the book at that time. Over the years, my interest in World War II and Operation Market Garden began to grow, and every time A Bridge Too Far was broadcast, I saw it. The scenes that represent the drops of the paratroopers and the assault of the Waal river were the most remembered. That, and the great musical score by John Addison. I finally bought the DVD and watched it several times since then. I must say that with every time I see it, the movie gets better and better. Especially with the close subtitles: first those that specify in what location we are. Without these, one could get confused where the viewer was taken from one scene to another. Second, since English is not my mother tongue, I was able to better understand some of the dialogues. (I finally understood what Liv was trying to say in Dutch =) The widescreen option is fantastic. You really get into the battle scenes and see all the extra pictures ... for example, when the John Frost battalion enters Arnhem, you see people riding bicycles in the background, which you can not see in the pan and version of scanning. But with a medium as good as the DVD, and also with the 25th anniversary of the cinema last year, MGM and United Artists lost a great opportunity. It's a pity that the only extra is the original theatrical trailer. I really would have liked to see extra behind the footage of the scene included in a second album. The Dutch Broadcasting Company (NOS) must have a large amount of archive footage, I remember that the news broadcast often spends time filming the film, like the excrement represented. In addition to that filming, the studio must also have additional images. They could even produce a new documentary about the filming of this film, including interviews with the main actors and Sir Richard Attenborough. And what about the original footage and notes about the battle that took place? Despite this failure, it is still a must buy if you like classic movies or war movies. After 25 years it still has its own and it is still an emotion to look at. Buy it, and in the meantime keep waiting for a special edition on DVD. I give this DVD 4 stars, but if they had included the extra material, I would easily get 5 stars!"

b'This movie has always been one of my favorites. I have three copies on VHS (two backup copies only in case the one I usually see runs out). I make all my friends look at him, and most of them love him as much as I do. It\'s stupid, completely inept and totally funny. I put it there with `` Forbidden Zone \'\' by Richard Elfman and `` Crimewave \'\' (also known as `` The Big Crimewave \'\') by John Paiz as one of the three best cult films of all time. Only The problem is that nobody has heard about this movie. So I could not believe my luck when I stumbled on the DVD! ! ! I thought I was dreaming. I was tempted to buy three copies ... just in case. First, I saw the deleted scenes and the extras, which were great. However, it seemed strange, because I had seen many of the deleted scenes (they are part of my VHS versions). Then, when I settled down to watch the movie, my heart broke. Someone, in his infinite wisdom, decided to censor almost all the nudity, and many other scenes have been shortened, or completely missing. I suppose this version of the film may seem a little more competent, because the missing scenes may have slowed down the pace of the movie a bit, but the scenes that were missing were UNSUSIVABLE. The ineptitude of this movie is what made it special, and editing it in a more "professional" version is a blasphemy on the limit. After seeing this edited and censored version, I wished I had never bought it. I wish it did not exist. Thank God for my copies of VHS. Whoever decided to censor and edit this movie should be ashamed of himself. Thank you very much for destroying one of my favorite movies. I only give two stars because some of the extras are great.'

b"Fred, Wilma, Betty and amp; Barney is back. But this time is not a continuation of the movie 94, but a prequel. When the movie opens, Fred and Barney got a job in a quarry. While they are at a wedding party, Wilma's friends want her to marry Chip Rockfeller. (Do you understand?) One night Fred (Mark Addy) and Barney (Stephen Baldwin) meet Gazoo (Alan Cumming). Gazoo is an alien. One night, Fred and Barney go to a fast food restaurant and meet Wilma (Kristen Johnson) and Betty (Jane Krakowski). Fred and Barney take Wilma and Betty to a carnival as an appointment. Soon Wima's mother (Joan Collins) appears in the apartment of Wilma and Betty. She wants Wilma at home for her father's birthday. On the day of the party, Fred, Barney & amp; Betty discovers that Wilma is & quot; a poor and rich girl. & quot; Fred fears that if he gives Wilma the wedding ring she will laugh at him. At the party is Chip (Thomas Gibson). And soon Chip makes a toast and Fred does too. But during Fred's toast, Fred's mascot, Dino, appears and arranges the party for Wilma's mother. That could have been the reason why Fred and his mother-in-law never liked each other. Chip invites the four to Rock Vegas. (Rock Vegas looks like Las Vegas). Ann-Margret makes a version of Viva Las Vegas, but the title is Viva Rock Vegas. If you like the Flintstones, here is a movie that you may like. Great movie !"

b'I\'m just writing this review, so this movie does not have the sadly wrong 3 stars of the other reviewer. There are a handful of truly great films from the Vietnam War, and generally each covers its own terrain. Full Metal Jacket is a kind of exception, since it covers the ground, the other three do it separately. Platoon covers the real combat, the feeling of hell that produced in an individual experiencing the fight, the jungle, the trauma in the moment when The Deer Huntsman covers the trauma of the postwar period, the long-range effect on the psyche of a veteran. Apocalypse Now covers the psychological (and poetic) heart of war, that is, the core of what war means, which is hatred, fear and the ruthless nature of the universe. After all, it\'s based on \'Heart of Darkness\'. "It could, in general, be the most frightening and convincing of all." In turn, Heart of Darkness and this film are based on a long line of literary backgrounds called `` katabasis \'\' in Greek, that is, the descent into the underworld. It is epic, punctuated by scene after scene that becomes dark and twisted, and the protagonist self-impelling, advancing to hell without knowing why, because as evil exists, he is attracted to it, to try to understand it, or if he can not , be part of it. Transitively, he asks you to try to understand evil. If I still do not have it, I would definitely buy it instantly for $ 6, as anyone who looks at this page and has not seen the movie should do so.'

b"I never had the chance to go see this movie when it hit theaters. I rented it without knowing what to expect. After watching it on DVD, I can say that I would not have minded paying the ticket price of the movie to watch this movie. It's not that glamorous, but what it is is a nice, respectable and respectable movie. Gabrielle Union does a good job playing a rude, nasty, hater of men with the name of Eva. Sometimes she takes it over, but that is acting and that is what she is paid to do. Eva is determined to take care of her little sister, who all bow to her instead of her men. The sister loves Eva and listens as if her word were the gospel. Men, on the other hand, hate their guts and want nothing more than to see her leave the city. He often interferes with the relationships of his sisters and insists on driving the men of his sisters crazy. Therefore, in order to bring order to their respected relationships, men plan to take Eve out of their lives. Therefore, the need for Ray (LL Cool J). Ray is a beach that speaks without problems with a serious game. The men tell Ray to go out with Eva to get her out of their lives. Ray agrees and that's how the story began with two people who fall in love with one another and are not supposed to fall in love. That's when things get complicated for Ray and Eva. Some parts of the movie were a bit outrageous and the end was not the best, but still, it was still a pretty good movie. I have read some of the reviews of this movie and other movies as well. What happens is that if you want real life situations, you see a drama or a real story. This is comedy ... Comedy is not supposed to be real. It is really an escape from reality. Do not we all need that now? Anyway, in addition to the ending, this film was well done with the supporting actors doing a great job interpreting their respected roles. Also, the women in this movie are pretty good. Also, LL did a good job playing Ray. I have a lot of respect for him as an actor. He did not do his part too much, but he made it credible. In general, I give this movie a B +. The ending was a small clich\xc3\xa9."

b"This is a little known but absolutely wonderful movie that, corny as it may seem, deserves to be shared by many. A small film about a family and the small trials and tribulations that go through the day to day. It is very realistic and it deals with the most common everyday things. What makes this film so amazing is how it is able to present this window in the life of this group of people with such ingenuity and insight, sadness and honesty; Ultimately, it results in a film that is tender and uplifting and full of hope. Acting is simply amazing. There are no other words to say it. Everyone, from Brenda Blethyn to Timothy Spall, to Marianna Jean Baptiste, to Claire Rushbrook, everyone takes turns stealing scenes in performances that are so natural and punctual that, sometimes, it does not even feel like you're acting. This is a real performance that goes straight to the heart. The script is wonderful, because it provides so many small details that one would not think of including in a movie. Only the smallest things that in some way give life to the characters. A wonderful movie that will never be acclaimed because everything is about the actors. There are no special effects or sex scenes of halle berry. No way, this is an actor's movie. And they steal the show. If you like REAL cinema, do not miss this movie jewel. IT IS SIMPLY WONDERFUL."

b'As other people have said, I expected to see an authentic adaptation of H.G. Classic Wells novel. At the same time, I was aware that this film was made with a modest budget, with the expected results. Well, this movie was worse than I expected. The special effects seemed somewhat caricatural, especially in comparison with the state of the art (Spielberg). Worse still, the use of color filters in many scenes became extremely annoying after a while. Even the overall quality of the print was, at best, mediocre, with an oversaturated color and just sharpness. And the performance will not receive any Oscar nomination. Also, I wonder if the original 3-hour release would be better to see it in the story. In this 125-minute version, there are many jumps from one subframe to another without proper scene development, in my opinion. The Martian "red grass" appears briefly in some scenes without any explanation. On the positive side, I thought that the tripods and the handling machines looked very good, the sound effects are pretty good and the musical score is beautiful. Unfortunately, that is not enough to overcome production that would otherwise be poorly executed. If only the CGI was of the state of the art and the color filters were eliminated, it would be a good film, but not the best one. If only ... ..'

b"G.D really is almost perfect. I never get tired of that. At the same time, I think most people do not understand the point. (By the way, I have NOT seen the Special Edition.) It goes through different stages: fear and confusion; euphoria, when he realizes that he can do NOTHING without consequences; Despair, when he realizes that life has no meaning if one pursues selfish pleasures without goals; and finally, a peaceful self-realization when it is dedicated to personal improvement and the humanitarian objectives that your situation gives you the opportunity to follow. Take a break to consider what each of the EE. UU would do in a similar circumstance. Oh, it's really funny, too."

b'This movie is in English and its main star is an American. However, it is a Japanese collaborative effort. As essentially a Japanese horror movie, it has some things in common with `` The Grudge. b'Ah, Gargoyles, finally get a deserved DVD release. This series is really excellent and has the honor of being one of Disney\'s most mature animated series to date. The series focuses on a group of living gargoyles, which are stone during the day and meats at night. Due to a curse on them, a small group of these creatures froze on stone for a thousand years before they woke up again in Manhattan in 1994. Like all supernatural beings in Manhattan, they naturally decide to fight crime. It may sound corny, but in the hands of a splendid team of writers, the series becomes much more than another story of "fight against non-human superheroes." Instead, Gargoyles becomes an interesting story with a captivating story and good characters. This series is benefited by its ability to take risks: the first episode even ends with what is essentially a mass murder. The program also addresses issues such as gun control in a fairly mature and realistic way, without becoming overly moral or prosaic. For example, the gun control episode "Deadly Force" (shamefully omitted by Toon Disney in his series career due to the presence of guns and gunfire, despite his strong message * against * inexperience playing with such weapons and fortunately restored without cuts in the release of the DVD) transmits its message without the characters remain saying `` The weapons are bad, mm\'ay? "The series also has a continuity rigidity that is rarely seen in American animated cartoons, the actions in previous episodes affect the later and the episodes have a fairly established order: unlike other Disney toons at that time, the episodes Gargoyles usually had to be transmitted in the correct order to make sense, the series is also full of references to Shakespeare (and other things, the first episode of the second season contains, of all things, a Kafka joke that I did not get during * years *) .Gargoyles is really one of the most interesting and unique series of cartoons in the Disney vault.This DVD is a great buy for the fans of a lifetime and highly recommended for new people who are curious to know The first season sets the rest of the series beautifully and gives the viewer an idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bwhat this series is about in general. I am already looking forward to future releases of the rest of the series.'

b'If anyone doubts the temporary quality of fame, just think of Douglas Fairbanks to clarify the point. In his time, the fame of Douglas Fairbanks was unprecedented. He and his wife, Mary Pickford, were considered the real family of the United States. Today, his wonderful action movies are not seen but by movie enthusiasts, and his face and his name are lost to the younger generation (if Jay Leno\'s "man on the street" interviews are any indication, our younger Americans) they seem proud to know the name of the Vice President, let alone a silent film actor like Fairbanks). That Douglas Fairbanks disappears from memory is tremendously sad. `` The Mark of Zorro \'\' is a good example of the kind of film in which Fairbanks specialized towards the end of the silent film era, and was very popular due to the dynamic presence of its star. There really has not been anything comparable with Fairbanks since his departure from the movies. No action star can approach his grace and power in an action movie. If you doubt me, buy this DVD and check it out for yourself. Watch Fairbanks jump over the tables, jump over high walls to climb a horse, jump from the table to a ledge near the ceiling, etc. And it was not only that he was able to do these feats, but that he did them effortlessly. The sheer grace of man was really exciting. He never seemed to strive for anything. I noticed this as I looked at the Mark of the Fox during a scene when Fairbanks lifts a leg and dismounts a horse running, at a gallop, to land as easily as if he were getting off the ladder. It made it look so easy, I went back and saw the scene again to make sure I saw what I thought I had seen. Yes, he had, soft as silk. Then there is his performance. In this film, Fairbanks plays a role of duel: Don Diego, a noble and elegant young man, and his masked counterpart, Zorro. His portrait of Don Diego is subtle and effective. Your body seems shapeless and smooth. His attitude is distracted and indecisive and vaguely lost. He detests the use of the sword and constantly cleans his face due to his great "fatigue". \'\' When his love interest declares `` He is not a man, he is a fish! \'\' She hits the nail in the head. However, when he puts on the mask, his body and form are reborn. His body looks agile and full of movement, and his smile, that tremendous and radiant smile that radiated pure happiness, is almost as devastating as his sword. Finally, there is the artistic design and the decorations of this film. Fairbanks loved these period pieces, and spared no expense in research and details. Their care, financial investment and dedication to craftsmanship really show. Everything has a beautiful, "deep" feeling. As a side note, this review is based on Kino\'s DVD release of this film and, as with all Kino releases, this edition seems simply great. God Bless Kino for being one of the best companies that preserves and commercializes silent films. If you have taken the trouble to read this review, buy this movie. If you do, Douglas Fairbanks will again be popular and famous, at least in your heart.-Mykal Banta'

b'MILL CREEK ENTERTAINMENT multi-channel packages are reasonably priced and of good quality. These twenty transfers of public domain movies without restoration vary from very good to sometimes fair; none is impossible to see. The `` legendary detectives \'\' of this DVD package are all series of films derived from the thirties and forties. `` The Shadow \'\' was a half-hour radio series broadcast for the first time on 31/31/30. Originally, only the narrator of mystery stories, in 1937 `` Shadow \'\' Lamont Cranston (now portrayed by a young Orson Welles) had become an integral character in each episode aired. The program\'s 24-year career ended the day after Christmas 1954. Shadow\'s three films here were first seen in 1937, at the height of the popularity of the radio show. `` Bulldog Drummond \'\' was created in 1920 by the British author Herman McNeile, who published under the pseudonym `` Sapper. "Drummond\'s stories were directly influenced by" noir "detectives, then popular in American fiction, and are considered to be the precursors of James Bond.The half-dozen films in this set that feature this character are all from the end of the decade. 1930. `` Dick Tracy \'\' was a crime comedian created by the pen and imagination of the Detroit newspaper artist Chester Gould, in October 1931. Gould worked on the strips until he retired in 1977. Other artists continue to produce In the comics, police detective Tracy wooed his future wife Tess Trueheart for 18 years, and finally married her on Christmas Day 1949. During that time, Tracy ran into legendary bad guys like BB Eyes, Flattop Jones, Pruneface, Haf and Haf, 88 Keys, Mr, Crime, Sphinx, Pear-shape and Faceless Redrum Dick Tracy\'s radio show was broadcast from 1935 to \'48. In the movies, Tracy was mainly portrayed by Ralph Byrd (beginning in \'37). Byrd stayed with the series until it ended after a brief career in early television. `` Sherlock Holmes \'\', the most recognized fiction detective of all, was the creation of Scottish author and physician Arthur Conan Doyle. The histories of Holmes were published in several British magazines from 1887. Over the years, Conan Doyle tried more than once to kill the character, but the public outcry caused him to reconsider. Doyle wrote four novels and fifty-six short stories starring Holmes and Dr. John Watson, his friend and cohort in the adventure, until the death of the author of the knight in 1930. THE SUSPENSE OF MILL CREEK! 20 Movie Pack would be a good complementary piece for this DVD. The preceding numbers that precede the titles are from 1 to 10 ratings of readers\' polls found on the resource website of a movie. (5.6) Bulldog Drummond returns (1937) - John Barrymore / John Howard (5.7) Bulldog Drummond Escapes (1937) - Ray Milland / Guy Standing (5.9) Bulldog Drummond in Africa (1938) - John Howard / Anthony Quinn (on paper secondary) (6.0) Bulldog Drummond\'s Peril (1938) - John Barrymore / John Howard (5.9) Bulldog Drummond\'s Revenge (1937) - John Barrymore / John Howard (6.4) Bulldog Drummond\'s Secret Police (1939) - John Howard / Heather Angel (5.5 ) Dick Tracy, Detective - Morgan Conway / Anne Jeffreys (5.9) Dick Tracy\'s Dilemma (1947) - Ralph Byrd / Lyle Latell / Kay Christopher (6.1) Dick Tracy meets Fear (1947) - Boris Karloff / Ralph Byrd ( 6.0) Dick Tracy vs. Cueball (1946) - Morgan Conway / Anne Jeffreys (7.0) Dressed To Kill (`` Sherlock Holmes \'\') (1946) - Basil Rathbone / Nigel Bruce (6.1) International Crime (`` The Shadow \'\' ) (1938) - Rod La Roque / Astrid Allwyn (5.3) The Shadow Strikes (1937) - Rod La Roque / Agnes Anderson (6.5) The Shadow: The Inv isible Avenger (1958) - Richard Derr / Jeanne Neher / Dan Mullin (6.8) Sherlock Holmes and the secret weapon (1943) - Basil Rathbone / Nigel Bruce / Lionel Atwill (6.0) The Sign Of Four (`` Sherlock Holmes\' \'\' ) (1932) - Arthur Wontner / Ian Hunter (6.4) A study in scarlet (`` Sherlock Holmes \'\') (1933) - Reginald Owen / Warburton Gamble (7.0) Terror at night (`` Sherlock Holmes \'\') ( 1946) - Basil Rathbone / Nigel Bruce / Alan Mowbray (6.1) The triumph of Sherlock Holmes (1935) - Arthur Wontner / Ian Fleming (as Dr. Watson) (6.9) The woman in green (`` Sherlock Holmes \'\') ( 1945) - Basil Rathbone / Nigel Bruce / Hillary Brooke'

The transfer, from the original 35mm elements, is as perfect as it can be. The appearance of the theatrical experience fills the eye and the ear and, as always, the heart. Welcome `` home '', E.T. and thank you, Universal, for a job well done."

Frankie Faison, who plays the traffic inspector, has 4 films this year and is an actor of a busy nature (White Chicks, Cookout). b"In the 1960s, when the creation of films was still an art form, the master puppeteer, George Pal created what has been considered a true classic, The Time Machine. Selecting as his hero, the handsome, brave and elegant Austrian actor Rod Taylor, playing Herbert George Wells, the director accurately portrays the adventurer, but taciturn, Victorian as a gentleman, who ventures with inventions and yearns for a more peaceful century to live . Using what has been hailed as the best special effects of that date, Pal launches Taylor into the future. By stopping only to observe the changing epochs in which the war is fought with better and more sophisticated weapons, Wells finally arrives at the land of the Eloi. Here he meets the beautiful and sensual Weena (Yvette Mimieux) and his people. During their brief time together, Weena allows Wells to learn that despite her idyllic paradise, she is not without dangers. In this future, it is the Morlocks who have become the masters of the world and have stolen Wells' time machine. Condemned to spend eternity in the future, Taylor confronts the Morlocks, resulting in a story that will later relate to David Filby (Alan Young) and his friends from Victoria. The film is magnificent and, despite having been reworked several times, it has never been matched. H.G. Wells would have approved it. *****"

b'The Italian work of the 60s is well known to the British public, for whom the film is a regular part of Christmas television programming such as the James Bond movies, The Great Escape and the Queen\'s speech. The negative reviews of American viewers are due both to the lack of a cultural context and to the lack of familiarity with many of the cast members. The film has aged well and provides a fun, if somewhat rosy, snapshot of British culture in the 1960s. The cast includes Noel Coward as Mr. Bridger, the criminal mastermind, and Michael Caine as the cowardly Charlie Croker. The British public will recognize a number of well-known actors in cameo roles, including Benny Hill and John Le Mesurier. However, the stars of the film are, without doubt, automobiles. Interestingly, the range of supercars of the 60s, including a Lamborghini Muira, E-Type Jaguars and Charlie\'s Aston Martin, are being eclipsed by the three Mini Coopers that drive the Italian police in an incredible car chase through Turin. Remy Julienne and her team of stunt specialists produced one of the most amazing and known, at least for the British public, car chases in the movies. It could be said that it is still one of the best car chase sequences and even more because the stunts were filmed in locations in Turin (and Coventry in the case of sewer scenes) and in cars with minimal modifications. There are many memorable moments. in the movie beyond the Mini Cooper sequence. Caine has "closed the doors", the older lady of Benny Hill obsessed Professor Peach in the tram of Turin and the ending "hanging" stuck with me. The additional features of the DVD are good, but not really exceptional. The documentary \'Making Of\' provides a series of interesting ideas about the film. The comment overlay track is a bit forced, but it\'s worth listening to. There is only one deleted scene, the incredible \'Blue Danube\' car ballet on ice. In short, this is a true British classic with a great cast, score and plot. A nice snapshot of the London of the 60, a fantastic cast (at least for the public of the United Kingdom) and the magnificent scene of the car chase make this one to buy. The Hollywood remake, although not a bad movie in itself, shares only the title, a story based on a gold theft and the BMW Mini updated with the original. And for anyone who wonders about the original Mini, they really are small and very fun to drive.'

b'28 Days Later is a film so well handled in terms of suspense, acting and meaning, that every time I look at it I am more convinced that it will become a classic in the genre of horror and science fiction. The same does not happen with the `` sequel \'\', which could be well directed by Fresnadillo, but is not well structured as a narrative, and does not lend any valuable "message" to the audience. 28 weeks later, the error of insulting our intelligence frequently occurs. How can it be explained that the husband of the surviving woman who is detained in a security center can have access to the room and not find any guard, or a doctor, or a soldier, or a vigilant staff in place ? There are not even cameras, in a situation where there is fear of the reappearance of the virus and it is possible, after the diagnosis made by the medical staff of the surviving woman. In fact, that is the key event that originates the violation of the virus. In addition, the film is so focused on the bloodshed, the bite and the vampire race, that a meaningful dialogue is not possible, which prevents one from having sense of the chaos. And what can you say about the helicopter used as a deadly power saw to decapitate dozens of zombie-vampires? The least I can say is that the scene is the peak of sensationalism. And insisting on the meaning of the film, why such a valuable element in history as the possibility that the survivor or her children have the key to the cure of the virus is simply wasted in favor of leaving the public with a terrible end, pessimistic and fatal? Is that the bait for another sequel, parallel to the series "Alien"? Meanwhile, we have a `` sequel \'\' that does not adequately comply 28 days later, regardless of the fact that Boyle is among the producers.'

b"It is a pity that Bruce Willis can not produce these films more often. John McClain is probably the best action hero in the entire history of cinema and this installment presents a great punch of action and humor. McClain is asked to bring in an alleged hacker to be interviewed by the FBI. The actor who plays this hacker is the guy who makes Apple McIntosh commercials. It is interesting to note that he seems to prefer a Mac in this case. Anyway, McClain appears just when the hacker is about to be hit by the bad guys. If it were any other movie it would be a guy with a magnum or a piano wire, but being a Die Hard movie, the bad guys come with ultramodern machine guns. Of course, McClain is able to take some of them and temporarily escape with the hacker. Therefore, we have the qualities of a great association as good as any for the Lethal Weapons films. The movie cheers you up all the time, especially when McClain teases the bad guy head by firing one of his key characters and then tell him I'm getting to get you. Kevin Smith has a bigger cameo like Warlock, a live at home with his mother hacker. It is a role that seems to have been made for him. This is the best Die Hard since the first movie!"

b"I had no idea that Ganz had him so good until I saw him here as Hitler. Alexandra Maria Lara as her young and naive secretary is also very good. The cast is excellent. Director Oliver Hirschbieger cleverly assembles everything and will keep you on the edge of your seat all the time, although we all know how the story ended. The film gets under your skin and steals your mind long after you've seen it. that - and that's a trick. How could the creators of this film be able to achieve this? By avoiding the usual approach of turning Hitler and his murderous SS thugs into two-dimensional cartoon characters, they instead show that many of them were what they were: humans. Mixed murderers, disoriented, fanatics, barbers and cold-blooded, and all in the pursuit of power (which never reached), but human at all. The sad thing here, as far as I'm concerned, instead of encouraging your nation to concentrate all that energy on making the world a better place, because the Germans, the German people, have given us much more than good cars and excellent lenses of camera and beer ... Hitler and his thugs had their people wasting all that potential in causing destruction and chaos, misery and pain ... in vain. I realize that quite a few Germans did not care about Hitler and his crazy notions ... only there was not much they could do about (once he came to power and they saw where he was actually leading them ... straight to Hell) . Any German who opposed the feared SS and the Gestapo ended up dead or in some camp somewhere to suffer the consequences. I always wondered what it must have been like for Hitler and his people in that bunker during the last months / weeks / days. .. This powerful moving image shows you what happened, and something else."

b'Anyone who is reading these reviews will have seen the production of TV and will know it closely; therefore, I will limit my review to the quality of the DVD image, or rather, the lack of it. It is a pity that what used to be a beautiful and memorable television movie has become a battered and vanished shadow of his former self. It is painful to see that something that has a special place in your heart is treated with such misery. For years, the only version that millions of people had seen on television had a faded color and a contrast so low that it almost seemed shot in black and white. If that is what you are used to, & quot; restored & quot; The version of this DVD (and the one shown on TV for the last 3 or 4 years) looks marginally better, but is barely restored. You just have to look at a deleted song in the extras section to see how beautiful and bright the original production was: crisp, clear, pristine, with highly saturated colors. The time and money SHOULD have been spent to bring the rest of the film to this standard. It is morally wrong to put a defective product on the market, then have the courage to collect money for it. As many of our parents probably told us when we were young, & quot; Everything worthwhile is worth it! & quot;'
b'I have loved Ricky all my life, although he is no longer with us, his singing and guitar on this DVD is something that I will cherish forever. Thanks for sending my orders so fast.'

b"In general, I liked most of the things that Paul Anderson did; Nothing surprising, but still some decent things. So I was not ready to condemn this movie before I saw it in the theater. b'This version of Jane Eyre is one of my favorites. I asked this DVD enthusiastically about a month ago when I found out. Unfortunately, I can only give this DVD two stars. That\'s a better star than the last `` remastered \'\' version that I reviewed ... the extra star is due to the fact that THIS, at least, is not missing a complete scene. Far from being remastered as stated in this release, if you can believe it, even worse than the other that I reviewed. First, it\'s dark and muddy, I had to raise the brightness of my TV almost all the time to see any detail. Second, the image is almost constantly filled with long (sometimes even half) scratches, black and white "dropouts", and a hair or fiber that appears at the top of the screen along all the front credits . Third, the color fluctuates several times throughout the film. Fourth, in some scenes the sound is a bit harsh. And to top it off the launch company (VCI Entertainment), not content with lying in its package, had the GALL to insert `` This special edition of the film has been digitally restored to its current condition \'\' before the film. There is \'truth in advertising\' for you. I can not understand why it is so impossible to get a good release of this movie. But I\'m tired of releasing companies that lie about remastering it. Do not pee on my leg and tell me it\'s raining.'

b"Wonderful interpretation of Jane Austen's masterpiece. At a time when graces and class distinctions ruled, the Dashwood sisters fell in love. Kate Winslet is lovely as Marianne Dashwood, Emma Thompson is an excellent Elinor Daswood, and Hugh Grant and Alan Rickman are wonderful here as Edward Ferrars and Colonel Brandon, papers for which they seem to have been made. And who of, of course, could forget the costumes? It's a shame that Sense and Sensibility did not win more prizes when it first came out. Does not matter ; true fans of this genre will appreciate how classic this movie is."

b'A calm and deliberate film finally suffers from having too much star power. No matter how sloppy and languid the filmmakers try to make Nicole Kidman look, she is still Nicole Kidman. b'Werner Herzog is the perfect and unique incarnation of the always worried, irreverent, dissatisfied and nonconformist director who enjoys walking on the razor and delights in exposing extreme situations on the eve of reaching the boiling point. For that reason, all its cinematography has been signed by novelty and original proposals, presented by unexplored territories and unthinkable stages. In this case, we witness the clash of two civilizations, visibly differentiated, the ancestral aborigines and the Western lifestyle, where myth and progress collide as the inevitable collision of two trains that displace each one, in opposite directions. A company will be installed in the middle of the Australian desert, in order to explore and exploit uranium reserves. But they will face ancestral tribes that oppose them because they will interrupt the dream of the green ants. A film dedicated to the mother of Herzog, with intriguing and acute reflections during the whole process, when this case is discussed in the Supreme Court. , through a very interesting test, where the happy ending will be absent. The final sequence will invite you to think and reflect.'

b'For starters, I am a lifelong bodybuilder and admirer of Arnold Schwarzenegger, so even though he is strictly a co-star in this, I am obviously biased. Having said that, however, I LOVE this movie completely! One of my favorite parts is the way that some of the best advice I\'ve heard about friendships and relationships in general are dispensed throughout the movie at times when you do not even realize you\'re learning something. Examples: Joe Santo (Arnold) is putting Craig Blake (Jeff Bridges) in training and advising him: `` You can not grow without burning! `` And we realize how deep that was when Joe repeats those words while the two fight over why Mary Tate Farnsworth (Sally Field) left Joe for Craig. In addition, there is Craig\'s uncle, Albert, whose voice is sometimes heard reading letters to Craig, saying: "It does not matter what you do, as long as you do something, and do it without pretenses." \'\'. Again, incredible movie. I have spent two videos so far, having seen it so many times. It\'s time to get ANOTHER ...'

b"I remember when I was younger I was going to see this movie with my brothers and I really enjoyed it. b'I saw this movie about a month ago at the local film library. After about eighty minutes, I discreetly looked at my watch and was discouraged when I realized that the movie was not even half full. Celine and Julie are going to sail? Until now I had not seen a body of water, let alone a boat. Where was this strange story with scenes that were repeated over and over again, and when would it end? I\'m a patient movie viewer, but this was too much. A series of film critics, whose opinions I usually respect, have practically built religions around their appreciation for this film. I wondered if this could be a case of `` emperor\'s new clothes \'\'? Almost two hours later, everything was over and I left the theater thinking that I could have seen two real cinematic masterpieces at the time I lost in Rivette\'s movie ... But somehow, it was not really over. The effect of the film persisted. It was not just an intellectual enigma that I had to deal with, the movie had gotten under my skin. The scenes were repeated in my head like a strange dream. His rhythm was different from everything he had encountered before. Celine and Julie never met any of my expectations, and neither did Jacques Rivette. In two separate scenes from the film, Celine and Julie introduce themselves to the men, who unconsciously believe that they will meet the other woman. In each case, the two women completely subvert the worlds of men, making holes in their rigid conventionality. Throughout the whole movie, Rivette was doing the same with me. Everything in the film, from its "plot" to its subtle manipulation of reality and its rhythm, forces you to put aside your expectations (or be miserable trying to hold on to them). You have to relate to the film on its own level, as you would to a child. Only then can you enjoy it. I do not know exactly why the film had that effect on me, but it says something about its power that more than a month later I still think about it. In recent days I have had this growing impulse to see `` Celine and Julie Go Boating \'\' again. The ideal circumstance for a first encounter with her is definitely in a theater or it can end up turning it off. Now that I have crossed that Rubicon, I would like it to be available on a region 0 or 1 DVD, so I could waste another three hours more.'

b"& quot; Back to the future & quot; It may be the most charming comedy / adventure there is. The film is a science fiction story about a young man who accidentally traveled in time from 30 years to the 50s. While smaller sci-fi movies would focus on the ideas of the paradoxes of time and hardware, & quot; Back to the future & quot; It focuses on the wonder of open eyes, charming characters and lots of good humor. The story begins with Marty McFly in 1985. Marty is a hopeless loafer with two foolish parents and a crazy scientific friend. Marty's friend, Doc Brown, has perfected a time machine with plutonium made from a DeLorean sports car. After a successful trial, Marty is accidentally transplanted to the year 1955 and was stranded there, he left his additional plutonium in 1985. What happens next is a series of wonderful surprises, since Marty interacts with the people of 1950 while looking for the version Doc Brown's youngest, but what is even more surprising and magical is Marty's relationship with his parents when they were teenagers. The film takes the perspective of a young man from his losing parents and makes him realize that at one point his parents were as hopeful and scared as he was. Finally he meets his parents for the first time. The film also suggests the hopeful notion that you can go back in time and help your parents when they needed it the most as Marty tries. While the movie is a joyful romp, there is a lot of action as Doc Brown comes up with an exciting plan for Marty to return to the future with lightning bolts, many visual effects and a high-tech endurance race. & quot; Back to the future & quot; It is the most balanced combination of science fiction, comedy and adventure. It is a film suitable for children of the 80s and 50s alike."

b'`\'I Know Who Killed Me \'\' is a scary little horror show that was designed as a kind of \'comeback\' vehicle for Lindsay Lohan in early 2007. Needless to say, the movie was not successful in that endeavor. Everything but. Lohan plays Aubrey Fleming, an attractive but relatively na\xc3\xafve high school student who is prey to a torture-crazy serial killer who manages to cut off some of her limbs before miraculously escaping from her clutches. When she wakes up in the hospital, she believes herself to be a girl named Dakota Moss, a kind of fictitious "alter ego" with a life taken from a mild pornography novel, which gives us ample opportunity to eat our eyes. Lohan, dressed in light clothes, turns in slow motion performing dances on a strip of poor quality. Aubrey, who is a fiction writer, simply a victim of repression, a wild and free spirit, so obsessed with being a "good girl" that she has allowed her true nature to remain buried in her subconscious. years ? And the trauma he suffered is simply the vehicle through which that true nature can now come to the fore? Or is there another less purely psychological explanation, say, symbiotic twins? - by this sudden change of identity? It really does not matter what the answers to these questions are, since this depressing foray into sadism, dismemberment and the supernatural hocus pocus is badly written, acted in an amateur way and completely devoid of emotion or common sense. Actually, history itself could have had some validity if it had not forced the audience to wallow in as many unpleasant injustices as it does. But, as it is, every time we begin to develop deeper interest in what is happening, we are subject to a new round of bloody bloodshed. Yuck'

b"Having grown up with the original Thunderbirds on TV (even at B & W), I expected something better. I suppose that as we move a little, teenage pubescent anguish no longer attracts much. I wanted to see the machines, the drama, the tension of the people who face the disasters that took them beyond themselves, the triumph of decent people over the impersonal evil of nature and all those good things that the original had in abundance, along with a shyness and humor that was not taken too seriously. The original was about the adventure first, with the incidental 'romance', and that is an important point, rather lost in this film. This is a teenage movie that grows and uses the Thunderbirds as a cover. I really did not need the Thunderbirds part, except the sets. The plot is, otherwise, perfectly normal and can be seen anywhere. The degree of improbability involved is much greater than the originals and a bit difficult to bear. The acting leaves a lot to be desired, and yes, the puppets of the 1960s were often much more realistic than the actors in this movie, and Ben Kingsley does not really look evil, or even evil. So, if you want a teen movie like so many others, this is for you. If you want something like the original, do not bother with this movie. Wait until someone has the guts to produce an 'adult' movie (rated 'G') in the classical genre. Unfortunately, this is not a particularly memorable movie."

b"Watch the American In Paris Blu-Ray and you'll know what's wrong with Gigi. The opening sequence is grainy. The transitions from scene to scene are bad.
