b"When a nuclear submarine unexpectedly falls into the Pacific Ocean and a hurricane prevents the military from sending a team later, they subcontract an offshore drilling rig near the area led by Bud Brigman (Ed Harris). To help the drilling team, the military sends a group of Navy SEALs led by Lieutenant Coffey (Michael Biehn) accompanied by the designer of the underwater oil rig and Bud again with his wife Lindsey Brigman (Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio). But while searching the nuclear submarine, they realize that there could be more to the sinking of the submarine than they thought, and while Lieutenant Coffey believes the Russians are responsible, the drilling team believes there could be something else .. supernatural involved. There are few directors who really know how to head each effort the way James Cameron does. His first film, The Terminator set a precedent for action films in the 80s, and he only surpassed that achievement with Terminator 2. With Aliens he made a film that was at least equal to Ridley Scott's Alien by making a sequel that changed the mood and style while respecting the original. In 1989, James Cameron directed The Abyss, a film that took place mainly under water, and that was filmed in the largest submarine set of the time. The assembly, built in a half-finished nuclear reactor facility, included 7 million gallons of water. So, among Cameron's other achievements, how does The Abyss rise? The Abyss is definitely Cameron's most underestimated movie. When watching movies like Avatar, Aliens, The Terminator and Terminator 2 it's easy to see how you can forget a movie like The Abyss, but if you look closer, The Abyss fits in with the others. Like other Cameron movies, it shows great attention to detail, with incredible special effects. On a technical scale, the film feels like real life, something that is always great when it comes to a Cameron movie. But, like other Cameron films, it's not about the special effects but the human element. Cameron does a great job humanizing his characters and giving body to their relationships. The performance is phenomenal, of course I would not expect less from a movie that includes Michael Biehn (The Terminator, Aliens) and Ed Harris (The Truman Show, The Rock). Biehn does it very well as a soldier who has lost communication with the outside world and has to make calls on his own about his next move, and that is driving him crazy. Ed Harris is great as the tough platform leader who longs for his ex-wife who keeps running away in different jobs without him, and Marry Elizabeth Mastrantonio is great as the aforementioned wife who finds that being stuck with Bud and his team is repulsive, but that grows close to the husband she had left behind and the team he runs. If you have not seen this movie, but you like the other Cameron movies, I recommend you give it this opportunity. I would say that this movie is possibly even better than The Terminator, and since I think Aliens is better than The Terminator, I think this is on par with Aliens. Give it a try, this is definitely a dormant classic that deserves more exposure than it gets."

b"It was the franchise fight that fans thought would never happen, except in the form of comics. After years and years of failed attempts and false starts, the powers finally succeeded. Hoping to capitalize on the amazing success of the merger of two successful horror franchises with Freddy vs. Jaso, two of the most popular science fiction creatures face each other face to face in Alien vs. Predator with those annoying humans trapped in the middle. There is not a clich\xc3\xa9 and eacute; that this movie does not like Disposable characters are widely sketched. For example, a bottle cap worn around the neck of a character is considered a defining feature. The film even manages to include that old chestnut tree where the characters overcome a fireball explosion. Fans who expect the two alien races to start hitting would have to wait almost an hour until their first battle, but it's pretty impressive as they throw each other out like something out of a comic book. It is true that the fight scenes are great in all their glory assisted by CGI, but this is not an endorsement. Poor Lance Henriksen is swaggering him here as a selfish entrepreneur who provides the only human link to the other Alien films (insinuating that he is the inspiration for the Android bishop in Aliens). It's only in about a quarter of the movie before it's dispatched quickly. There is an audio commentary by writer / director Paul W.S. Anderson and actors Lance Henriksen and Sanaa Lathan. They connect apparently as oblivious to the narrative disorder that is this movie. Also included is an audio commentary from visual effects supervisor John Bruno and creature effects designers Alec Gillis and Tom Woodruff Jr. Anyone who wants to hear these details will find this clue. There are three deleted scenes that total a total of two minutes and include a bit of Predator humor that was cut correctly. Also included are two advances and a gallery of the covers of the comics. to Dark Horse 's Alien vs. Predator series. Alien vs. Predator was not worth the wait and the fans of the comic will feel cheated. The movie begins slowly, but once the aliens and predators begin to hit each other, the weak script and the clumsy plot mercifully fade into the background. It's a shame because both alien races are ready for innumerable story ideas that subsequent sequels have not been able to capitalize effectively. All we have left is a good paint film by numbers."

b"I was terribly excited to discover that one of my favorite classic movies, the 1963 Peter Brooks & quot; Lord of the flies & quot; It was on DVD. I was even more excited when I saw that a study called Criterion had given him a luxury treatment. & quot; Lord of the flies & quot; It was the first DVD I bought and I was introduced to the phenomenal Criterion Collection. Every extra on this DVD is fantastic and interesting, there is no stuffing or no sense praise. The comment alone is worth the price of this DVD, it gives a great idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bhow this movie was made: for example, the film was one of the first independent productions produced. This is one of those rare comments that increase your appreciation and understanding of the film, I classify it next to & quot; Seven samurai & quot; and & quot; Grand Illusion & quot; (also both Criterion dvds) comments as one of the best I've heard. The film seems absolutely fantastic, worlds better than any vhs or laser disk edition I've seen before; Criterion produced an amazing and clean image that will impress in any video configuration. _Lord of the Flies_ is one of my favorite novels; Golding masterfully touched on many themes and concepts about society and managed to capture the essence of humanity in the juvenile cartoons he created. For the most part, those themes and ideas are very faithful in the film. As noted in the dvd commentary; there is no script credit, because there was no script, the production team worked directly from the novel, using it as their only source of history. The result is a remarkably clear and coherent adaptation of the original novel, brought to life with great faith and surprising dexterity for a novice filmmaker. You can still see some technical limitations in the final product, but they do not contribute to your enjoyment of the film. In short: a fantastic, dark and irresistible story is charged to life in such a stark manner that the viewer sometimes seems like a documentary that develops. Finally, to top it off, the film received a real treatment on DVD that perfectly complements and improves the film itself; In total, it is worth the price of admission."

b'Ghost World is an initiation story that defines the character of a generation that is one of the most elusive in modern memory. Enid (Thora Birch) is trapped in a small town with her companions and adults who are not going anywhere. Only Norman, the future passenger of the bus, is reliable from his point of view, perhaps because at least he is trying to leave the city, although this is not something that happens to the audience but something to think about. This is a reflective movie with attractive characters, sharp wit and soft warmth. The composition that includes the use of color in the ensemble and the costumes is exuberant and clear; the editing and the highly expressive camera. I recommend this film to anyone who likes to better understand the lives and problems of middle-class youth struggling with the search for identity at the end of the 20th century.'

b'As a former Marines and Vietnam veteran, I have to disagree with Mr. Brennan\'s interpretation of the second half of this film. The scenes of war were marginal at best and failed to capture the "realism" of the war ... Platoon was much better in that regard. Mainly because Oliver Stone was a veteran, himself. However, the scenes of the training camp at FMJ were accurate. R.Lee Ermey played the Drill Instructor perfectly, as it should have been, after having been the same in real life. I had several D.I. It\'s like that in the training camp and I can assure you that it was during the Vietnam War. Now I can laugh at the movie, but while we were in training camp it was not a matter of laughing, we were there to learn to fight and go to war, other skills were learned, but they were secondary. We had to be tough and they made sure we were there. The training camp portion was almost like a documentary for me! Having said all that, the movie was like two parts to me. The first half and the second half. With one person dead and the other alone and totally based on Hollywood\'s perception of what the war was like. For those who were not there, believe me ... It was very different from this version. In general, due to the performance of R. Lee Ermey and Vincent D\'Onofrio I give him 4 stars.'
